essay:div.essay:p: Secretariat 1936 Document 30 YOSEMITE CONFERENCE SUMMARY Pressing problems of the Pacific area were brought into sharp focus, critically examined and solutions discussed at the Sixth Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations, held in the Yosemite Valley, August 15-29, 1936. Here delegates from countries bordering the Pacific exchanged views with notable freedom. The outstanding result was the development of a spirit of hope that peaceful solutions may be found for issues that might without wise statesmanship, backed by public opinion^ drift into war. Here scholars, statesmen, and men of affairs from eleven coxn' Iri oeeply perturbed by political unrest, East and West, calmly examined some of vhe out¬ standing symptoms of disorder, diagnosed both the immediate ailment ov .:he world and its chronic afflictions, and finally o.rrived at an entirely favosa": le prognosis provided only the patient could be persuaded to give a half-way irrtelj agent cooperation. The occasion was the Sixth Conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations established some ten years ago to study the relations of the Pacific peoplest One of the justifications for optimism was the first appearance as full members of an Institute Conference of representatives from two great nations which can contri¬ bute much to the adjustment of divergent interests in the Pacific area, France and the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics. Another was the unexpected but obvious determination of all the member groups not to use the occasion, as well they might have done, simply to strengthen the case of their respective countries before such a tribunal of intellectuals and thus to bring it to the consciousness of influential circles throughout the world; but rather to take a new departure in international discussion from a candid and realistic analysis of the soro points between the nations. In this they were aided by the character and reputation of the Institute which is made up of non-official member groups in the various countries represen¬ tative in each case of the most advanced scholarship, experience in public affairs, and sensitiveness to social needs. This combination of talents and mentalities can, perhaps, best be illustrated by mentioning a fe^^r of those who took a loading part in the Yosemite Park discussions: to start wi&h the two new member groups already named, France sent Albert Sarraut, barely relieved two or three months ago of his responsibility as Prime Minister, a servant of his country, as legislator and administrative official for more than thirty years. Associated with him were the two best known French authorities on Far Eastern affairs and two men intimate¬ ly acquainted with the economic and political life of Indo-China. The Moscow group had sent Or. V.E. Motylev, economist and geographer, an outstanding figure among Russian social scientists, and associated with him a journalist of inter¬ national reputation. The Chinese group was led by Dr. Hu Shih whose eminence in letters and in education and whose consistent political philosophy through many yours of changing currents of thought in hi3 own country have ensured a hearing for his

utterances on every continent. With him was a distinguished group of scholars, of "business leaders, and of men in public life. The same categories might also be applied to the strong Japanese group which came under the leadership of Dr. Tadao Yamakawa, a member of the House of Peers, and which included such men as Kenkichi Yoshizawa, also a Peer, who was Minister of Foreign Affairs in 1932 and has held many other posts of distinction; a number of economists and political scientists who have taken part in the researches of the Institute for many years; and men close both to the Government and to influential business circles in Japan, a group which, bocause of the variety of its own affiliations, was able to give the Conference a sense of the diversity of Japanese interests in international questions. The British group was headed by the Rt. Hon, A,V, Alexander, Member of Parliament and Labour Leader — believed by many to be destined for an even higher post in the next Labour Government of his country than that which he held in the last which ho served as First Lord of the Admiralty, Representative also of many currents of public opinion, the British group was especially strong in persons of long experience in Far Eastern public and private business. The Philippines, Australia, New Zealand, and the Netherlands took part through the presence of smaller but distinguished groups in each of which wore men and women internationally known for their contributions to the social sciences or for the part they have played in international politics, Canada, because of its geographical nearness, and the United States, as the host country, had the largest member groups, the former headed by that veteran of international discussion, the Hon, Newton W# Rowell, K.C,, who represented the Dominion at the First Assembly of the League of Nations, in 1920; the latter by Dr. Carl L, Alsberg, a scientist who has won international renown by his studies in the world's food supplies. What did the 136 members of the Conference talk about? The subject of the Conference, agreed upon three years ago, was "Aims and Results of Social and Economic Policies in Pacific Countries," The "policies" to be considered were not only those of governments but also those of parties and influential groups. But in order to reduce this vast subject to manageable proportions, preparation and conference discussion was limited, as regards major attention, to four countries: the United States, China, Japan, and the Soviet Union, In each case, the Conference round tables v\rore asked to consider the international implications of recent changes in national economic policy. It was possible to concentrate attention thus on the foreign aspects of what are essentially internal develop¬ ments because these developments themselves were the subject of a rich documenta¬ tion which every participant was expccted to have read - at least to the extent of his own interest. Indeed, it would probably be correct to say that no un¬ official international conference ever has had before it so extensive a collection of data pertinent to the agenda, authoritative as to the facts and scholarly as to interpretation of the facts. Not including several recently published reports of larger Institute studies, there were presented close on sixty of these documents, ranging from brief pamphlets to extensive monographs - the most extensive being the collection from Japan, the most interesting to the Conference members probably that coming from the U,S,S,R., bocause only very few facts about the socialist constructive development in the Far East had been available previously in one of the Western languages. Of course, the reconstruction of China, the economic and strategic expansion policies of Japan, and other topics on the agenda had been the subject of previous Institute studies and, in some cases, of an extensive literature, so that it was possible after a brief review of the facts to proceed to questions of the motives and results of policies, of difficulties encountered in their application, and of their effects on the interests of other countries. As a deliberative body, the Institute of Pacific Relations does not attempt to influence action by governments or other agencies. Nevertheless, both

the composition of its membership and its procedures are designed to marshall the information gained from study in such a way as to present clearly the really significant facts, clarify the problems which they indicate, and to produce agreements as regards the likely direction in which to look for their solution. This is achieved without taking votes and without any attempt to arrive at a tuperficial harmony by driving minority opinions into silence® Starting with nothing more than a common desire to understand a situation and the attitudes held in regard to it, the members net infrequently see ways to overcome difficulties which had not previously occurred to anyone# The present conference was full of such occasions - most notably in the final part of the program which, leaving aside the particular questions facing individual nations, tried to envisage as a whole the changing balance of forces in the Pacific and to examine the possibilities of peaceful adjustment of dif¬ ferences in national purpose. Throughout the preceding discussions the conviction had grown that the problems of the Pacific are too closely connected with those of other parts of the world to make possible effective separate solutions. This thought was clinched with the phrase: "the peace of the world is indivisible." Another conviction which grew from the discussions was that security - economic or political - is unattainable for any one nation or group of nations unless it is shared by all. This thought found expression in a prolonged quest of members for the conditions of "collective security." Third, and considerably slower in maturing because a variety of interpretations gave rise to misgivings as to the exact meaning and possible consequences, was the growth of a belief in "peaceful change." As national interest was seen to clash upon national interest, the un¬ welcome fact gradually became clear that only actual sacrifices of national interests, at least on minor points, can sufficiently lessen the strains and stresses of international relations to ensure the world against disturbances a- rising from changed conditions. At first, the question was raised whether "peaceful change" was not simply a compromise between leading powers by which some of them make to others concessions voluntarily instead of having them wrested from them - in such matters as cossion of territory or re-distribution of markets through bilateral or multilateral agree¬ ments# Such compromises, it was held, if they do not consult interests of the weaker or dependent peoples, may merely transfer the domination over their fortunes, as formerly under the agreements made between dynasties, from one power to another. In the course of a lengthy discussion it was discovered, however, that the chief exponents of the doctrine of "peaceful change" realize the need for drastic re¬ adjustments, not only between the great powers, but also between the dominant and the dependent or semi-dependent peoples. The sort of peaceful change v;hich would reduce international frictions and lay the basis for international cooperation in the interest of stability and progress, it was admitted, would have to reckon with a gradual rise in the economic, political, and social status of populations which have not in the past played a very active part in the determination either of their own fate or that of intornational relations. This realization was closely connected with yet another one, admitted, it is true, in varying degrees of fullness by the representatives of different nations; that the roots of almost every international conflict lie in some maladjustment within one or more of the countries and imperial systems affected. Thus, the weakness of ^hina, brought about only in part by the decay of an economy not easily integrated in that of modern world interdependence but also in part by a long history of foreign aggression, now is the focus of mutual distrust and apprehension between Pacific nations. Thus also the maldistribution of economic power between

different classes and groups in countries i/\foich are counted as strong forces in international affairs, often results of former imperialist adventures, give rise to internal difficulties which in turn find vent in disturbances of the respective country*s foreign relations. Examples of this are the lack of consuming power through the great disparity of incomes in such countries as the United States which seek to throw on the world markets products which might well "be absorbed at home if a fair minimum standard of life could be maintained but which, as surplus* in competition with the products of other countries, arc liable to lower world prices to a level at which these commodities can no longer be advantageously produced® Another example is the growth of a surplus population which, in a country like Japan, unable to find buyers for its products in an impoverished^ peasantry, must needs seek outlets either in opportunities for emigration or in opportunities to engage in export industries «• again loading to a disturbance of friendly international relations as foreign countries raise barriers against the admission of both Japanese immigrants and Japanese products. While most of these problems arc familiar ones, the situation in the Pacific area has greatly changed, it appeared, with the emergence of the Soviet Union as a norr factor to bo reckoned with. Although the U.S.S.R, is almost self- sufficient and needs neither additional territory nor foreign trade to uphold its internal strength, the very fact that it need not compromise its interests to procure advantages abroad is looked upon with misgivings by certain other natiorio. Though in fact it has given many evidences of a desire to participate in the stabilization of international relations and is far less isolationist in its policies than the United States, the noarness of this strong young power^to the chief trouble spots of the Pacific is viewed with alarm by somo because its econ¬ omy and political system are so different from those of other countries as to make incalculable the lines of policy which they would acquire if one of the neighbors should seriously weaken in its power of resistance. It was realized, especially in the light of the trends which have developed in the course of the recent v/orld economic depression, that even so powerful ana aggressively advanc¬ ing a country as Japan is fragile in the sense that any new pressures from with¬ out, or any support from without for tendencies of social division within, might eventually have catastrophic consequences. A majority of the members of the Conference accepted at its face value the statement of representatives of the Soviet Union that their country had no desire to foment trouble abroad - and in this they were upheld by the record of recent years. It was admitted that the example of a successful socialist construction in the U.S.S.R* might be a dis¬ turbing element in the inner harmony of neighboring countries. The tendency of the Conference to look for the causes of international friction in the mal-distribution of possessions and opportunities both as between nations and as within each nation, was re-inforcod by the contributions to Its discussions of representatives of two great international bodies which have re¬ cently engaged in searching investigations of those causes, the International Labour Office and the International Institute of Intellectual Cooperation. The International Studies Conference of the latter, in fact, is paralleling on a European background the Institute of Pacific Relations' investigations of the part which overpopulation and the uneven distribution of essential food stuffs and industrial and raw materials play in international conflict. As regards the latter problem, the Conference came to the conclusion- somewhat surprising to many of the members — that after all the outstanding difficulty, at least in times of peace, is not that some nations arc self- sufficient in regard to the raw materials which they require while othors have to seek them in territories under foreign rule; but that it is the inability to pur¬ chase such materials when quota and tariff barriers prevent the free sale of commodities the returns from which might be offerod in payment. It was in the

light of this conclusion that tho Confcronce paid much attention to possibilities of freeing the clogged channels of international trade. In general, it was felt that where, faced with the necessity of protecting its own industries, a country must place restrictions upon imports of competitive commodities, a system of quotas is more advantageous than one of prohibitive tariff ratesj for, while a quota on imports - whether general or in regard to those from a given country - can be raised or lowered from time to time to admit such quantity of the respective commodity as the country requires and can admit -without danger to its own pro¬ ducers, a tariff is much less flexible but, a continuing barrier to the degree of its effectiveness in helping industries of little internal vitality to sur- vive0 Another conclusion was that bilateral trade agreements, though sometimes the only practicable first stop to revive an international exchange of commodities, are likely to close channels of trade between the contracting parties and third parties. For this reason, multilateral agreements and those containing a "most- favored-nation1' clause were regarded as more advantageous, usually,for the ro- vival of stagnant international trade. It became clear that the demand of some nations for free access to raw materials essentially has a strategic motivation with a view to possible future wars. The members of the round tables thus faced the dilemma that if they sub¬ scribed to the view that nations deficient in such essential raw materials as metals, coal, cotton, and chemical substances, should be assured of them either by cession of territories or by special treaties, they tended to strengthen preparedness for war; if, on the other hand, they declared such special adjust¬ ments unnecessary because in timcs of peace every nation can buy what it can afford to pay for, the grievances in this respect would continue to exist as potent sources, in association with others, of international conflict. For those and other reasons, tho Conference was driven to recognize that all poacemeal readjustments between individual nations are insufficient to dissipate the war cloud which hangs over tho Pacific area as over the rest of the world; and that only a complete change in the trend of national policies from self-protection to trust in agencies of collective peace can produce the pro- requisite conditions for a lasting peace. This, however, requires not only^a strengthening of treaty provisions to make more difficult violations by individual powers; it also requires a change of mentality from fear and distrust to confi¬ dence and trust in international cooperation. Hence some attention was given also to the place which public opinion must play in strengthening tho forces that make for intcrnational understanding. In this connection it may be stated that in the research program of the Institute which is only in part linked to the preparation for its conferences inquiries into economic causes of mal¬ adjustment are now being matched in most of the member countries by studios of public opinion on international questions and the part played by the press in influencing that opinion. The Yosomite Conference was the most successful of those held thus far by the Institute of Pacific Relations «• chiefly because of a much more adequate pre¬ paration for it on the part of the National member groups and of the International Secretariat than was possible in earlier years. Several of the members who had attended more than one conference declared tliat tho Institute had now, in its tenth year, entered the age of maturity, !/fhile that maturity is still that of young and vigorous manhood rather than of ripe experience, it was felt that the Institute has proved its worthwhileness. It has become accepted in the most influential quarters of many countries as a valuable voluntary and non-official counterpart of the diplomatic machinery.

The Conferences, held every two or throe years, are only one of the Institute's activitiesj many consider it less important, in fact, than the continuous research work conducted by the member National Councils in accordance with a concerted international program, and the day-by-day diffusion of knowledge from the eleven national offices. Some of these offices are now equipped with extensive research and reference libraries® Several of the National Councils have periodical organs of their own, in addition to the international Institute quarterly, "Pacific Affairs," All of them have become, for their respective countries or regions - for, in several cases the National Councils conduct their activities through a number of regional branch offices - recognized sources of authoritative information on the peoples and affairs of the Pacific area. No announcement has yet been made where the next Conference is to be held; but there is a considerable demand that again, as in 1929 and in 1931, it shall be in the Far East0 Provision has also been made for more frequent smaller interim conferences for specific purposes between the general conferences of the Institute, The general policy of the Institute is to carry on its work as much as possible through the National Councils, acting to some degree under the direc¬ tion and with the assistance of the International Secretariat. Privately financed, the Institute thus uses its resources to the largest possible extent in the direct pursuit of its object rather than in the building up of a costly central machinery* There is the less need for the latter in that the Secretariat is largely a peri¬ patetic one - strengthened in turn by a frequent interchange of national secre¬ tarial personnel «• and in that the leading personalities in the various member groups have become internationally linked by such close sense of fellowship in the common task that understanding and cooperation between them is of an un¬ usually strong and intimate nature. The Yosemite Conference again demonstrated that international under¬ standing begins with a serious effort to know the thoughts and the worries of the other fellowj and that where mutual knowledge grows, mutual liking follows of itself. NOTE: This summary was prepared by a member of the Conference but this does not imply that it represents the views of all the members of the Conference or of the Institute as a whole.

ROUND TABLE TOPIC I, AUGUST 16, 1935 (Dr. Joseph S » Davis) I interpret, as I think the Program Committee has interpreted, the American Recovery Program broadly to include the whole group of politico-economic measures of the Roosevelt Administration, "beginning with the executive action shortly after the inauguration in March 1933, continuing with the legislation of one hundred days in the special session of Congress, and followed "by a con¬ siderable number of other executive acts and legislative measures. The recovery objective was prominent in many of these measures, but by no means always dominant. Relief, reform, social experimentation, and political exigency were all involved and sometimes dominant. Moreover, it was a program only in a loose sense. At the outset, certainly, there was nothing like a com¬ prehensive coherent plan, but rather a combination of schemes urged by persons of differing opinions. Gradually the administration undertook to do more "national planning," and to work toward something which might be called a "national plan." But what has thus far evolved has never constituted a compre¬ hensive integrated plan, nor one primarily devoted to recovery* It is perhaps necessary in our discussions to concentrate more on those parts which relate to recovery, but by no means all of the significant acts with international im¬ plications were designed as recovery measures. I think we should bear in mind th^t to the formulation and execution of a program of planned economic adjust¬ ment, including not only those mentioned in the handbook outline, but also those limitations of time and of human capacity. The Administration began its work toward the end of a 12--month's period including the presidential campaign, in which were reached the depths of severe depression - agricultural industrial, and commercial; and also in a psychological crisis of fear and unrest which found partial reflection in the closing of banks through failure on an increasing scale. It was out of such emergency psychoses that the early emergency program took shape=. It was designed, to meet the psychological crisis and the banking difficulties and, if possible, to reverse the "vicious spiral," as it was called, of economic recession. Action - boldc. decisive government action, was called for over a wide front. It could not wait on the development of integrated plans. "Do something, " was the watchword, "for God's sake, do something." There were consistent efforts, however, to avoid dictatorial methods and to win and maintain the support, not only of Congress but of the public at large. Never before has there been such a large grist of press releases put out by the government, and never before has there been such extensive and effect¬ ive use of the radio in the interests of government measures.

The early objectives of this policy of action were to raise commodity prices and increase purchasing power. Not only in the early weeks of the ad¬ ministration, "but again in October, President Roosevelt emphasized his intention to raise the price level from the depths to which it had fallen in the past three years# "Do it we will" he said, "in one way, if not in another«" The increase of purchasing power of the farmers, particularly of the wage earners, was like-' wise considered a primary objective. President Hoover had enunciated the dictum, "We cannot spend ourselves into prosperity." The new administration replied, in effect: "We shall try to," and undertook to pour out money on a large scale. The idea was to raise commodity prices and to increase purchasing power, both speedily and substantially. It is of two groups of measures directed toward these objectives that I wish to speak - the monetary policy and the agricultural program The monetary policy was directed toward the first of the general object¬ ives, raising the level of commodity prices. The first step was to abandon re¬ demption of currency in gold, and to restrict exports of gold. Then gold in private possesion was called in. Then the purchase of gold at higher and higher prices was adopted. Finally came the president's action devaluating the dollar in terms of gold. These were deliberate moves, not forced by technical necessity. Those who regard them as a necessity find that necessity in the psychological and economic situation rather than in any technical condition,of the currency. But it was also in the minds of those who were responsible for those moves that we could not merely raise prices thereby, but also institute a reform in the direction of stabilizing price levels - establishing what Professor Fisher called the "stabilized dollar," what Secretary Wallace had called the "honest dollar," what the opponents called the "rubber dollar." The initial moves,were hurriedly made, on the advice of one or two unorthodox advisers. By no means all of the domestic implications were con¬ sidered; there was not time. To some extent international implications were taken into account, but.they were not given great weight and were not allowed to interfere with what was deemed to be a domestically justified nove to raise the general price level. The results of the monetary policy were too numerous to discuss in full One of the earliest effects was a strong speculative boom, from April to July, 1933. which had a marked influence on our course of development. This boom was quickly followed by severe recession, and this in turn, by new efforts to bring about price advances of a more durable character. With respect to its main objectives, it is safe to say that the gold or currency policy gravely dis¬ appointed the Administration's hopes and expectations. Soon the adviser who had strongly urged it disappeared, and the confident assurances that its objects would be achieved were forgotten. The price level, indeed, rose from the depths to which it had fallen, particularly after the adverse weather of 1934 had severely cut the supply of various agricultural products, as well as during 1933-34 when the Nra Was working similarly in the direction of increasing prices. One of the greatest difficulties in appraising the elements of the recovery pro¬ gram lies in determining their share of responsibility for the factual results to which many factors contributed. So it is with the influence of the monetary policy on the general price level. It is not known to what extent it was the cause of the advance that occurred. Surely it was not completely responsible. The fact remains that the price level today is still well below the level of 1926, which was often referred to as the goal of the policy.

I turn now to the agricultural program. What was called The Farm Act of 1933, one of the emergency measures of the first hundred days, had three important sections or "titles." The last of these provided the legislative "basis for the president's action on the monetary policy, uhus linking the monetary with the agricultural program» Another was the Emergency Farm Credit Act, under which a Farm Credit Administration was set up with broad powers and responsibilities. In the data papers that have "been submitted to you. com¬ paratively little attention has been given to the Farm Credit Administration# Yet its work in the past three years, in the fields of debt relief, debt re¬ ad justment, and expansion of credit to farmers, has been carried out on a major scale and has unquestionably contributed greatly to the improvement of the financial position of the farmers* Its real importance, indeed, may have been as large as that of the more spectacular Agricultural Adjustment Administration# The AAA, as we may call its was se^ ^P under the first title of the Farm Act of 1933, called the Agricultural Adjustment Act. It was an outgrowth of prolonged planning (or plotting). Prominent in it, however, was the idea of production control which had come rather recently into the field of agrarian thought. Not until after the 1932 election, indeed, v/ere any of the farm organizations pledged to production control, and it was not even mentioned in Governor Roosevelt's Topeka speech of September 1932, in which he announced the principles of a farm relief program. One of the main objectives of the AAA was to cut down the production, temporarily at least, of great staples of which we produce an export surplus, in order, particularly, to reduce the supplies which had been carried over and were not readily salable, and to raise prices oi these products both immediately and in the longer run. A second objective was to pour funds promptly into the farmers' hands. In part these were to be paid to induce farmers to curtail their acreage or production, as "rental or benefit payments." Soon, however, without special provision for it in the Adjustment Act, the ■Administration arranged for heavy loans to the producers of cotton and corn, with the same objective - particularly, in the case of corn growers, where it was found impossible to get benefit payments to them for several months to come. Also supplementing these loans and benefit payments, extensive purchases of various farm products were made by the AAA or the Federal Surplus Relief Corporation,, and these distributed to families on relief. These purchases were made primarily to raise the price of the products concerned, and to speed the flow of the money into the farmers' hands„ but the relief dumping ground was chosen in preference to an ex'port dumping ground. Efforts were made to proceed throughout with the cooperation of the farmers, both in connection with all phases of the programs for adjustment of acreage and production, and even in connection with the loan and surplus purchase schemes. I think we have.never before had such a painstaking effort on the part of the government to proceed with the full knowledge and cooperation of the beneficiaries of the plan. Even when Congress passed two acts, the Bankhead Act and the Kerr-Smith Act, under which coercive taxes were imposed to compel cotton and tobacco growers.to participate in the adjustment plans, this action was not taken until the administration had assurance that the farmers concerned would welcome such action.

Eventually, the production control Measures and the other emergency actions, including the loan and surplus purchase plans, wore gradually converted in the minds of the administration into permanent ones. Without alteration of the emergency sections of the "basic act, what had been purely emergency measures were held to be v; or thy of continuance as part of a permanent policy. Along with this, there were added some other elements of a "planned agriculture," in¬ cluding efforts to arrive at a "planned use" of agricultural land# I think it is fair to say that the international implications of the agricultural program, were more fully considered than was the case with many of the other government measures• Perhaps this was because of the personnel that had the leadership in this program. It was accepted, for example, that the restriction of production would for the time being restrict our export of the products concerned; but it was considered that this was essential in order to meet a changed situation in which foreign countries were less able and willing to buy these products. In no sense and in no case was permanent abandonment of the foreign market- contemplated. In the case of wheat, moreover, the United States sought and got an.international wheat agreement for the regulation of the flow of exports and for the readjustment of the world wheat supply to the world wheat requirements. High hopes were entertained for this and other potential agreements, and it was a great disappointment to the administration when it broke down before the end of the first year. Export subsidies had ior years been urged as a means of aiding farmers, and under other leadership it is quite possible that large~scale experiments with such subsidies would have been adopted. T^e international implications of such subsidies were considered^ objectionable, and the utmost Secretary Wallace permitted to be done in this direction was an export subsidy scheme in 1933—34 under which 23 million busnels of wheat (in grain and flour) v;ere exported from the Pacific Northwest, nearly half of it to China, under a loan to the Chinese Government. Only recently, in April 1936, was this policy of export subsidies renewed, but then limited only to flour from three Pacific Northwest states to the Philippines. Congress adopted in August, 1935, an amendment - Section 32 of a series of sections amending the Agricultural Adjustment Act - providing for more extensive resort to export subsidies. President Roosevelt in January, 1936, recommended the re¬ peal of this section. When Congress did not repeal it, but strengthened it^ instead, the Administration made no further objection; but the extent to which export subsidies have been resorted to has been exceedingly limited. So far it constitutes a very minor element in our policy, and little more than a con¬ cession to congressional demands for some action of this sort. The difficulty of assessing the results of the agricultural program is very large, not only because in the course of its operation there has been some genuine economic recovery in this country and abroad — to whatever cause that recovery may be ascribed — but also because the weather has played an especially important part in the past three or four seasons. The droughts of 1934 and 1936, and adverse weather also in 1933 and 1935, played important parts in curtailing production of farm products and raising farm prices and farmer income. The production control program of the Administration really had a major rusulc only in the case of cotton, where the crops of the 3 years, 1933—35, were perhaps 2djo smaller than they would have been in the absence of any such restrictions. In the case of wheat, almost the entire reduction was to be charged to tne weather and almost none to the AAA. In the case of corn, the responsibility for the reduction was divided between the two, but in two of the three years adverse

weather was more of a factor than official restrictions. In rice the AAA re¬ strictions were largely effective, but the crop is not of national importance. The loan on cotton was of major importance "because it kept prices higher than they would otherwise have "been, restricted exports materially and created an embarrassing "corpse" for the government to dispose o^. In respect to cotton^ most of the price advance that was achieved "as due to the AAA. coujjled with such aid as was given by the monetary policy of the administration* but with. regard to wheat, corn, and hogs, most of the advances were due to the adverse weather conditions. In practically every case except tobacco, however, the price advance fell far short of that which was called the "fair exchange value" or '• parity" price at which Congress had directed the AAA to aim. It proved, and the AAA soon recognized, that restriction of production in the amount necessary to raise prices to the so-called "parity level" would arouse antagonism from the general public and cause farmers to lose more in volume than they gained thru price advances. Hence the administration recognized that the production control system was a weaker force in the attainment of its objective than it had originally anticipated. Moreover, the production control system under voluntary contracts was in the process of breaking down - not where it was applied with coercive measures, as to cotton, and tobacco, but where the rental and benefit system Y/as relied upon. An increasing amount of wheat was being planted by persons who had not signed contracts with the government. The acreage sown for the crop of 1935 exceeded that of the base period for the entire country, instead of falling 10$ short of it, as the administration had wished. Plans.to make this system permanent were underway, and new contracts were formulated or signed, when the Supreme Court made its adverse decision on January 6, 1936. That decision did not entirely invalidate the agricultural acto It threw out the production control, processing tax, and benefit payment systemj on the .grounds that it invaded the constitutional rights of the states. This was a crippling bio?/, but it did not kill the AAA nor interfere with various other elements in its program. In respect to production control, indeed, this may have been a blessing in disguise to the AAA* It probably averted a disastrous breakdown in the system that was underway. It did force a radical and sudden change in plans but under the new Soil Conservation and Domestic Allottment Act, the AAA is undertaking to go as far as possible in the same direction, while putting great emphasis on the conservation of soil and soil fertility® It seems.likely that this act will not come before the Supreme Court before it is replaced by joint action with the states that is planned to go into effect early in 1938. It is impossible accurately to assess the distribution of burdens and benefits under the agricultural adjustment program. Not all of the benefit pay¬ ments paid to farmers represented a new addition to their income, though the greater part of it dido The advance in prices was largely offset by the re¬ duction in volume attributable to the AAA, and the net income of the grower was not particularly enhanced thereby. Of the increased income of farriers during 1933—35, a large part is due to the recovery that has been experienced in general, part to the accidental effects of adverse weather, and part to the benefit pay¬ ments and certain official acts of the AAA. Perhaps the AAA contribution may be put in the neighborhood of a billion dollars or somewhat more, for the 3 years under consideration. The burdens were widely distributed but to a considerable extent fell on the great mass of consumers of agricultural products, including farmers, though some part fell on processors and distributors.

Kreps) First I wish to pay passing mention to the silver policy of the Ad¬ ministration. As you know, early in 1933, the President was authorized to accept limited quantities of silver, computed at $1.29 an ounce, in payment of interest and principal on the war debts, a measure used by Great Britain to make a token payment in 1933, and then droppecl. Then the World Economic Conference brought forth a silver agreement among the countries of the world, which in effect sought to make permanent the status quo. Finally, in June of 1934, the Silver purchase Act made it mandatory upon the Secretary of the Treasury to buy silver in world markets until the metallic base back of our paper currencies consisted one fourth of silver. About 835,000*000 oz. of silver was purchased, the price jumping from 48 cents in June of 1934 to 81 cents in 1935, and falling back to about 45 cents at the present time, for the administration has since last November not pursued its purchase policy with any noticeable degree of vigor. The fact I wish to emphasize concerning silver policy is that accord¬ ing to the most charitable view one can take of it, it was definitely regarded as a stimulant of foreign trade. Silver producers had long maintained that raising the price of silver would raise the purchasing power of the Orient, indeed, according to some, of the peoples of India as well as China, that is, one-half the population of the world. This view had been thoroughly exploded in serious economic literature, but it found influential exponents in such persons as Dr. Will Burant, and Mr. Robert Brownell of the American Smelting and Refining Corporation. It was apparently these experts to Whom administra¬ tion circles lent favorable ear. Political representation from the seven silver-producing states no doubt also received a certain amount of consideration. It is not accurate to say that the opinion of experts on the silver question was wholly ignored, however. Early in 1934, a mission was sent to the Orient, but their report was never made public, from which the inference is readily drawn that possibly the experts were unable to corroborate the assertions of silver producers. While this part of the New Deal foreign trade policy failed dismally, if indeed it did not do gratuitous mischief, the rest of it, notably the re¬ ciprocity trade agreements met with a considerable degree of success. The situation in American foreign trade need not be described except to say that exports and imports had fallen in 1932 roughly to one-half in volume, and two- thirds in money values, from their 1929 levels. Consequently in 1934, a Trade Agreements Act was passed, giving the President power to raise or lower tariffs by not more than 50$. Fourteen such agreements have now been negotiated, the most important being that with Canada. Time makes it impossible to summarize their provisions, except to say that agreements have been made with 8 of our 20 best customers, and now cover about 40$ of our imports and 35$ of our exports.

In addition to the reciprocity trade agreements, there are certain general agreements that deserve passing mention, notably those with Czecko- slovakia and Ecuador, providing for reciprocal unconditional most-favored nation. treatment and the exchange of notes "between Bullitt and Litvinoff, whereby Soviet Russia agreed to buy not less than $30,000,000 worth in the TJnited States. These agreements indicate that where possible,.the United States has not abandoned its traditional preference for most-favored nation policy. It dis¬ likes special preferences and special bargains. One additional factor should be stressed. Even the shifts in foreign trade policy in the United States, and its shift to bargaining and quotas, were not made with a view primarily to the needs or problems of foreign countries. On the contrary, the primary emphasis, it seems to me, has been on the domestic welfare of domestic industries. The administration in its bargaining thinks primarily of stimulating exports for domestic industries, a viewpoint of course of long standingj except that now it is coupled with the realization that ex¬ ports are bought with imports and consequently concessions must be offered. In the Canadian agreement, the reduction in duty on live cattle has been computed. as averaging $9.00 per head. The increased imports of live cattle have enabled Canadians to increase their purchases of manufactured goods, notably furniture. Domestic problem?,domestic advantage, have been the ruling considerations. In how far the increase in exports has been due to these trade policies I know no way of assessing.* Turning now to the MR A, I am, of course, in no way even able to touch the high spots. It can be discussed as a measure of recovery and of reform. In passing I might observe that the distinction so often made between relief, re¬ covery and reform is not as valid as it is cometimes alleged to be. Dr. Davis and I, in looking at the wilderness of alphabeteria, decided merely to take up devaluation, AAA. silver, reciprocal trade agreements and. BRA as the most im¬ portant recovery measures having international implications. Of these it should be noted that MA has in it the most generous admixture of reform. Yet I do not regard, nor has it been so regarded in administration circles, that recovery and reform are contradictory policies. In many cases recovery could not be achieved except through reform. This is probably the most significant aspect of the KRA experience. Eor it seems to me that BRA and other reform measures show something of a definite change in viewpoint on the part of the American government. Prior to 1933, there was a tendency to look upon the American economic system as reason¬ ably perfect, and to attribute domestic ills to some "foreign devil®" Ex¬ planations of the depression, at least officially, usually looked upon it as something that slunk in upon us surreptitiously from abroad. The war in Europe. currency fluctuations, movements of long and short term capital, especially for¬ eign withdrawals of gold were commonly emphasized. Since 1933, considerably greater.heed has been given those who were analyzing rather than eulogizing our own system with the result that there exists a greater consciousness of its defects. .Sometimes, indeed, responsible officials have suggested that there may have been something in our economy that caused the depression in other countriese We have recognized more that our own house was not in order, and been less disposed to lecture other countries. In fact, in some circles there ex¬ ists active admiration of foreign countries, notably England and Sweden, and to some slight extent of Russia.

This has not meant any real loss of allegiance to the American economic system. Despite the political froth of the moment, a temporal condition of the mouths of opposite camps of American politicians, largely assumed for purposes of preserving or securing the political patronage that follows success in elections, the American people, in my judgment, still adhere firmly, in their ideals at anj rate, to the principles of laissez faire. This laissez faire as I have said elsewhere does not mean merely "absence of government interference - For that is nothing "but anarchism. It means rather an all around renunciation of and "binding guarantee against special interest legislation*... If we roughly translate laissez faire as {let alone1 it never meant that government should in all matters let "business alone, or let the people as individuals or as groups and classes alone in their "business dealings and relations with one anothern It meant rather that the government should compel all classes and individuals to let one another alone, or keep their hands off wealth "belonging to others * In substance it is the American ideal of the athletic field, where,, to realize the noble ideals of fair play and equal opportunity, referees continuously exercise control over competitive activities in order that a maximum of liberty may be enjoyed by the contestants. So that each may secure the maximum individual reward commensurate with individual effort and individual ability, lanes or areas are narked out within which competitors must stay. In order to ensure better playing of the game. all the.rules, no matter how old, are regarded as being constantly on trial and changed when necessary by a rules committee which meets frequently for that purpose." The real shift in our recovery policy is that in our conception of what makes the business system go. Formerly we believed in the 11 trickling down" theory. Recovery then meant recovery of profits and of returns to investors and enterprisers. Government action was used to pay interest to bond-holders and stimulate confidence among business men, all of this in the belief that such would promote the largest possible volume of industrial activity, the largest possible employment at highest possible wages. Now the action of government is based on a different observation, that of millions of farmers and laborers, who, while untrained in economic science none the less possess votes, and seem to be surprisingly unanimous in their belief that prosperity does not trickle down, but is diffused upv/ard. As they see it, feed income or purchasing power into laborers and farmers, and instead of going down it seems sometimes with distressing celerity and irresistible force to trickle up rather than down. This is, of course, a very old theory, one first advanced by the Swiss economist Sismondi in 1819, in a book entitled "Some New Principles of Political Economy0" It is curious that he recommended four items: abolition of child labor, a shorter work week, a minimum wage, and in effect, social security legislation. The URA thus attempted to promote recovery not only directly by en¬ abling industries organized under codes to put into effect monopolistic devices, control of production and marketing, which were thought would, and which did, increase prices and profits, but also by effecting labor reforms which have long

"been put into practice in certain industrialized countries of Europe* I should add that there has "been recovery* Ihe laborers in NRA industries whose incomes had "been most severely hit have experienced an increase of not less than 2ofc m real income. On the other hand, salaried workers and those with fixed incomes. who were "benefiting undeservedly from lowering prices during the period f.t or: 1929 to 1933 are seeing a part of their unearned increment in real in-ionics taken away from them* parm income has likewise increased, as Dr. Davis po.'ntod out.» The cost of living has risen slightly., from an average oi 80*8 in .U-Vyi to 81.-1 in 1935c Wholesale prices rose rapidly some 25'jo in 19-r53? hut have been remark¬ ably stable for the last eighteen.months* Dividend and interest payments ere ^ running currently very near their 19^6 levels a Employment has-, h owevor, no-. i.<- creased as much as had "been hoped. But 1 do not believe that anyone can say.how much has been due to recovery measures and how much would have occurred no matter what brand of politicians had been successful in the elections of '193-3. In conclusion, I want to pose three questions. Last nignt, Mr. Hoxland emphasised that the solution of our international difficulties may await tho completion of certain internal changes economically and socially in the various countries at interest. Conforming to his duties as host at the opening con¬ ference he naturally made commendatory reference to the economic systems of our guestsc But this morning, may we Americans be permitted to cease being quite so tactful and inasmuch a.s you are studying America first, suggest that the American economic system of laissez faire be considered for its ins truetiveness. In fact, of course, our economic structure falls short of this ideal, bub we believe the goal of our striving is not only good for us cut good for otner countries in the Pacific. .Many of the innovations of the Hew Deal are not exclusively American any more than the situation out of which they arose is an exclusively -American situation. Many of the measures of the ITew Deal are functioning in other Pacific countries. You, toor have made some concessions to the "trickling up' or "sucking up" theory® Let us compare notes.' Which of these measures has vonceci out well in all countries? Which has worked badly? Which has been boih good and bad? Why? Economic scientists have such a distressingly small amount 02 real insight compared with the demands made upon them.
