Secretariat 1936 Document 22 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON U.S.A. ROUND TABLE TOPIC I, AUGUST 17, 1936 (A.F.W. Plumptre) As Dr. Dafoe said, I want to speak for a short time this evening about the general economic effects of what might be called the New Deal policies on Canada and on other countries in general, and to do that I want to divide the New Deal policies which I am going to consider into three separate categories. In the first category I want to group those price raising policies which included the NRA, the object of which was partly price raising, the monotary policy such as the Public Works policy, and the gold devaluation policy. All these policies had as part of their objects at least the raising of general prices. My second category is the AAA., which was partly also directed at raising agricultural prices but had as part of its program also a certain reduction of output® And lastly, the third category I want to say a few words about the new trade agreement policy. I understand that the New Deal policies, particularly those in the first category which I mentioned, arc not so popular in the United States as they wore three years ago, and I understand also that the Supreme Court has dealt them a blow which, if not mortal, may at least be described as an unkind cut. In spite of all that I come not to bury but to praise the New Deal. I have heard in these discussions, perhaps more particularly from my elders and betters in the last two days, a good deal of criticism of the New Deal and its policies and its re¬ sults, and I take at once for my defense and my text this evening, "Out of the mouths of babes and sucklings hast thou ordained praise." First of all I want to turn to the expansionist policies which increased or had as an object the increasing of prices and purchasing power. These policies all of them, I think - had singularly favorable repercussions upon Canada - more favorable than upon the United States, for in Canada we got most of the benefit with little of the ill effects which you had in the United States. In fact, I think one can claim that of all the countries in the world, not excluding, the United States, Canada, profited most from the New Deal. Take, for instance, the NRA. We profited first of all out of the short¬ lived boom in 1933, that short speculative restocking boom - we profited as did large numbers of Canadian business men and also Canadian agricultural producers profited out of that short-lived more or less speculative boom. We profited in the longer run insofar as the NRA put more money in the hands of workers in the form of higher wages, and insdSbr as those workers spent that money, as many of them must have done, first directly upon Canadian goods coming in as tourists, as so many do in the summertime, or indirectly through American importers bring¬ ing in goods from Canada. We gained in that way, but on the other hand in Canada the profitableness of this new spending was not offset, as it was in large measure in the United States, by the increase of costs due to increased wages; nor in Canada were the businessmen hampered and bothered first by the formulation of codes and then by the evasion of them. Turning from the NRA to the public spending programs again Canada benefit¬ ed in large measure, I feel, as the result of indiroct spending at once through tourists again or upon imports from Canada, We gained from the favorable effects from that spending, but did not accumulate debts \vhich are acting in this country as a deterrent to businessmen. Take the gold revaluation policy, or if you like

the depreciation of the .American dollar in terms of gold and to a rather less extent at the same time in terms of sterling, Canada profited very greatly out of that 1933 reshuffle of currencies* Previously we had been in a very "bad position® Since 1931^ when Great Britain abandoned the gold standard, the pound sterling had been at a substantial depreciation below -American funds, and the Canadian dollar had stood halfway between appreciation, in terns of sterling, and depreciation in terms of the Canadian dollar. That was an unfavorable situation, just insofar as a very important part of Canadian international transactions con¬ sist, to put it very roughly in this «. of selling goods like wheat to England and getting in return from that English pounds v/hich are swapped for American dollars, and those American dollars were used either to buy imports from the United States or to pay debts, of which wo have very many and very large ones in the United States - and we do pay them® When the pound sterling depreciates in terms of the American dollar and we sell wheat in England, we get about the same amount of pounds in England but that buys fewer American dollars, and thattf therefore, pays fewer debts and buys fewer imports in the United States. Since"1931 we have been in an unfavorable situation in the world currency situation® With the Roosevelt devaluation in 1933, however, that particular situation in the world currencies was completely reversed, the Canadian dollar depredated below its old parity as against sterling, and rose to slight appreciation over parity with the American dollar for a very short time® There again the American policy had favorable repercussions upon the world® The gold policy had a further favorable effect, in that in 1928 or 1929 we were exporting gold valued at about 140,000,000. Today our annual exports of gold are well over $100,000,000 and here gold promises to be the second most val¬ uable single commodity in our volume of exports. To mention one policy - the silver policy - our silver producers benefit¬ ed as did American producers here in this country® And I think that there can be little doubt that as there were favorable actions of the American policy on Canada, there were favorabie reactions of the American policy back on the United States itself® For as our exports improved and as our business conditions improved, so we purchased more from the United States, and there has been a marked revival since 1933 of our purchases in this country® Indeed, the rate of improvement since 1933 - a year after the Ottawa agreements « the rate of improvement of our purchases in the United States has been a good deal greater than the rate of improvement of our purchases from Great Britain® Now I want to turn one moment to the effects of the AAA, my second category® This had as an objective the raising of agricultural prices and also to limit output. With tho rise in prices, a reduction in output occurred but there are those who believed this was not due to the AAA but grow out of benefits of the drought of 1934, 1935, and 1936. Be that as it may, there is no doubt that a certain amount of restriction has taken place - certain amount of diminished output has been achieved and a certain amount of price rise may be attributed to the administration, and this has given a much needed fillip in some of tho hard-pressed areas of the Canadian agricultural east and west® So much for the rosy effects of the administration's policy upon Canada® Now just a word or two about those effects upon countries other than Canada. No doubt it would be interesting and profitable to take the 52 countries of-' world one by one and consider their position one after another. 1 remember that Puck, I believe, put a girdle around the earth in 40 minutes and brought back a sleeping

potion, and I will take warning from that, and only in very general terms will discuss the effects of the .American New ^eal upon the world in general® I have already pointed out that in this New Doal a large number of cards slipped across - if I may use a joke which I have already used in the round table - the cards slipped across the 3,000 miles of unprotected frontier and most of those turned out to be trumps, The same effects must have boon at work, in a lesser extent no doubt, but to an appreciable extent in very many other countries® I have an idea that many other countries benefited as a result of exports and as regards increased prosperity, raised prices, etc. Speaking entirely personally, I have been surprised to find in this conference so little appreciation, as it seems to mo, among delegates from countries other than the United States, of the effects of the United States program upon themselves analogous to this I have just described upon Canada® The tendency here seems to have been, in a very short experience among the foreign delegations, if I may include myself in that term - the tendency among foreign delegates seems to be to view the ^R/i and all the New Deal policies in general with a mixture of scorn and pity, and to regard as most obnoxious all those policies whoso immediate effects wore not largely internal but whose cffocts were largely external, whether meant to be or not, such as the gold purchasing policy® These they regarded as terrible blows to recovery and the things which have made impossible international cooperation® Personally, 1 am still sufficient¬ ly wicked and unorthodox to believe that - to use an eminent economists^ phrase - in 1933 President Roosevelt's determination to concentrate upon the internal situation and to refuse to stabilize was "magnificently right®" I think ho was right from his own point of view and the world1 s point of view® Quite apart from that, I do feel that the not hard hit arrangement of United States they seem to mo to have borne the brunt of the depression, so the United States in various areas and in various ways by the accumulation of debt in the drought area, in the area of labor troubles, I feel that in these areas and in such ways the United States has been paying a fairly high pricc for en¬ gineering world recovery, recovery that has gone on as in Canada so in other countries in a more stable way than it would have done had the United States not adopted the policies which she actually did® Now just ono or two final words about trade agreements, my third cat¬ egory® The Canadian trade agreement, considered by all odds the most important of the .American agreements for the Canadian trade with the United States, is roughly five times as big as the trade of that country whoso exchanges with the United States arc next great® Important as that agreement i s to the United States, it is even more important, ^ think, for Canada when ono realizes that about 60% of our imports come from the United States and about 30% of our oxports or more go to the United States, to realize the dependence which we have upon this country, and in addition to that th^re is a tremendous tourist trade which drives people like myself and other members of the delegation out of Toronto and other contors during the summer® I believe that the new trade agreement will encourage trade, I need not specify - you would not bo interested if I told you the other exact lines of the agreement. The movements of the duties appear to mo to be substantial, and they apply to what appear to me to bo a number of very important commodities. And I think it will encouragc trade without seriously damaging existing interests either in the United States or Canada, and that partly because it seems to have been engineered with some care but more particularly because it is being put into operation during a time of expanding markets, and expanding prosperity, when business, if it does take a knock, can stand it® So, taking what I might call

the short-run view, I think there is evidence that the trade agreement between Canada and the United States is likely to be fairly beneficial to both. Regarding the long-run, I have no re doubt, I would have no doubt if the agreement were permanent, but it is only to run for three years, and after that to be terminable after six months period - the same applies to most of the other agreements. Canadians have become used to mistrusting the Americans when they come bringing lower tariffs. Twice within living memory Canadians have built up a profitable export market in primary products to the Unitod Statos only to heve that market wiped out by a stroke of the presidential pen, and wo do not want to see it happen again if possible because it brings with it hardship and loss. I have said some kind things about the United States - and by the way^ I do not want it to be thought that I believe the administration had in view, when it enacted the NRA and these other policies, the favorable repercussion on Canada, Nevertheless, I have said kind things about the administration and the results of the American policy, and I would like to say one more thing. The trade agreements policy seems to mo to bo meeting with not inconsiderable success and it does therefore mark a reversal or some reversal of the trend of tariff walls over the past eight or ten years. That is all to the good. That it includes the most-favored-nation principle, instead of strict bilateralism, also seems to me to be a good omen; but the policy is good only in so far as it is constant. Like the Chinese delegate who spoke last, we too want stability. I havenTt talked this over with the Canadian delegates, but if there wore one request xvhich I think the Canadian delegates here would unanimously make to the United Statos, it would be perhaps this. In your trade agreements' you have dealt with us kindly and fairly, justly, perhaps even generously. You have helped us promote prosperity - will you now, as far as is possible, endow that prosperity with some permanencee

Secretariat 1936 Document 21 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON U,S.A# ROUND TABLE TOPIC I, AUGUST 17, 1936 (Dr. Leonard Hsu) Before I talk I wish now to make an apology. I shall speak on the effect of the American silver purchase policy on China rather than stop at silver policy, for two reasons: I was more prepared on that subject when I was asked to dpocik this afternoon of the effects on China. The second justification of my apology is the effect on China is a good example of the international implication of the .American silver policy. Its policy of one country affects the welfare of another country, and I can speak more concretely and specifically. My time is ten minutes. The acknowledgment of the silverites in .America that the American silver purchasing policy, through raising the value of silver, tends to increase the purchasing power of China and thereby prove beneficial to American trade with China, has caused much concern and debate in China. As a result, the Chinese national government appoints, in the Ministry of Industry, a committee to make a special study of the subject, and this committee spent one year and a half to make the study and issue their report, entitled "Silver and Priccs in China," published in China both in English and Chinese. The result of the stucfcr to speak in simple language, was somewhat like this: The United States silver policy tends to increase the price of silver; the higher price of silver tends to in¬ crease the value of the Chinese dollar, because the Chinese dollar was based upon silver; and the higher value of the Chinese dollar means lower commodity prices in China* Again the lower commodity prices in China meant less income for the general population, and that, thereby, causes general economic depression. This depression resulted in lessening purchasing power, and this decrease of the purchasing power of the Chinese population has caused less imports from foreign countries to China, because the Chinese could buy less. Therefore, the silver policy of the United States was harmful to both China and the United States from the standpoint of Chinese trade with the United States. Our discussions was that it was the state of business conditions in China rather than the exchange rates that most affected the imports of China. There¬ fore, the rise in silver purchasing power caused Chinese imports to decline. If you are interested in figures, I should be glad to refer you to the reports the Chinese delegation will be glad to supply. In my opinion, it is exaggerated to ascribe the economic depression in China, as if it was entirely dependent on the silver situation due to the operation of the American silver purchasing policy. Perhaps it is nearer to the truth to say that the -American silver purchasing policy accentuated the Chinese economic depression and hastened to bring the crisis to a head. I am glad that it did because it meant to us this currency reform. It was a blessing in disguise.

Speaking of the economic depression in Chinat from 1932 to 1935 China experienced a depression; the degree of severity was perhaps not much less than that of the United States, although as a rule the Chinese were more patient than the Americans, so that we made less fuss about it® In analyzing the causes of the Chinese depression, we want to find out what arc the factors - monetary and other factors - influencing the commodity, prices in China, which in turn caused the depression® The result of our studies was that largely the cause was the price of silver and the value of the Chinese dollar® The value of the Chinese dollar caused wholesale prices in Shanghai to decline 13g$ in 1932 and 7®1% in 1933® What were"the social and economic effects? First was a decline in government revenue. The customs receipts, receipts from land taxes were de¬ creased, revenue from local governments and provincial governments decreased. In spite of the decline in revenue, then we had an increase in the government budget because the percentage of money needed to meet debt service was increased® Because of the widespread of social and economic unrest we needed more expenses for policing. Our expenses for debt services and military service and other services tenAed to increase. Then foreign trade: we faced a decrease in exports and imports. As a result wo had an enormous amount of adverse balance of trade. In addition, the city business declined. Our studies of these economic conditions in Shanghai, Peiping, Tsintao, Nanking and othor cities in China clearly showed that as soon as the silver dollar went up business went broke® So the bankers got embarrassed, because business, industry, and commerce were not profitable occupations so the bankers suddenly found their money had no place to go., so there was an enormous amount of money in Shanghai. Shanghai faced artificial prosperity where the rest of the country faced a severe depression. Above all, agricultural prices dropped, dropped from 25 5o 75%, and that means less income for the farmers - hard living for them - that means for 80 to 85% of the 450 million. We have 450 million now® In what way did the American silver purchasing policy affoct China? In two ways. One was it further raises the exchange value of the Chinese dollar because of the rise of the silver price. For example, the price of silver in New York rose from 65/ an ounce in 1933 to over 75/ an ounce in December, 1935.. Second, because of the artificial appreciation of the value of silver in foreign markets, a disparity developed between London exchange prices of silver and the Chinese exchange rate. This disparity was as high as 14-g% at the end of 1935® This in turn causes the exodus of silver. The smuggling of silver from China was estimated at $570^000,000 worth of silver in 1934 and 1935. In the meantime I may say that the United States acquired approximately one billion ounces of silver and half came from China, so you had a good policy at our expense. This drastic change on the monetary stock of China causes immediate embarrassment upon the bankers, in Shanghai, but worse than that, it caused a lot of misery to the Chinese farmers. Wo did what we could - measures were taken to prevent this misery® First we established the so—called equalization charges to equalize the disparity between London silver prices and Chinese exchange rate. Second, we imposed an export duty on silver in order to lessen these exports of silver. Third, wo imposed severe anti-smuggling laws; fourth, the provincial governments and the city governments in various places also enacted severe punishments against speculators and silver exporters. But after many months of trial very little good was done. So in

November, 1935, China determined to help herself* China was forced to abandon the silver standard altogether. Now we have a so-called managed currency. This managed currency has enabled us to be comparatively free from the effect of changes in the price of silver abroad. I may say, also, this adoption of currency reform is of China's own volition® It is not so much due to the insti¬ gation of any of our foreign advisers, as is usually believed. What have been the effects? First, the period of utmost exchange in¬ stability has somewhat ended and this period is now more or less replaced by management of currency designed to maintain stability# Second, no multiplicity of note issues and scattering of currency reserves take place. We are trying to centralize control of the note issue and the custody of reserves in the hands of what we call the Currency Reserve Board# Third, the unit of account is unified on the basis of the so-called "Legal standard dollar" throughout the country. This means geographical unification of the standard unit. Fourth, wo have a greater centralization of control by government banks over commercial banks, and that means more stability of the commercial banks. Fifth, this stability of exchange has restored more or less public confidence and causes more money to circulate so that you see the revival of trade and the recovery of prices. Again, the farmers are benefited. This year the farmers are more prosperous than ever before in China® In fact, the Chinese are in better condition than in the last ten years almost® Since the currency reform, what is the effect of the .American policy in China at present? I may say the effect is more indirect « nevertheless very important, for two reasons. One is that although the Chinese dollar cannot ex¬ change for silver it can exchange for the United States dollar or other foreign currencies. Second, the reserve against our ncte issue is still silver, so dras¬ tic changes in the prices of silver in foreign countries arc still matters of direct concern to us5 for the future of Chinese currency we hope the price of silver shall be stabilized and is not fluctuated violently in one way or the other® Stability is our watchword and we hope it will be your watchword. This stability affects the peace of the Far East. For example, the higher price of silver, as I said in the past,, may cause the prices to drop. This economic depression means wider spread of social and economic unrest in China® Now, as Mr® Belshaw has summarized, the reconstruction policy in China today rests upon the amount of financial support. This financial support comes at the present time largely from internal taxes - land taxes, customs, general tax, maybe in the next few years there will be an income tax. This income from taxes - the govern¬ ment revenue from taxos - again depends on general stability - economic and social stability - of the country. Now we have entered another agreement with the United States - the agreement has been entered into between the United States and China whereby the United States treasury would purchase an unstated amount of silver from China and China agrees to leave the proceeds of the sales in the United States for the purpose of stabilizing exchanges and maintain a reserve in silver against our note issue so long as the United States adheres to its present policy of purchasing cilver» Suppose the United States changes its mind again. Suppose you say silver is no longer my sweetheart, This means a lower value of silver® This will affect the Chinese rosorvo0 If it isn*t your sweetheart, it is still our sweetheart. It will affect our currency and cause the same confusion, and go back to the same economic depression© What wo need is stability. We don't care about other kinds of stability, but we do care about stability of commodity prices in China - stability of your policy. Stability moans economic development in China, As the previous speaker said, a strong united prosperous China is the best security of the Far East, Therefore, in your peace is our peace, in our peace is your peace, for your stability is our stability.

Secretariat 1936 Document 27 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON U.S.A. ROUND TABLE TOPIC I, AUGUST 17, 1936 (Chester Rowell) As in duty bound the Americans, as the host nation, have placed them¬ selves first upon the operating table subject to the scalpel. The others will have their turn later. And now you have asked me as the representative of the host nation to face the most difficult and the most delicate of all of our questions. The most difficult because it seems to be agreed that this policy, which I cm about to elucidate, does not exist and the most delicate because it has been requested that I shall discuss it with reference to the naval policy of the United States. In other words, I shall discuss political foreign relations with reference to what is avowedly a machine of war® There could bo no more delicate subject. I E'hall hope to treat it delicately. As to this policy, however, if it cannot be reasoned it can perhaps bo rationalized. We can at least relate this naval policy to another policy which has some coherence, end we can give an explanation of the naval policy with reference to the diplomatic policy, which would be rational if the relation were actual, The United States as has been pointed out in the round tables and as is a familiar fact, has had three policies toward the three regions of the earth and those three policies we have not attempted to bring under one formula. The policy toward Europe has boon one of political isolation and of economic interrelation, and we have determined to maintain both and maintain them both in spite of the fact that that inconsistency has gotten us into both of the groat ISuropecin wars through the back door. Toward the two Americas, our policy is the Monroe Doctrine, a difficult subject which I will not at this moment undertake to discuss, except to say that to the extent that the present troubled condition of the xvorld revives not only part of the original importance of the Monroe Doctrine which is the protection of the integrity of all the nations of this continent, and that to that extent our naval policy may be hold to have a consistent and tangible defense purpose. Our policy across the ocean centers largely upon what we have called the policy of the Open Door in China. And that being the only one within the juris¬ diction of this Conference, lot us see what, if any, relationship our foreign policy toward the Pacific nations has toward our naval policy and how it may bo adjusted to this policy,, This policy of the Open Door is far older than its formulation by John Hay in the administration of McKinley. Ho formulated it, however, as a name at a time when it was threatened by Europe, and wo used the voice of diplomacy and the potential menace of navies - not our navy, except in part but of the various European navies against each other to produco an agreement by them that they would not break through the principle of the Open Door in China. So there was a definite policy by the United States in using diplomacy for protection of that doctrine when it was threatened by Europe.

A second caso was in the Washington Conference of 1922 when as a politi¬ cal condition of the naval disarmament which reduced the navies on the two sid os of the ocean so that it would "be physically impossible for them to conduct an ag¬ gressive war in either direction, a political consideration of that was the Nine- Power Treaty which secured not only the Open Door but which included the oilargod expression of respect for the integrity of China not merely territorial but administrative. As things have since developed, it has boon the opinion of this country that this political consideration and the naval agreement were inseparable, and it has been the argument from the Japanese side that they were separable, ivnd now when again this question of the Open Door in China comes up again, there is the question whether the diplomatic voice of the United States is or is not again being raised upon that question, and the present fact is that the diplomatic voice of the United States is raised very little upon that or any other question by virtue of the fact that we have in this timo of distress concentrated ourselves very largely upon our own problosns. Now relate that history to the history of those naval treaties and if possible to the rationalization of our Pacific naval policy. The naval treaties as you know in their present stage began first with the Washington Conference, in which we dealt with the throe first rank navies and the two second-rank navies. The arithmetic of naval policy is far simpler than the arithmetic of land policy^ because there are only three first-rank navies in the world - there wore only two more of the second-rank - wo may have to reckon in the future with two more that may develop. At that Washington Conference we reached agreement upon capital ships, including the throe major navies upon that basis of parity of the 5-5-3 ratio which British end Americans insist is parity and an effective ratio, and which the Japanese reluctantly accepted but which they protested and have since continued to protest does not constitute parity. We were not able to extend that to cruisers and auxiliary vessels. The second London Naval Conference was held with the purpose of doing that, but because it was a five—power treaty and a five—power agreement could not be done, the agreements had to be very provisional with escape clauses, and that confercnce, while it accepted some things, accepted far loss than the hopes of those who promoted it. The Third Conference in London had for its purpose, if possible, to extend beyond its original terms these Washington Conference treaties after the date of their expiration® But that foundered upon the definition of parity. The American definition of parity was what we called effective parity, and we insisted that 5-5-3 ratio constituted that. The Japanese definition was equality. Hence, both sides were fixed in that policy, the Japanese withdrew from it, we are now committed in principal to an unlimited naval race as soon as the treaty expires. There is no one of us who wishes to engage in that naval race. That is the familiar history of these treaties. Now, if possible, rationalize the American naval policy to this fairly clear, foreign policy, and I don't claim that this rationalized relation is in fact as clear as one could formulate it. In the first place, in answer to this troubled inquiry as to why America is just now engaged in a groat naval building program at the very time when professing to be withdrawing from imperialistic ambitions, the answer is wholly irrational and very practical and clear. One of the major reasons for building these ships is that we want to spend the money, and this is the quickoi and easiest way to do it. We have a great program of making work, the larger en¬ terprises usually require a long time to plan and prepare. The ships are already planned and a very large part of the motives that have produced so much enthusiasm in Congress is that this is the quickest and easiest form of public work. If we "Should later do with them what we did with them at the Washington Conference - sink them - that is the cheapest thing you can do with a naval vessel. It would, how¬ ever. be entirely false to assume that that is the whole of the case.

The rest of the case, however, is a part of the general confusion of our varying thoughts ae to what the navy is for, after all. The ,navy is for defense, but what is it going to defend? Our naval experts themselves* are wholly incapable of knowing what sort of navy we need, because our political authorities wholly refrain from saying to them what they shall be called upon t<3 do with that navy. If the purpose of the navy were defense of our shores, in the first place it would have to be very different sort of navy and in the second place the shores arenft going to have to be defended, as against the sort of war that might start any day between France and Germany and could not start in that way between America and any other country. Any future war will be through the back door the same way as before, and the ordinary theory of the war gome which rests upon the hypothesis that war has been declared, omits all realities - wars aren't declared in that way. Nevertheless, much of the theory is based upon the fact that somebody might come and attack us and we might need to be defended,, My opinion against that sort of hypo¬ thesis is that we are dealing with facts. But there are other purposes of navies. As I said in one of the round tables to day $ the navy is the amplifier of the voice of the diplomat. The voice of the diplomat speaks exactly as loud as the potential voice of his cannon, and if those cannons are potentially loud enough they never have to be used because he -will be heard. Now, if the time should come in the future that onco more the voice of American diplomacy would be raised upon the question of the Open Door in China,including the definitions of that in the Nino-Power Treaty, we should not wish the voice of our diplomats to be muzzled and unheard by the refusal of anybody to listen, and we have recently learned by observation and experience in Europe that that can happen - that he who does not wish to listen to the diplomat who raises a question can successfully do so more or less. If this question should arise - it is doubtful - and if it is doubtful it is doubtful if we need a navy policy in the Pacific •» if it should arise it is desirable that the voice of the diplomats both ways should be heard and heeded, and if they need the amplifier, then this should bo loud enough to make them heard, and then the voice of reason can prevail. As to the other jingo danger which appears in the jingo press of both countries, it is wholly irrational. I would eliminate that from our naval policy. It would be physically possible for head on war to take place on the Atlantic be¬ tween the American and British navies because the diameter of the Atlantic is with¬ in radius of fleet action. The policy of both countries is based upon the assump¬ tion that that will never happen. Under these naval limitations, we have on the Pacific the additional protection that the diameter of the Pacific is far beyond the radius of fleet action, and so that sort of war upon the Pacific^ even if otherwise possible, as an additional protection is physically impossible. If under our peculiar conditions it is impossible to find either con¬ tinuity or complete explanation for our naval policy, at least we may hypothetically rationalize that naval policy as related or relatable to the much more tangible diplomatic policy which is part of the permanent history of the United States.

Secretariat 1936 Document 28 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON U.S.A. ROUND TABLE TOPIC I, AUGUST 17, 1936 (A. G# Elliot-Smith) I think you will all agree that Mr. Rowell is a difficult man to follow, and after his intense factual survey I feel my abstract speculation may fall a little flat, I think it is impossible for us of the British group not to be interested in the recovery program of a nation which after all we may somewhat claim is our own flesh and blood. But I think it is only true to say that what we are par¬ ticularly interested in is how far the return of governmental and public opinion in the United States lies toward a policy of isolation or whether she is more prepared to cooperate in world economic recovery and in the maintenance of world peace. I said that was the British view but I don't think it is a selfish.-oAo;s* because we are coming to realize more and more that not only is peace indivisible but so also''is economic prosperity. A single nation may have a temporary advantage at the expense of another nation, but such an advantage is neither durable nor desirable, and the converse is equally true. No-./,. I don't think it would be wholly inopportune here to deal with, I think, a rather widely spread misapprehension as to the interpretation that should be put upon Sir Samuel Hoaro's speech of September 11 last year in relation to an examination of markets and access to raw materials. There are many, I think, who seem to believe "chat Great Britain is conscious of her weakness and is now preparing to hand over her colonies piece-meal; while the enemies of Great Britain see in this speech just another attempt by perfidious Albion to hand over somebody else's colonies or territory. I would ask you to believe that neither of these two interpretations is the true one, but that the explanation lies in"what I have already said—we are coming more and more to be¬ lieve that peace and prosperity are both indefensible. All nations must in some degree be dissatisfied. This is the purpose of the conference; we want to find out what are the legitimate demands of the various peoples and to see how those demands can be satisfied. If they can—not merely by changing over the roles of what have come rather unfortunately to be callcd the satisfied and dissatisfied nations. And I think it will be clear from this the isolationist policy on the part of any country will militate against such a hope— firstly, in that it must paralyze trade, and secondly, it means that a nation is going to v\rithhold its help from those who do not wish to see that the use of legitimate demands does not degenerate into the satisfaction of the stronger at the expense of the weaker, or, to put it another way, to withhold its help from those who would like to see the lion lie down with the lamb, but that the lamb shall not bo inside the lion. Frankly, for us, I think, the outcome of the round table discussions is slightly discouraging, Vie welcome recovery while realizing that it is difficult to determine how much of that recovery is due to governmental action, how much to climatic caprice, how much to the general up-swing of the pendulum of world prosperity. In so far as limitation of crops, for instance, has helped the dom¬ inions, I think we should be hypocrites if we pretended we were sorry. The some also applies to trade agreements which have been made, and also to the somewhat vicarious method by which America has brought about the stabilizing of the currency of China. But if those trade agreements—these limitations—must be interpreted as an indication that an isolationist policy is to become permanent rather than a transitory phase for a period of internal house-tidying, then America is going to delay longer in playing her part in a world In which economics

have become international. Turning to the purely political aspects, it would seem that it is rather like the weather forecast for three-quarters of the British summer-further outlook unsettled. I think you all would be irritated at that particular state, because you don't know whether to take your coat because it will be too hot—on the other hand if you don't take your coat your clothes may be ruined. I think that possibly that is not an inept analogy with the world situation—where we have every nation re-arming at its fullest ra e because of uncertainly as to what is to happen and uncertainty as to who is friend and who is its foe. There is one thing -which might be described as a bright period in the round- table discussion—that was the evidence that United States, Great Britain, and Japan would be glad to see the integrity of the Philippines guaranteed. But that left many questions unanswered. Is that to be simply a pledge of non-aggrcssionj will that bring certainty; will it involve military commitmentj is it to be yoked to the full with the collective security of the world? Mr. Chester Howell has outlined the American naval policy, but if there is one thing that has emerged from the discussion of the round tables, I still feel it is that the American foreign policy is somewhat confused, and the point I desire to make more than any other is that it is the uncertainty as to what a great nation like America is going to do that is perhaps one of the greatest factors for insecurity in the world at the moment. We had in one round table at which I was present this morning the suggestion that America would probably act and cooperate with collective security in actual fact or at least she would not interfere with such measuies as migh e sen o further collective security; but except that the mercurial temperament, to use an American's words, the mercurial torporament of the iimerican mind—which seemed unlikely she would make that declaration beforehand, and so the children of un¬ certainty must remain. I do not want this to be interpreted as an appeal for an Ando-American alliance of the pre-war type. What I wish to see^is America taking a distinct place in the comity of notions, bocause, as I have said above, and don't hesitate to repeat it, we feel that there is no such thing as national prosperity or national security unless it be embraced in world prosperity and world poacc.

essay:div.essay:p: Secretariat 1936 Ebcument 6 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON U.S.A. ROUND TABLES, AUGUST 17,1936, 8:00 p.m. (H. BELSHAW) The Round Table discussions were centered in the main on the inter¬ national implications of recent policy in the United States, more especially since the advent of the Roosevelt Administration. Discussion first centered on the extent to which the Recovery Program had taken international implications into account. The Recovery Program was directed primarily to the solution of internal difficulties "but it would not be true to say that international impli¬ cations were entirely ignored, or that the bearing of international trade policies on domestic rocovery was entirely neglected. The attempts to negotiate trade agreements afford positive evidence that the importance of reducing barriers to international trade was recognized. The view that agreements to stabilize currencies at the time of the London Conference was premature in the interests of the world as a whole and that the United States could best serve such interests by placing its own currency on a satisfactory basis provided at least an ostensible motive for the refusal to enter into stabilization agreements. Nevertheless the preoccupation of the Administration with domestic re¬ covery was abundantly clear. Whore domestic and international interests con¬ flicted, the latter tended to be sacrificed. Thus the Restriction Program of the AAA was pursued despite the necessity which it imposed for countervailing duties on imports and despite the risk that competitors might capture some portion of world markets for foodstuffs and raw materials. There was indeed some conflict of opinion both among the general public and in the ranks of the President's advisers. Some looked to a recovery in world trade as a necessary condition of recovery in the United States, Others maintained that a national recovery program could be made to succeed irrespective of external conditions. Still others argued that the interests of world recovery would be more effectively served by a domestic policy promoting prosperity in the United States even though this temporarily hampered the international flow of commodities, than by a policy which concentrated on international aspects of the problem. Just as opinion was by no means homogeneous, so the policy was not entirely consistent - the objective of economic insulation could not always be completely reconciled with bilateral trade agreements which might result in lower tariffs. An American member expressed the view that the majority opinion in the United States was in favour of both economic and political isolation. Since politicians are not entirely uninfluenced by the opinions of voters it therefore becomes a vital issue whether or not this trend in opinion will continue. Other members suggested that the trend towards isolation was largely a depression

phenomenon which would change with recovery. The expansion of American in¬ dustrial production would then impose an urge towards the development of new markets in order to dispose of surpluses and this would weaken the sentiment towards economic isolation. Since economic expansion would thus cross the1 interests of other nations, it was not compatible with political isolation. In short, economic oxpansion being given, the "United States v/ould no longer be an entirely free agent, for those nations whose interests appeared to be prejudiced might take action in respect of which political isolation would be considered inappropriate* Attempts to expand trade had been made through the device of bilateral agreements of -which 14 had already been negotiated. In the absence of action on a more comprehensive scale, bilateral agreements might make towards a lower¬ ing of tariff barriers, thus promoting trade expansion. Since the agreement with Canada there had been an expansion of trade between the two countries. Although this had resulted in the main from the general trend towards recovery, the trade agreement was no doubt a factor. Little evidence was forthcoming as to the effects on other countries. Despite certain possible advantages, bi¬ lateral agreements were fraught with certain obvious risks. The competitive interests of non-participating nations might be prejudiced and retaliatory action encouraged. Frequently negotiations were conducive to irritation and misunderstanding. In large measure bilateral agreements were a response to de¬ pression; to shifting pressures on the balance of payments and to exchange in¬ stability® As a defense measure they might be justified, but when once curren¬ cies were stabilized they tended to perpetrate uncertainty; they led to new disturbances and made the problem of stabilization more difficult. In the British Empire they cut across the principle of imperial preference and so were difficult to negotiate. The effects of the AAA appeared to differ in different countries of the Pacific Area and were confused by adverse weather conditions in the United States, especially in 1934 and 1936. Canada benefited without having to share the costs. So also did other countries which competed in world markets in such commodities as wheat, but tariffs on butter and other livestock products wore disadvantageous to surplus producing countries such as Australia and Now Zealand. Although the emphasis in the new programme was on soil conservation, restriction seemed to bo at least a secondary motive which lessoned the chances of tariff reductions. In so far as the Soil Conservation Program tended to restrict the production of wheat and other grains, it v/ould continue to benefit competitors on world markets. A likely effect was the relative increase in the production of the livestock products and this gave small hope of a reduction in tariffs on such products. The silver policy of the United States found no support in the Round Table discussions even amongst American members. It was regarded partly as a racket and partly as a policy, but it failed both as a racket and as a policy. Silver interests had argued that a high price for silver would increase the purchasing power of China in other countries oven though economists had pro¬ phesied precisely the opposite effects. The silver policy was strongly condemned by all Chinese members at the Round Tables since it had depressed prices in China. The effects were particularly serious to agricultural producers because prices declined while tax rates and other costs remained fixed. So it occasioned

widespread distress which was soon transmitted to the cities. It reduced Chinese exports because of effects on exchange and affectcd China's capacity to purchase from abroad. The depressing effects on taxable capacity seriously interfered with the reconstruction program in China, While changes in prosper¬ ity in China were due to more general causes, the American silver policy had aggravated the depression, British and Japanese members considered that the silver policy had seriously affected the economic interests of their respective countries. It reduced trade, impaired the capacity of China to make payments on foreign debts and weakened the position of the banks, Chinese opinion was emphatic that the recent reform of the currency had proved wholly beneficial but might easily be endangered by American silver policy in the future, so China did not desire any change in the price of silver but was anxious that it should be kept stable. Some differences of opinion emerged on the economic effects of exchange depreciation. The evidence of trade statistics suggested that American trade had improved in most Pacific countries, but an economist member argued that such benefits wore temporary and were obtained at the expense of competitors. To this point of view the reply was made that exchange depreciation might still be a necessary method of adjustment even if it were granted that the direct effects were temporary. It might prove the simplest and most effective means of lessening the burden of fixed costs in export industries. Further, its influence in promoting recovery in the countries which practiced it might more than offset its injurious effects elsewhere. If American devaluation had assisted recovery in the United States it had probably assisted world recovery. Members from various national groups expressed considerable difficulty in understanding the foreign policy of the United States in the Pacific Area; or in reconciling the denials of imperialist aims and the desire to withdraw from situations which might involve America, with tho recent intensification of naval construction. These difficulties proved to bo shared by American members so that there was no coherent analysis of American policy in relation to naval construction. As one Chinese member put it, the United States seemed not to have a policy but only ideas about policy. An American member suggested that the difficulty in interpretation might bo due to the apparent lack of continuity in policy# con¬ ditioned mainly by tho sensitiveness of tho Government to public opinion' - a public opinion susceptible to change under the influence of demagogues, It was further suggested that naval construction might be proceeding under the cover of official expressions of policy which were very different from tho considerations which were actually determinant. So policy might be separated from the general attitude of the people. It was argued that while America desired to avoid European entanglements and consistently played the part of the good neighbour in South America, there was no intention of withdrawing from the Pacific, A strong body of opinion described American policy as motivated by considerations of defense. The United States would not risk the life of a single soldier to retain its interests in China, Nevertheless American commitments in the Philippines might entangle the United States in a defensive war, A Japanese member expressed the view that the naval program of the United States had intensified competitive construction in Japan, Japan was

puzzled to know against what threat in the Pacific defense was required, more especially as Japan was prepared to guarantee the integrity of the Philippines. Such a guarantee was conditional upon the maintenance of the Open Door and agreement not to use the Philippines for military or naval purposes. A Chinese member forcefully presented the view that China was the focal area in the problem of maintaining peace in the Pacific. The present policy of China was to help herself, but sho was seriously hampered by political and economic pressure. A strong arid united china was the best guarantee of peace in the Pacific and Pacific countries would achieve more by cooperation in building a strong, prosperous and united China than by building armaments. So the discussion ended, by strong emphasis on the close relationship between economic and political conditions, and with a plea to remove a cause of conflict rather than engage in costly preparation against it.
