essay:div.essay:p: Secretariat 1936 Document 33 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON JAPAN ROUND TABLE TOPIC II, AUGUST 18, 1936 (Kenzo Oshima) As the attention of the whole world appears to be increasingly centered upon the recent growth of Japan's export trade, I consider it proper at this time to present certain pertinent facts, end to outline briefly the factors underlying the situation* To begin with, I should like to present figures indicating the real position of Japan's export trade during the years 1931-1935. Total exports dur¬ ing 1931 were valued at 1,146,000,000 yen; they increased in 1933 to 1,861,000,000 yen; and in 1935 they further increased to 2,499,000,000, the highest export figure ever attained by Japan. During these years, then, there was an increase of more than one hundred percent and the status of the pre-deprcssion period, namely that of 192 7, was restored to her. As would be expected, imports increased during the same period, but the rate of their increase did not correspond to that of exports. The consequence was that Japan's trade balance achieved a remarkable improvement. Specifically, the end of the year 1931 saw an adverse balance of 88,000,000 yen- but in 1935 the balance was 26,000,000 in favor of Japan. The figures cited indicate the growth in value of the export trade and a similar phenomenon can be noted in the volume; the figure for 1931 was 5,295,000 tons, whereas that for 1935 grew to 9,045,000 tons. Next, I should like to review briefly the items of Japan's export trade. Articles wholly manufactured, which in 1931 constituted 46.5% of the total volume of exports, increased in percentage to 58.1 per cent for 1935. In this connection, we cannot ignore the change in the proportion that raw materials occupied in relation to Japan's total volume of imports; ..it was, in 1931, 55.4%, whereas in 1935 it had grown to 61%. Thirdly, 1 should like to point out the geographical changes in distri¬ bution of Japan's exports. In 1931, exports to Asia were 44% of the total volume and in 1935 they increased to 52%, whereas combined exports to Central and South America, Africa and Oceania, almost negligible i& 1931, wore, in 1935, 15.6% of the total volume. On the other hand, exports to Europe and North America showed a tendency to be stati onary# Lastly, the principal export goods, hitherto limited to cotton goods and silk, came to include miscellaneous commodities which showing a remarkable increase, constituted in 1935 more than 50% of the total volume of Japan's exports. These facts are sufficient to show, in its broadest outline, the position occupied by Japan's export trade in recent years. Next, I should like to turn briefly to the principal causes for this rather remarkable development.

First, the rationalization of industries must bo considered as one of its important co.uses. As'is generally known, Japan has been suffering since 1920 and especially since 1927, from severe economic depression. During this period her industrial corporations, by enduring many hardships, contrivod to rationalize and re-organize methods of production and marketing* Throughout the depression period Japanese corporations, either by abandoning dividends, writing off capital investment, or by enduring various other sacrifices, achieved successful re¬ adjustment in the various spheres of industry# And so, vjhen a change of Ministry in 1931 brought about a policy of inflation to replace the policy of deflation to ' which the outgoing Ministry had adhered, Japan1s industries found themselves fully prepared for the new condition* This fact is partly responsible for the tempo with which Japanese goods rushed out to foreign markots# Second, Technological developtoGnt - invention and improvement of mech¬ anical equipment - gradually enabled Japan's industries to supply themselves with their own machinery® A good example of this is clearly discernablo in the vreaving industry* As the third cause, exchange depreciation should be mentioned. The de¬ preciation of the yen resulted from the fact that the yen had theretofore been over-valued, and was now adjusted by a natural, economic process to its justifi¬ able value# This situation'was nob, as is sometmes alleged^ brought about either artifically or deliberately* The fourth cause is that industrial organizations have been strictly ad¬ hering to "sound finance principles" - exemplified in the cotton spinning and rayon industries. The following figures will clarify the fifth cause, which is labor efficiency; in 1920 there were required 106 males or 344 females to operate 10,000 spindles in the textile industry, and the annual per capita production was 12.7 bales. In 1935, the sane number of spindles required only 25 males or 160 females, and the per capita annual production was 23.7 bales, almost double the preceding -amount. I cannot conclude this brief exposition without pointing out the fact that the' development of Japan's export trade has been over-emphasized in popular thinking, and has often been wrongly interpreted. According to recent studios made by League of Nations researchers, Japan's exports amount to but 4.44% of the total volume of world exports. This figure is practically the same as those for Canada, Holland, and Belgium. Mow, bearing in mind the fact that Japan's population is ten times as large as that of any°of the above mentioned countries, the development of Japan's industries must be recognized as a necessary moans of preserving her livelihood. Hence, it should be obvious that Japan's export trade cannot be considered as unduly expanded; rather it is to be recognized as a natural and inevitable consequence of the growth of her economic capacity. Using the index number of value of export trade for 1928 as a basic 100, the numbers for 1931 and 1935 are respectively 58 and 127* With regard to the volume of production, taking again the index number of 1928 as a basic 100, the numbers for 1931 and 1935 are respectively 107.8 and 192.3. These figures, however, should not be viewed superficially or as an independent phenomenon.

The Japanese nation, though one of the oldest in the world, has but a short history of about a half centuiy since it made its debut on the stage of world economy* Consequently, Japan has had to make tremendous efforts in order to keep pace with other advanced countries of Europe and America, These efforts, moreover, have always been made with two objects in view; one is to feed and clothe her rapidly growing population; and the other is to contribute toward the promotion of human welfare in cooperation with other leading powers of the world* In addition, there is another fact which should not be overlooked in connection with the growth of Japan's export trade. Japan has always been a debtor country since the beginning of her economic contact with foreign countries. And she has never failed to carry out her obligations in this respect. It is of interest to note in the following figures the proportions which the amounts re¬ quired for payment of foreign debts plus tJap value of imported foodstuffs and raw materials bear to the value of Japan's exports. A The amount required for the payment of foreign debts. ""[Million dollars )* B The value of imported food¬ stuffs Total of A & B Value of Exports 323 382 280 4 3 1931 470 400 330 70 1932 620 541 451 90 1933 724 618 ■50 90 1934 * At present exchange rate Objectively considered, those figures show that with foreign debt obliga¬ tions to be met - an obligation which Japan has never shirked - and with tremendous expenditures necessary to import food and raw materials for her growing population, Japan's apparent rapid growth in exports is the inevitable result of her deter¬ mination to meet her obligations to her own people and to maintain her integrity and position among the Powers, And in these figures will be perceived not only Japan's efforts to serve her internal problem but also her spirit of cooperation and her faithfulness towards her external obligations. I think I have already presented all the points which are necessary for the comprehension of the recent development of Japan's export trade. I should like, hoiA/evor, to add a few words in conclusion; that is, whenever Japan's growth of export trade might be considered as colliding with the interests of another nation, Japan vrould always be prepared and willing to collaborate with that nation, in a most friendly manner, for the sake of attaining a solution which is most advantageous for both of the parties concerned.

Secretariat 1936 Document 34 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON JAPAN ROUND TABLE TOPIC II, AUGUST 18, 1936 (The Rt, Hon# A,V, Alexander,M,P,) In dealing with this obviously difficult subject, a proper spirit, a true conciliation, and a consideration for the needs of great populations in the world by other nations in the world, are essential. First I would like to refer to the agenda revisions. It has boon suggest¬ ed that the alterations of the agenda have been made with a sort of collusion of the British delegation to recognize the new regime in Manchoukuo, There isn't the slightest foundation for this. We have no knowledge of any such negotiations. We believe that you can plc.co no credence in that particular rumor. The reason the British delegation has been interested in these revisions was that the re¬ action upon us of some of the questions was that we would be projecting Japan unnecessarily into a position of separation and unnecessary justification, I've desire to make it clear to our Japanese friends that wo had no desire to sec them put in the dock. Regarding tho omission of questions a,, b,, and c, under Paragraph 6 of the Handbook, Page 26, it lias boon suggested that the British delegation moved for the deletion of these paragraphs because the idea contained in them was already being promoted and that therefore, wo did not want to have them discussed in this conference. It would be most unfortunate if wo approached this conference with any such idea, I should like to say that these revisions were made largely at my own suggestion, and my idea in making them was actually a pro- China approach, I felt that they vferc almost insulting to tho great country of China, as if we wore almost unmindful of the great human rights of that great nation, I hope that I have completely satisfied any of tho doubts on this question and that our real desire at the conference is to have a free and frank discussion by all countries on these matters. We have listened to a very powerful paper with regard to the expansion of export trade, and the reason for that expansion, by Mr. Oshima of Japan, We do not want to put Japan entirely on the defense and we rocognize that there is a great and human right of a nation to develop and expand in such a way as "will on- able her to meet the legitimate demands of her people for a higher standard of life. We put the right of Japan to expand in this way: the right of an indivi¬ dual to have all the freedom that life could offer in the sphere of light, emotion and hope, and any nation has this right. It is on the point of view as to whether that is the true objective of Japan that makes tho necessity of frank consideration of this question and we hope there will bd equally frank answers, I want to say a word or two on this question of motive behind tho expansion. The extraordinary tempo of Japan's advance impresses all of us. No nation in history has ever achieved such an acceleration as has boon achieved by Japan, The question is whether or net it is the best thing to force such a tremendous increase, because ultimately the pur¬ chasing power of the dislocated markets is lessened and instead of reaching the objective you have set for yourself, you will find yoursolvos and your people beset by many of the difficulties of which you complain today. As one of our delegation has put it "What wo firid difficult is that you are rushing like a bull in a China shop into world markets," That is one of tho very strong points that

we want kept in mind during the course of the discussion® On the subject of raw materials, from our point of viexv wo want Japan to have proper access to the raw materials which she needs and to have the right to develop the payment for this, but is this race of -theirs in their search for raw materials the only method of obtaining them? Let us measure how much of the expansion of the purchase of raw materials is for the sole purpose of in¬ dustrial development or how much is for the provision of war materials and a preparation of a much bigger campaign than could be for expansion. The total charge for military expenditure for the year 193?. was 442,000,000 yen and in 1935- 36 the charge to the ordinary budget was 1,230,000,000, nearly two and a half times the expenditure for war than had been the case only 5 years before that® If you look at the figures for 1934-35, 46% of the whole budget revenue was being ex¬ pended on the fighting services of Japan, and in 1935-36 it was over 50% of the .. total revenue. If loan-revenue be ignored, the percentage of military expenditures to ordinary budget revenue was about 75% in the year 1934-35® And so we must ask how much of this drive is for expansion and hew much in the interests of the industrial workers, and how far in the interests of some other motive. Many people have said that it is not merely the economic urge which is behind this growth but that thoro is a national purpose in Japan today which explains this particular campaign® I hope wc shall hear of this from our Japanese friends when wc actually put our questions to them. It may bo said that if the Japanese arc doing this, they are doing no more than what has been done in the past by western countries, and our answer to this is that they ought to have learned enough to avoid the mistakes which nations have made in the past® Regarding expansion and export trade, on behalf of the British delegation, I may say that given proper conciliations and trado agreements, we sec nothing fundamental to object to. It was, however, this groat expansion for raw materials on the part of Germany which lead up to the last war, but after the war Germany became our largest customer in Europe, so looking back on that wc have no foar of your expansion in Japan, if it is net going to rebound on the Japanese them¬ selves® From my personal point of view, I was very interested in the opening speech of this conference made by Mr. Holland, to the effect that we should find the solution to these problems in internal and economic adjustments within our own countries, I dn not believe that you will over got true peace in the world until each nation is really preparing to tackle the question of internal social and economic adjustment. To use a cockney expression, "mucking about" with the exchanges will not accomplish this. It must be dealt with by internal and social adjustment. In Sheffield today we make more stool with one man than wo did in years past with five men. We feel that this wealth must be enjoyed by all the people and until the nations of the world are prepared to faco that you will always have unrest® I would say to our Japanese friends that if'their objective is purely to raise the standard of life of the Japanese people, I am certain that wo shall be able to arrange conciliations and trade agreements and generally will have como

to a satisfactory conclusion. On the other hand, if there is some imperialistic motive behind it, I feel that it would be well for them to be warned that there is very great disaster in that. There is a point to which you may find the policy actually goes too far, which -would put your nation in a lonely position that we would not like to soe# We would like to say to her that if they are going to rely upon themselves, almost certainly there will ultimately be a com¬ bination against them. I am one of the last that wants;, to see that happen. We British have a great friendship for the Japanese people. Wo cannot easily for- got the service they rendered us in 1918 and we wish for mutual understanding and a lasting peace, but this can only bo had if we really get down to conciliation, trade understanding and good fellowship, and do not disturb other nations in an unnecessary degree.

Secretariat 1936 Document 17 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON JAPAN ROUND TABLE TOPIC II, AUGUST 20, 1936. (Yusuke Tsunami) I want to speak as briefly as possible about the main points raised in the four round tables on Japan. I am not speakinC on behalf of the Japanese delegation, but rather as an individual critic, so that when it comes to some expressions of views they are entirely my own• We had the great Dleasure of listening to Mr. Alexander of Great Britain in opening our discussions. How, with the permission of this speaker, who is m the front row, I should like to make some observations on his remarks. I venture to dissent to a certain degree from his statement in this vein: the percentage^or proportion he allotted to the appropriations for the Japanese armaments appearing in each year's budget I think is a little too large in proportion to the whole budget, in comparison with other states. For instance, the reason y ^ e pro¬ portion of Japanese armament expenditure gives such a largo percentage is because we have a different system of budget making. In the first place, quite a num er of special budgets are not included in the ordinary budget, and also we have not, like ?n England, France er America, the interest, the huge amount of interest which vou are paid out of the total budget on the national loans raised during the war. When you compare these figures you will find tho proportion is not so alarming as expressed by Mr« Alexander. In the second place, during tho course of discussion in the past three days there have been occasions of linking the expansion of Japan s trade with her in¬ creased expenditures for armaments, but it seems to me that there is no connection between these two whatsoever. If you start connecting these two things, might it not occur to a Japanese that by buying the raw cotton^from America we are helping you build battleships? Therefore, 1 think the logic of trying to connect these two things is a little bit far-fetched, to my run <, Now I have a rather small mount of time tonight, so I will try to touchy upon various points briefly. In tho ocond place I should like to speak on one impor- tant point, that is this: While I was listening to the very interesting discuss¬ ions in the round tables I had an impression that — it might bo wrong -- that some people had the impression or feeling that Japan is separate from tho rest of tho world, as if Japan's case was something peculiar to her alone. But 1 do not think that Japan's case is so different. Japan's social unroot Is_Pnrt md or reel of tho-world's social unrest. Japan's economic rial-adjustment is a Dart* of the picture of the whole world's mal-adjustment, and the results of the rapid expansion of Japanese foreign trade are also tho same things that have occurrcd and aro occurring in different parts of the world, between nations and also within tho borders of one country, in different parts of that particular country. so I hope you will look at Japan as part and parcol of tiio picture 01 the whole world, and nothing particularly different in tho ease of Japan. In the third place, I want to call your attention to tho throe phases of Japan¬ ese expansion. Wo have talked about its political phase, which „.v~ no , go into very much at length, and then we have had occasion to talk m detail a the economic phase of Japan's expansion into trade and industry. I want to pel out one very important factor in Japan's " expansion, which wo did touch upon but in a very slight way. That is Japan's cultural expansion, wiic 1 goal <*d objective of Japanese life. The height of ambition of Japan is to con- tribute something to the world stock of civilization, the heritage of mankind, bv her continued existence as a nation on these curious islands J turies. Japanese minds aro directed toward imbibing tte culture of the whole

world and thereby creating some by the harmonizing of the different cultures of the world into a new fusion which we intend to return to the whole of humanity. In the fourth place I want to call your attention also to the fundamental causes of Japan1s expansion, that is, the pressure from within, duo to tho increasing population, out of proportion to its size of territory* We have tried to solve tho situation by internal adjustment, and those who have visited Japan will remember how we have succeedcd in tilling tho land up almost to the top of the hills, and yet, due to the mountainous conditions of the country we could not cultivate even with the most intensive system of cultivation, more than 15% of the total area. We have found out we could not elevate or enhance the standard of living of the people any more without some other means, and one was the migration of the Japan¬ ese into foreign countries, Unfortunately those were mainly closed to us. The other alternative was to sell our manufactured goods in different parts of the world* Unfortunately this met with difficulties because of trade barriers, tar¬ iffs, quota systems, etc. I want to speak more at length about the internal situation of Japan because without knowing the psychology and the physical situation of the Japanese nation at home you cannot lpossibly understand the nature of the expansion of the Japan¬ ese race. In the first place, I should like to call to your attention this simple fact, that the Japanese standard of living is not so low as some people might have thought» Those who have been in Japan realize that although we live in houses built of wood and covered with paper we are not living in a very primitive way. We may not all own Ford cars, but we still are happy with raising morning glories in our less expensive flower pots* We spend our money in different ways, sometimes less costly, but when you look at the expense of each household for education in proportion to the income of that house, you realize that wo arc not entirely benighted, hopeless barbarians. Also, if you visit Japan you realize,— I hope you do not misunderstand me if I say so — you realize the sense of security in the Empire. You hear about assassinations, but none of us will assassinate you if you come there. In Tokyo you can send your daughter of 14 or 15 alone in the street in the evening. You realize tho sense of order and neatness that we have. That is the nature of tho Japanese. Then the question, why these wars? Before we discuss that I should like to deal briefly on a very important phase of tho internal condition of Japan. That is tho now social reconstruction going on on a very large scale in much distressed rural districts of the country. Wo have in our Japanese delegation a very prominent scholar, Dr. Nasu, and I think some of you have had occasion to listen to his expression of that phase of rural reconstruction. Now, for instance, since 1932 wo have been engaging on a very large scale in what we call economic reconstruction plan for rural villages. We have created elaborate plans for each village, of which there are about 11,000, and about half, 5,500, villages of Japan have now those elaborate plans which ore in operation. This plan is in fact changing the structure of life in the villages. And then, the great burden that was lying heavily on tho shoulders of the unfor¬ tunate farmers and peasants of Japan was tho tremendous accumulated debts which amount to over 5-gr billion yen,— how to deal with this was a serious problem, and the government is spending a great deal of money for the relief of those agrarian debts, and these villages are given, by creating corporations, the guarantee of the central government to change from very high interest debts from village money rentals to the loans of lower interest given by banks. Another interesting phase is the industrialization of villages, due to the abundance of hydroelectric power in Japan. Then there is the groat movement in Japan of cooperative associations. Out of &gr million farmers wo have five million already incorporated in this cooperative association and cooperative credit association. This supplies money at no interest to the extent of one billion yen.

I do not need to go into more phases of this rural reconstruction. Now I want to come to a more recent event, the famous February 26 incident, I do not need to go into the details of this story® I .want to summarize the re¬ sults of that uprising of some young military officers in Tokyo. Two outstanding things resulted out of this very unfortunate incident. One was this: that even when they shook the foundation of the country, they could not create a military dictatorship. In the second place, they could not suspend the working of the par¬ liamentary system of government, Now we know that these two things are safe in Japan® I must explain very briefly the psychology of those young military officers. It has been misunderstood abroad. These officers are mainly recruited from among the middle, labor and farmer classes of the nation, and living as they do in barracks with other soldiers have not only the deep association of their homes but are con¬ stantly living with sons of other peasants. These young officers, so simple and genuine and single-track-minded, began to compare the distress in rural districts with the luxurious ways of living of a few people who had amassed money by indus¬ trial expansion, and began thinking that by putting some important people out of the way, by changing the system of government and the economic order, they could bring blessing to the hard-working peasants. Therefore, although they were mis¬ guided, their motives were genuinely sincere. That is why in the past, after a few unfortunate incidents they had to a great extent enjoyed the support of the peasants in the rural districts. But their last acts in February of this year made a tremendous change• On May 4 of this year the Emperor opened the Houses of Par¬ liament in person and gave us an Imperial Rescript. Throe days later, on May 7, while the atmosphere of Tokyo was still tense with the distress of this unfortunate and bloody incident, a small, unpretentious and ungainly man walked up to the tri¬ bune of the House of Representatives and began to make a speech of interpolations to the Prime Minister and the Minister of War. Nona of us expected anything extra¬ ordinary to come from this rather old gentleman, n;:arihg'his seventies, small of stature. Then suddenly this ppeech began to become one of the most historical speeches in the Japanese House of Commons* It isa very long speech, and almost at the end of every phrase he was applauded. Why? Because he gave vent to the pent-up sentiments of the majority of the Japanese nation, and in a very frank way stated the facts of these military insurgentice of the past and present. At the end of the speech he severely criticized the interest of military people in poli¬ tics, and stated: "Mr. Minister, I want to express the sentiments of the -whole nation. The whole nation is indignant. There is a limit to the patience of the nation, and I want you to realize, although you might not have heard, because wo are not free to talk outside of this House, but I am going to tell you frankly that the people are indignant, and you should take stops to rectify this condition in the army." When he ended I realized that Mr, Saito had made a historical speech. The most surprising thing was not merely this speech but the answer he evoked from the Minister of War. General --—-<—--- walked up to the Tribune and said, "I have listened with intense respect, and I agree with the statement of Mr, Saito," and you can imagine the ovation these two men received in the House, and the next day the newspapers of the country, of which there are quite a few, carried a whole page of these speeches. The present Minister of War is attempting the "rectification of the army movement," Now I want to make a very brief excursion into a forecast of the future. The point is this: Will Japan close her eyes to the world and walk on the path of isolation, politically and economically and intellectually? Ladies and gentlemen, if you would kindly study the history of the Japanese nation for the past thirty centuries you will realize that we have passed more serious crises than this, arid wo have passed always with a renewed interest in the whole world. The restoration of 1868 was started with the violent movement for closing the doors against the foreign barbarians, I do not think that Japan will walk the

path of isolation# In the second place I want to call your attention to a very simple thing# "When you lock at a foreign country, particularly when you do not read the language of the people, you are prone to place too much stress upon extreme sides of the pic¬ ture. Now I lament the great importance, too much importance, placed upon the extreme views now in print or in oral expression about the Japanese• For instance in reading the most interesting and most penetrating, excellent data paper of Sir Frederick Whyte, I take exception to his placing so much importance on the extreme view of KODO or the imperial way of government# I do not think that is the great¬ est thought of the Japanese nation at the moment. That, however, ife entirely ny individual ,view# ...How. the Japanese traditional policy has always been to accept the superior points in assorted cultures. We even now revere the name of Confucius and the Great Buddha. The debts we owe to the great nations on the Asiatic con¬ tinent, China and India, are heavy. In the past three-quarters of a century our debts to western people have been very great, and we do not forget our gratitude to them. Therefore, I do not think the majority of the people follow the lines of isolation. D0 you realize the extent to which Japanese public education has gone? At present the illiteracy of the Japanese is less than 4g^. Ninety-nine and one-half percent of the children from the ages of 6 to 12 are attending schools. That is the basis on which we demand the great nations to treat us as their equals and their sisters. Now what about the Japanese liberals? Who wore they who were assassinated? Liberals. Who are now fighting at the risk of life in Japan? So-called liberals. And if you could road Japanese books, etc. you would realize that i/ve arc not like some countries of Europe. We still have liberal traditions of thought. The liberal? politically demand the maintenance of the parliamentary system of government. Economically they are demanding more and more socialistic legislation of the country. In this connection I may say at present there are many things that even the well wishers of Japan are not happy about and are not satisfied with, and I must confess there are and have been a number of things in the countries which I admire so much, France, England, and the United States of America, or China, there are things even in these countries which wo cannot quite agree with. Therofore, I know that there o.re many things on which you can't agree with us, but I want to conclude my disjointed talk with this: We Japanese aro now passing through the throes of internal reconstruction, and I hope the friends in the outside world, the well-wishers of the peace of the world will have patience and sympathy for us, who partly due to geographical situation have been meeting with these difficulties, and partly to the exigencies of the time aro facing tho serious task now before us.

Secretariat 193G Document 18 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON JAPAN ROUND TABLE TOPIC II, August 20, 1956 (Sir Kenneth Wigram) I cannot tell you how shy I feel at my presumpticn, as a mere soldier in addressing this audience of experts, most of whom have forgotten more than I ever knew* It is some consolation, however, to me to recall that somewhat trite definition of the genus Expert, namely, the man who knows more and more about less and less. My feelings are, I imagine, not very dissimilar to those of Daniel when cast into the lions1 den, though I am afraid that no lion who may be tempted to devour me will get even half a meal off me. Now let me try, if I may, tc summarize the impressions I have got from the discussions of the past three days, but before doing so I should like to thank the members of my round table, and particularly the Japanese members, for the high standard of the discussion and for the free v/ay in which opinions were expressed. As I saw it,the main theme running through the agenda was Japanese expansion and the effect such expansion was having on other nations. My first reaction to that was that a nation like Japan has not gratuitously put her¬ self in the wrong vis-a—vis other nations, thereby causing herself a sense of loneliness, and for all practical purposes, cf isolation, without some very good reason. The first thing to do, therefore, was to attempt to discover the causes which prompted her to take the action she did, for until those causes were diagnosed it was surely futile to attempt to apply a remedy to the problems which ensued. Generally speaking, the causes may be described as political, in which I include security requirements and defense generally, and economic. Subsidiary to both these main causes are the psychological and historical factors which in some curious way seem to influence, and at times to a very great extent, the course of political and economic policy. In any case they are both very important auxiliaries and form, if I may use a mili¬ tary expression, the supports and reserves. Cn the economic side I feel that we should regard the problem not primarily as one of Japanese expansion but as part of the problem of world conditions as a whole. If these conditions had not been so abnormal during the past decade I doubt whether Japanese expansion would be a matter of such world wide concern, I have no intention of enumerating the political and strategical factors which have contributed to this policy of expansion. Suffice it to say that they did exist and in the eyes of Japan were of sufficient import¬ ance to demand immediate attention. The methods by which Japan elected to give them that attention, and the subsequent menace in which she implemented her policy, are quite another matter, and although these methods might have been the fashion in the 19th century, and are even being practised in that highly civilized continent, Europe, at the present day, they are

no longer fashionable except with the promoters, and are inclined, to offend. the susceptibilities of the world at large. On the economic side I speak as a child, but reenforced by the knowledge that in the comity of economists there is no general staff, and consequently no doctrine, and that by an astute weaving of words principles can be interpreted in more ways than one, and so I take my courage in both- hand s • I am greatly struck at the desire evinced by a large number of members of every delegation to accept free trade as the most effective way of restoring the equilibrium, I have always imagined that the prosperity •f an individual country, in fact the prosperity of the world as a whole, is largely dependent *n the volume of international trade# And yet what do -*• see around me? Every artifice and every device to restrict the normal flow of that trade by tariffs, by quotas, by subsidies. These, I realize, can be and are justified by the peculiar conditions pertaining in various parts of the world. The question I ask myself is: Are such expedients, which after all benefit only a portion of the community at the expense of the remainder, really sound? To come back to Japan, are we not inclined to set up Japanese trade expansion as a bogey and to lose our sense of proportion and per¬ spective? May not the real trouble be due to the fact that it came as a surprise to a distressed and dislocated world? Again, may I assume my former existence and draw an analogy from military affairs? I need not dilate on the value of surprise, nor need I remind you of the greatest ex¬ ponent of that weapon, Stonewall Jackson, whose motto was "Mystify and Mis-* lead," and who, by the consistent employment of surprise was able to main¬ tain his forces in the field against superior numbers. An individual taken by surprise, be he general or be he a politician, will, as a rule, seek expedients, will sacrifice rational thinking for speed, and will cften act in an irrational way. May not our discussions here help us to get a correct perspective, a better sense yf proportion? The real embarrassment to other countries lay in the time factor, for industrial communities must have time to adapt themselves to new con¬ ditions created by the arrival on the scene of a nev;- and powerful competitor. "What the world asks Japan is that she should realize this and should regulate her export development in such a way as to minimize the dislocation caused to other countries. There are also the questions of population pressure and agrarian distress. The former, though acute, now should, I understand, adjust itself in time. As for the latter, it will be for Japan to decide whether she can combine agriculture with industry in those small islands. The vexed question of low selling prices, connected as they are with wage rates and standards of life, which though fully deserving the attention they received, are a field into which I have neither the time nor the tech¬ nical knowledge to enter. In the present temper of the world, we cannot hope for speedy restoration, and may have to wait a considerable time. That, however, need not prevent a constant search for amelioration and for measures which may rolicve the present tension, even by short-term adjustments. For example,

there is the proposal to transfer the obligation to impose restrictions from the importing country to the exporting country. Again, something may be done by trade agreements on the basis of reciprocity and fair play# Other short term measures of a similar nature have also been discussed# My conclusion is that (a) on the political side the principal cause of the present trouble is, on the one hand, fear born of suspicion, on the other hand, fear born of the reactions to that suspicion, followed by action which tends to aggravate that suspicion# The remedy here surely lies in collective security# On the economic side, the principal factor as I see it is the growing desire for national economy, and in that field the remedy surely lies in a more liberal recognition by all concerned of their duty towards their neighbors# "Knowledge driveth out fear#" The discussions we are having here add something to our knowledge and will, I hope, go some way towards allaying that fear# If to that knowledge wo also add good will, wo shall, I feel, bo t;c11 equipped to dissipate that fear altogether#

THX GENERAL RAPPORTEUR ON HOUND TABLE TOPIC II JAPAN The discussion of Topic II by the four round tables has been earnest and eager, but has been happily free from any such feeling as might naturnlly hrve been expected if the discussion had been conducted by partisans, instead of scholar; 'Vo ^-ve a^ le&rned, I am sure, that proolems so complicated can be viewed from many points of view, and thrb it is not strange if the exponent of a policy sometimes fails to soe^all of its implications. The value of"discussion lies in the ultimate presentation of a comprehensive picture which could not be expected from any one speaker, however.detached. . . drowning in The Ring and the Book" has given us the greatest literary exposition oi tais truth, and our Round Tables have successively ^iven us the views of Half-Rome, the Other Half Bono, and the Tcrtium Quid, until we are in a measure, now ready for the final judgment. * . _ The subjCG^ assigned for the three days was originally the recent com¬ mercial expansion of tee Japanese, In order that the widest view might be taken t ie ritish ^legation suggested that the methods and obj ectives of the trade polic- 01 . ?* B^tain bG simultaneously examined, and we thus had before us the com- mercial policy^of the two great island trading empires, whose industrialization has caused tneir well-being to depend upon commerce, and who have geared their credit policy to the sale of their manufactured goods, c ~ Ah!? ?^tr°"°rdinarily vaIuable data P^ers prepared for submission to the Conference laid a background of fact under the discussion of such solidity thot th! does not recall a single instance in which controversy arose over the statistics of commercial intercourse. The interpretation of these basic 1 acts, nowever, was vigorously disputed, ... , Th° merf exten't Of Japan's overseas commerce, it w.e pointed out, was not enough to alarm her competitors for the trade of the world. In the cureroeate it amounts to only 4%. iiYhy is it then that the commercial expansion of Japan Jsas causeu^so genuine an anxiety in the rest of the world? Tyro answers, in the main were given to this question. First, it was pointed out that the speed of Jaoan's expansion caused dislocation in the established industries and markets of the world, which it would have boon difficult to digest in normal times, but which a Wh°n Praotloally every country was struggling to rocover from a of than pr<3SS10n Drescrited shocks quite beyond the absorptive power of many were trieftf^t^ rCmei:lf,ored «"»* theories prevailed and many expedients mon-urn + % in recover.>r<' Lo general economic conference undertook to which ht i I rf6'7 0r t0 aSSign to thc ▼oriow nations the earts the TOrld the°efi>ct^7*f d been any such thing as economic isolation in h e i i- •+ j j. ■ a na'tlon 0 policies, whether sound or unsound, would ,.ve been limited to its own shores. But there was nothing oven remotely resor¬ ting economic isolation. Instead we constituted, for better or worse, a closely

integrated family of peoples, and however "bravely we asserted our self-sufficiency and independence, wo wore actually dependent upon one another in vital ways. It was impossible for .America to play with its silver policy, all in the confines of its own backyard. It was impossible for some nations to go off Gold and others to stay anchored to Gold, without causing deepened depression in other places. Tariffs, quotas, subsidies and the whole apparatus of modern commercial life wore found to bo sensitive to disturbance from without and to have external consequences of the gravest sort. The flowering of Japanese commorcial expansim seems to have come at a time when both its extent and its consequences were magnified in fact and even more In appearance. The years 1930 and 1931 showed Japanese trade at a low point. During the depression Japan prepared actively to take her place in the revival when it should come. This she did by an extraordinary revolution in her technical pro¬ cesses, which enabled, her to turn out more goods at loss labor cost. Then, as the currencies of the world retreated from Gold, Japan followed the load and by devaluing the Yon again cheapened the cost of the goods with which she sought to capture export markets. In all this there was c nfosscdly no plan to upset the economy of any other notion, No speaker claimed that there was anything wrong in Japan's ambition to soil as much as she could, wherever sac could. Indeed, apart from several acute collisions of particular Japanese products with long established industries, as, for instance cheap cotton piece goods flooding the markets long rolled upon by Lancashire, there was a clerr feeling that Japan with her cheap manufactured goods, had been a welcome merchant, and the hope was repeatedly voiced that trade with Japan would continue to grow. Nevertheless, the questions of speed and dislocation persisted, Japan, it was claimed, sold her cotton piece goods at 20$ or even 30$ below the prevailing price for similar qualities when 10$ would have amply sufficed to give her all the competitive advantage which she needed. The consequence of this was that Japan not only preempted the market for the cheaper grades but seriously injured the market for better grades, with which she did not compete. Another Illustration of dislocation was afforded from the Netherlands East Indies, here a dramatic decline both in imports and exports was to be noted, Japan, a former large customer, protected her own infant industries behind barrier tariffs, thus cutting her imports while at the same time she marketed her exports in increased quantities in the Netherlands Islands, It is clear that here was a double dislocation. The Netherlands Islands were forced to find new customers among countries to whom they were not accustomed to soil, and at the same time were buying increased quantities from a country which was not in the habit of selling to them. From Japan's point of view the conflicts between her expanding trade and the local national recovery policies were entirely accidental, and the dislocations were only those which inevitably occur when a new commercial competitor enters the field, While some of the Western countries accept 1928 or 1929 as a normal trade year, manifestly it cannot be accepted as a general normal. Nor can "recovery" in Japan be taken to mean the same thing there as elsewhere. For one of the old industrialized nations of the West, recovery means the re-attainment of an earlier

level of well-being. For Japan, a newcomer into the competitive field, it means setting the pegs farther forward. As one member of the Conference phrased it, to Japan it is Recovery plus discovery, which is the true standard of measurement. In general it nay be said that there was a general recognition of the legitimacy of Japan*s commercial aspirations. That she is a proud, dynamic people, desiring to do well whatever she undertakes, and that she is really serving us all as she cheapens the cost of production and distributes her skill and economy was agreed, Japan is entitled to the place in the commercial sua which her genius may give her. Such concessions, however, were safeguarded by questioning whether the standard of living of human beings should be depressed, and while it was generally agreed to be impossible to equate the various satisfactions which national taste and tradition led people to value, yet it was felt that the industrial system required various guarantees of employment and provisions against exhausted vitality to a minimum which should not be sacrificed anywhere in the competitive struggle. Such, then, was the outcome of the discussion of Japanese commercial expansion, viewed purely as a commercial phenomenon. It would have been less noticeable at any other time. It had the y.dsfortune to run at cross-purposes to many plans for national recovery, and while not absolutely extensive enough to be serious, the speed of its impact was too great for the absorptive power of closely integrated national economies into which it was projected. The special case of China naturally took up a groat place in the general problem. There seems to be a frank feeling on the part of Japan that ^hina is a special case, and a marked reluctance on the part of China to being so regarded, Japan, China's closest neighbor, feels that she has special interests there which she claims can only be protected by a strong and not unfriendly central Government,, She regards herself as justified in being friendly to autonomous governments which, while still a part of ^hina, are hostile in sentiment to the central Government and not hostile to what Japan has come to regard as her right in Manchuria, The. outstanding phenomenon in this conflict of views has arisen from the smuggling in Hopei Province, v-.here in the eleven months from August 1935 to July 1936 the national revenues of ^hina have suffered a loss claimed to amount to 136,000,000, a sum tragically needed by china if her reconstruction is not to be delayed and if she is to continue to meet promptly her external obligations. This smuggling is said to be enlarging in the categories of smuggled goods, and ex¬ tending in geographical penetration, and to the eyes of the Chinese it naturally ha the appearance of an attack upon her administrative integrity which not only threatens her ability to arrange further needed rec nstructi m loans but emporils her ability to meet her existing obligations. To the Japanese claim that China s tariffs are so high as to amount to a prohibition of imports when the purchasing capacity of the Chinese is taken into account, C:;ina replies that while she has raised her tariff repeatedly since she acquired autonomy in fiscal policy, she has not yet reached an average tariff as high as that of Japan, The grievance, however, is not primarily commercial. Its political implications are obvious and are the components of the gravest controversy affecting the relations between these two great powers. This Institute can only hope that its researches into the problem have been helpful in permitting the gravity of the problem to be made clear. Patient and just Statesmanship must supply the answer.

Upon the political implications of Japan's commercial expansion, in general the Conference has "been distinctly helpful. '.<e have all come to realize that something more than unobstructed access to raw materials in peace ti .ie is necessary if countries not wholly self contained cm be expected to feel secure, when the great exigency of War faces them. Fear is at the root of the trouble, a fear which cannot be exorcised by assurances or quieted by being blind to the realities of life in the modern world. It is an over-simplification to ask with regard to Japan or any other country, why they are arming. Modern war is so swift and terrible in its onset as to leave no time for preparation after the danger appears. Responsible states¬ men must be prepared and no excuses are taken for anything so colossal as failure. The extent of preparation for war will be judged by each nation after it has measured its dangers and its needs. If Japan is industrializing and seeking independence in the matter of raw material, who shall say that her statesmen arc wrong, unless the united world has some assurance to give them against disaster. But one thing this conference has made very clear: that there is no security but collective security. How to achieve that is the quest of the Holy Grail, For a little while wo may depend upon our own strength and in pride and confidence pursue our own. course, but in the long run the end of that course is chaos, That is the implied lesson of every discussion in the Conference, and it is especially interesting to note that that lesson is emphasized in the con¬ structive suggestions made- as the Hound Table was about to dissolve. The most notable of these had to do with temporary adjustments of existing commercial con¬ troversies of one sort or another. It was proposed with regard to the weaving industry and the like that the Japanese enter into trade agreements in order to prevent collisions and disloactions. I hope that out of the data papers and deliberations of this Conference statesmen of our countries mil find it possible to take up actively the maturing of treoties which will answer some of these com¬ mercial questions. Then it was the groat suggestion made by M, Sarraut that in view of the obstinate character of many of these controversies, particularly iiir, view of the problem of population as it affects the Japanese, the only apparent answer to the question is industrialization; in view of that, and in view of the dispute about the standard of living in various countries of the world, he under¬ took to make the suggestion that there should be called two great conferences, one economic. Disregarding the failure of the recent one, taking a fresh hope, he felt there ought to be called a conference to deal with world economics, surveying the needs, the dangers, the conflicts, and undertaking to reconcile the difficulties which nations have in adjusting their trade as it expands. Then, he felt, there ought to bo called a World Disarmament Conference. Whether or not the approach to peace is to be through voluntary disarmament, whether or not some further con¬ structive effort for peace is not a surer reliance than disarmament, may bo a debatable question, but the calling of two such conferences, and the focussing of the eyes of the world, upon the problem of colloctivc security as the answer, would seem to be in the direction that the world ought to move, and this eastern world, like the western world, would find its problems answered, by such a conference. It is no part of my duty as -Rapporteur, it may even bo a presumptive In¬ trusion of the sentiments of an individual whose whole luty will be done when he has faithfully reported trhat others have said, but to me the problem of collective actir to assure peace with justice is the most inspiring task of statesmanship. My countr is not a party to the post-war system which aims to secure that blessing and upon the part which America can take now or hereafter in its operation my countrymen are divided, but to me, in the recent test of that system in Europe, Sir Anthony Eden was a knightly figure. The limits of possible concerted action may have been misjudged, but at least he tried to save collective security for the world, and I envy him his gallant action.
