essay:div.essay:p: Secretariat 1936 Document 35 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON U.S.S.R. - ROUND TABLE TOPIC III August 21, 1936 (Mrs® Barbara Wootton) Ladies and Gentlemen: May I say first of all, how much I appreci¬ ate having the opportunity of speaking on the first occasion on which the Soviet Union has participated in the I#;-P.R», and on the first occasion on which the topic of that country has occupied its full place in our conference« The Soviet Union celebrated its coming of age and reaching the age of dis«i cretion last year3 and wo are all glad to welcome this new young member of the comity of nations among those who like many states represented here, are weighed down with a greater seniority, I take this opportunity of welcoming the Soviet members of this conference© I am going to open this enormous topic by picking out one or two of the salient facts which our friends have placed at your disposal in the data papers. Former experience with conferences encourages me to believe that not all of the members of conferences read all of the data papers; some read most of them; most of them read some. Perhaps I had bettor not go further. Let me ask you first of all to look over some of the facts of re¬ construction which have taken place during the present period of planning in the Soviet Union® Let mo ask you to remind yourselves that during the period from 1929, while the incomes of most of us have been regretably re¬ duced, the Soviet Union claims that the income of that country has been ad¬ vanced from 29 billion rubles to 65 billion rubles# Let me also remind you that over the same period tho amount of new capital invested has been mul¬ tiplied five-fold. We are accustomed to the signs of uninvested and un- investable capital® The Soviet Union faces that unfamiliar phenomenon, an apparently insatiable demand for more capital for more investment. Let me remind you of some of the achievements of the Soviet Union in quantitative rather than in monetary terms* One test of activity which will bo most con¬ vincing is the tost of the volume of railway transportation. Anyone who has traveled on a Soviet train will hardly dispute any figures about the density of travelI At tho beginning of the planned period, 187 million tons of freight and 365 million people were carried in ono year. Six years later the railways carried nearly 3 times as many tons of freight and 919 million people* Progress in agricultural output is shown by an increase in production of the principal cereals from 717 to 901 million centners from 1929 - 35. In industry the output per worker employed has increased about 64 per cent, while the number of workers has approximately doubled*, These are only a few of tho high spots. To complete the picture let me refer to the data papers ■ about tho Northern Sea routo. There is described one of the most picturesque and romantic enterprises of the Soviet Union# Already vessels are regularly passing the full length of tho Northern soa passage. It is true that there are not very many of them yet, and one of the topics of your round tables will be to discuss how far that route has genuine economic possibilities# At least, the Soviet Union has demonstrated enterprise and virility. The first is the increased attontion to consumers' goods which distinguishes the second from the first plan and which, I understand, the Soviet Union hopes will bo more particularly realized in the later years of the second plan. The first plan was the most Herculean capital enterprise ever undertaken. The second plan is showing a little more regard for some of our common human frailties

which express themselves in the desire for the minor luxuries of contemporary life® Second, I would call attention to the increasing emphasis on the development of the Far Eastern regions, and of the whole of Asiatic Russia. The natural resources of the Soviet Union in the Far Eastern region have hardly yet been surveyed. They are now beginning to be adequately explored and it soems likely that eventually the natural economic contcr of the Union will be East rather than West of the Ural Mountains, That, however, is look¬ ing very far ahead. In the meantime it is significant to notice that the capital development proposed in the eastern part of the country under the second plan is four times as groat as the development under the first plan. That capital development is accompanied by a relative increase of the pop¬ ulation in the Eastern part of the country. As a result of all of this it is commonly accepted that you have had a marked rise in the standard of living of the Russian and Soviet peoples# It is the claim of the Soviet Union that there is no natural or necessary economic limit to that rise. Lly colleague, Mr. Romn, who is speaking presently, may have something to say about this, and the economics of it will no doubt occupy some of the round tables. It is evident, at ]c ast that whatever limit there may be to the planned standard of living is not oppressive at the moment. Two features of tho whole planning I would like especially to em¬ phasize. The first is TEMPO - our conception of a reasonable tempo of economic expansion. Everything in economics is relative, and nothing more so than the conception of economic tempo. The rate of development in the Soviet Union is certainly startling. In the old days tho economists used to talk, when they spoke with more confidence than they do today, of 3% per annum, as a normal rate of development of all the production industries of the v/hole world. In tho Soviet Union an increase on the order of 15 to 20% soems now to be regarded as tho minimum that is respectable. Second, the common economic assumption is disproved by recent events in the Soviet Union. This is the assumption that what is known as economically backward areas will be developed by tho surplus capital of other countries. This may have very important meanings for other parts of the world. Ono of the interesting topics of discussion is the extent to which this independence of foreign capital has imposed difficulties and privation on the Soviet people# In tho meantime, I think we academics have to thank the Soviet Union for at least providing us with tho supreme illustration of the capital¬ ist virtue of abstinence I As a result of all of this, the Soviet Union comes into what we somewhat arrogantly call the comity of nations, and .comes demanding respect. The Soviet Union has acquired two of the current titles of rospect. First, they have very largo armaments, and second, they have demonstrated their power of borrowing money. If you wish to enjoy respect in this world, carry a gun and borrow moneyi Need I add that they have gone even further, and that they are now actually in thr front rank of tho world's producers of goldt 1 think that they have no more worlds to conquor. The next question is, are they going to have happy relations economically and politically with the rest of us? As to their trade relations, wo used to be uneasy about the possibility of happy economic relations with a country whoso economic and social life was planned, and whoso foreign trade was in the hands of govern¬ ment monopoly. But it has been found possible today to conduct a trade of quite substantial volume between the planned and the unplanned community. Some of the burden of our complaint, v«rhen we British moaned about the dif-» ficulties of Japanese competition is relevant here. We found ourselves some-

times wishing that the Japanese would take in hand the planning of their foreign trade. The Soviet's own. theory about trade is that they will always need some foreign trade as complementary to their internal production# They look back on past experience and note that, as the level of the standard of living rises, so the amount of internation exchange has tended to increase* Exchange between advanced industrial nations, as in pro-war days between England and Germany, was on a very substantial scale* Again the Soviet Union could not easily be wholly salf-sufficient# When ^ had a discussion yester¬ day with Mr# Roma as to the possibility of producing of bananas in the Soviet Union, I was interested to find that he was not unduly optimistic# Let us now look at the facts of the existing situation. First, Soviet trade has changed materially during the period of the plans, and that in accordance with the Soviet's own principles. They now import less machinery, fewer motor cars and almost none of what has bccome a sort of symbol of the ideology of Soviot Union, the tractor# Their imports turn to raw materials such as rubber and the more luxurious food stuffs® This is going to produce problems for the rest of us# Trade complementary to your own production docs not necessarily mean trade complementary to the convenience of the rest of the world. In this connection, however, one should recall the Soviet attitude to the theory that, as every nation develops it will become choked with a surfeit of its own goods« ™he Soviet contention is that this will never happen to them because they have an infinite swallowing capacity. Wo in the old-fashioned part of the world had better perhaps stick to the facts of the present, and withhold judgment on the whole Soviet theory# The facts are that there is not yet any sign of a flood of Soviot exports. The Soviet foreign trade has shrunk with the foreign trade of the rest of the world, and it has certain tendencies to shrink even on its own account. Their main ob¬ ject is to acquire essential .commodities, and the supplies of these at homo are far greater in the Soviet Union than, for example, in Japan# We cannot look ahead for more than 10 or 15 years, and I see no sign of a vast Soviet export trade in that time. There is another fact that the Soviet Union has to face# The population of that country increases by about 3 million souls a year and nothing that can be d one is likely to diminish that increase within a generation's time. I shall leave for later developments in the round tables the interesting allied questions about the digestive capacities of our various economic systems. I now introduce Mr. Romm.

Secretariat 1936 Document 39 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON USSR ROUND TABLE TOPIC III,AUGUST 21,1936 (V. Romm) The U.S#S#R# group appears for the first time before a conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations; we come before you at a moment when our country has achieved much and is looking forward to achie\re much more. We have achieved a socialist society, a society, the foundation of which is public ownership, state and. also cooperative, collective farm property as the means of production, A society where there is no longer unemployment, no exploit¬ ation, no oppression of nationalities. Our society has virtually become a class¬ less one. In the political field these processes have found their expression in the further historical step in the development of a genuine democracy and a genuine freedom - the Stalinist draft of the New Constitution of the U.S.S.R. The rapid industrialization of the country, which has transformed it from a backward agricultural into an advanced industrial country, with a planned economy, has been accomplished solely by our own forces. In our construction work we had to overcome difficulties, both external and internal. The socialist construction was carried out on the basis of a planned and rational development of productive forces and opening of new resources. To under¬ stand the significance of what has been achieved it is necessary to visualize for a moment what was the starting point. We had to start from extremely low levels. There were people in our country who denied the very possibility of building up socialism in our country. The Trotskyist counter-revolutionaries who are tried at this very moment in Moscow for a contemptible plot against the life of the great leader of our country - Stalin - were proclaiming the impossibility of successful socialist construction. Theirs v/ould have been a policy of internal and external adventures instead of the present policy of construction within and peace without. They were defeated by lack of any mass support and thus the very fact that they finally resorted to desperate acts cmd plots of individual terrorism is in a way a peculiar illustration of tho plenitude of our victories. The level from which wo had to start was very low indeed. Old Russia was a country with a very low level of general industrial development, an extremely low standard of living of the great majority, and with a lack of development of natural resources, a great part of which wore even hardly known. Russian and foreign capital developed only those resources and regions which could be most conveniently exploited for a direct and rapid profit. Besides the general lack of development, this resulted in an extremely unequal distribu¬ tion of productive forces. Three-fourths of the whole industry were conccntrated in a few regions of European Russia. The greater part of the country was scarcely populated and was kept on a primitive level. The relationship between the centrcil parts of the country and its outlying regions was of a clearly colonial character, Siberia, Central Asia, the Caucasus, etc. were converted into raw material append¬ ages.

In 1921, Lenin wrote; "Look at the map of Russia, North of Vologda, southeast from Rostov-on-the-.Don and Saratov, south from Orenburg and Omsk, north of Tomsk, there are endless spaces which could hold dozens of immense civilized countries. And on all those spaces reign patriarchial conditions, semi-barbarism and even complete barbarism," As early as in 1918 -^enin stressed the necessity of a rational distribu¬ tion of industry from the viewpoint of bringing it near the source of raw materials. The great progress in the development of enormous new industrial regions in the east of the USSR is a planned development in this direction. The bringing of industry near to sources of raw materials is the economic basis of our national policy, a policy of complete political, racial, cultural and linguistic equality. Backward nationalities and regions everywhere are those that produce raw materials and possess no industry of their own. The rapprochement of the in- dustry to sources of raw materials eliminated any remnant of colonial relations and achieves economic equality making all nationalities and regions equal partici¬ pants in the common work, thus largely by itself raising backward nationalities to a higher level. But this latter task is also the object of numerous special measures destined to accelerate the development of formerly backward regions. It is significant that in the draft of the New Constitution several republics, formerly only autonomous, or indirectly affiliated with the Union, are raised to the status of sovereign constituent national republics of the Union, In industrializing the country along the linos laid down by Lenin and Stalin, in raising agriculture to a higher level - of a large scale production on a collective basis and equipped with modern technical means - the USSR over¬ comes the...historic inequality between city and village, raising the agricultural population to higher material and cultural standards. And the problem of the attitude towards formerly backward nationalities is but a particular case of the problem of the relationship with the peasantry. In our nationality policy we are standing on Stalin1s definition of the nation as "a historically evolved, stable community of language, territory, economic life and psychological make-up mani¬ fested in a community of culture," Among the developments described, the advance of the industry to the east of the country is of foremost importance. One of the most outstanding events is the completion of a second coal-metal basis in the East, - the Ural-Kusnotsk Combinate, not to mention other important industrial developments in the Asiatic part of the USSR. The development of the communication and transport system follows the same pattern as the development of industry. Incidentally, the industrialization of the USSR in general, and of its Asiatic part in particular, has strengthened its economic and military power and thus has strengthened its security and capacity for defense in the Far East. The ever growing power of the USSR cannot bo considered menacing for any¬ body, Not only is the USSR opposed in principle to any aggression or expansion, but does not need any such thing. Our system contains within itself unlimited possibilities for the development of productive forces, for the progress of tech¬ nique and for the increase of productivity of labor. At the same time progress in the USSR can never result in unemployment or overproduction. Our economy is not governed by profit but by the requirements of the masses of the people. The rapidly rising standards of living create unlimited possibilities of development of the internal market. The increasing production, under a planned socialist eco¬ nomy, is and will be rapidly absorbed by growing consumption. There is no objective

limit for the rise of standards of living and cultural standards. Therefore, it is unthinkable that need should ever arise even for a trade expansion, not to speak about other more grave forms of expansion* The USSR has achieved technical economical independence and foreign markets play a subsidiary part in its economic activity. The USSR is not dependent upon exports, unlike many other countries. At the same time it is not refusing to develop economic, commercial, technical and other relations with other nations on a basis of mutual advantage. The aim of becoming a self-supporting and economic¬ ally independent country, which we have achieved, has nothing to do with theories and practices of * self-sufficiency1 and * autarchy,T so fashionable nowadays in some of the Authoritarian1 European countries. We are not for economic isolation, and it should be borne in mind that exchanges between advanced countries are much more active and varied than between advanced and backward countries. The transformation brought about by the new social system in our country will become most clearly apparent if wo remember for a moment what wore the social setup and the policies of Tsarist Russia. The comparison, incidentally, will show how little truth there is in "Geopolitik" theories emanating from present-day Germany. Those theories would like us to believe that the policy of a country, its interests and "needs for expansion" are predestined and for all times to come predetermined by immutable geographic factors, independently from its social system. The Tsarist Empire, plus the present territory of the USSR, occupied the territory of Poland and Finland and the Baltic States. Thus it possessed even more territory than the USSR, And it was conducting wars of conquest throughout its history. It was the weakness of the internal market that prompted the policies of conquest. Agriculture was handicapped by feudal relations, the peasant was fleeced by the landlord, the 'wages were very low. One of the Tsar's ministers coined a startling phrase - "We will go hungry but we will export." The huge country, with its vast empty spaces suffered from "overpopulation" and actively supplied immigrants to the U.S.A. at the end of the 19th and the beginning of the 20th century, while the USSR, existing on the same "geography" takes measures to encourage the increase of population, which is growing at the rate of over 3 millions a year. Having an undeveloped internal market, Tsarist Russia preferred to "expand," selling abroad goods which its own population could not afford to buy. It went from one adventure to another - the Russo-Japanese war, attempts to conquer Constantinople and the Straits, if not the who1e of Turkey, etc, - and finally went to its grave. This may be history, but its lessons aro useful. Just as it was natural for Tsarist Russia to be an active factor of ruthless imperialist policy, it is natural for us to have a consistent policy of peace. Perhaps one of the most interesting examples of the complete reversal of trends with the change in systems is the attitude of the USSR towards those count¬ ries which in the past were objects of the imperialist and colonial aggression or domination of Tsarist Russia. The Soviet Union not only has tho best relations with those countries, but on the basis of its growing industrial power, is actively helping them in the development of their productive forces and in the attainment of economic independence.

The foreign policy of the USSR is thus a logical result of the working out of our whole system* It is - in Stalin1s words - "a policy of preserving peace and strengthening commercial relations with all countries." ^t is based on the fundamental principle of peaceful co-existence of different social systems, recognized by the World Economic Conference of 1927. The foreign policy of the Soviet U?iion consists in fighting for peace, for the security of the USSR and fighting for universal peace. The fact that the USSR is in principle opposed to territorial spoliations and imperialist expansion, as well as the fact that - as has been already demonstrated by facts - does not need and docs not want political or economic expansion, excludes the possibility of any other aims in Soviet foreign policy. From this viewpoint the internal achievements of the USSR must be interesting for all friends of peace, because the growth of the economic power and independence of the USSR has so strengthened its military power that the USSR not only assures the security of its frontiers but acts as a moderating factor in the relations between other countries through¬ out the world, making it more difficult to unleash war. The Soviet public opinion, although firmly convinced that the Soviet Union is well defended, and its security not necessarily dependent on outside help, and yet it is deeply disturbed about the dangers to world peace. The cause of collective security has suffered many severe blows. The outcome of the Ethiopian conflict and the failure of the League has to be partly explained by past Y/eaknesses of the League for which the USSR is not responsible and also by the encouragement of other potential European aggressors. The impunity of, and the non-resistance to unilateral revision of the European status by Germany was another severe blow. As a result we see at this very moment a new menace of the use of force, of armed intervention, of the explosion of new contradictions in Europe. Despite all this, public opinion of the USSR as before considers collect¬ ive security is the most efficient way to preserve peace and thinks that the closer the danger of war, the more effective methods are needed to prevent it. The USSR is a consistent supporter of the League Covenant, which is not responsible for the fact that it is not being applied. The USSR is actively participating in collective security wherever there are prerequisites for it, wherever it depends on the USSR. The events of past years and past months again bring home to us the indivisibility of peo.ee. Peace in "Western Europe is not possible without equival¬ ent guarantees of security in Eastern Europe. And it "would bo a vain dream to hope that without restraining European aggressors the Pacific could be pacified.

Secretariat 1936 Document 19 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON RUSSIA ROUND TABLE TOPIC III, AUGUST 22,1936 (Honorable Newton W. Rowell) Mr, Chairman, Ladies and Gentlemen; When in Europe in 1932 I made a special trip to Moscow to extend a personal invitation to the Russian group of the IPR to attend the Conference which was to be held at Banff in the following year. I was most courteously and hospitably received by Dr. Petroff, then the Chairman of the Voks - that is the society for cultural relations with foreign nations - and at that time he hoped and expected that the Soviet group would send a delegation to Banff. It so turned out that expectation was not realized, but in view of that fact I am sure you will appreciate with what cordiality the Canadian delegation joins in the welcome to our Soviet friends tonight. We had hoped to welcome them in Canada. We were not able to do so. We join with the others in the welcome to them now. When there I commenced to read the Moscow News, a daily paper published in English and edited by Mr. Borodin, whose name will be familiar to most of the members of the Conference. I was very much interested in it, and as I found they had a weekly edition, 1 subscribed for it and for the past four years I have boon a consistent reader of the Moscow News, so that 1 have been able to follow from week to week the development in the "Soviet Union, economic, cultural and other¬ wise, and I have sought to increase my knowledge of the developments there by reading a great many books on Russia. The last one I delved into on leaving home was Beatrice and Sidney Webb?s book, to which our Chairman referred. May I say in reference to the Ihily News just one observation, because it does indicate some difference between the social and economic system in Russia and that which prevails elsewhere. I imagine that most papers in the United States and Canada give the public what the public want to read, being inspired by the motive of private profit, ond desiring to increase their circulation they cater to the public taste. In the Soviet Union the papers publish what the people think the public needs and you get in the Soviet newspapers the fullest public information about the government's plans, its achievements and the developments from time to time. It is more serious reading than the average Canadian or American newspaper and is very full of useful information to all those who desire to acquire knowledge of the Soviet. Now, tonight I have been asked to give some impressions of the round table discussions and in the time at my disposal I can only refer to a very few. May I say that one of the things that impressed me which was discussed at the round tables, although owing to the pressure of time and the magnitude of the questions of great and significant interest, very little time could bo given to it but one, I think, which occasions concern outside of Soviet Russia, was the question of the export of Communism. ^ur Communist friends said that Soviet Communism was a social and economic system and as such could not be exported. I think with that we all agree, but that does not touch this point which un¬ doubtedly is a measure of concern in other countries, and that is the ideology

behind Communism, I think we all recognize that ideas recognize no international boundry. The ideas, modified, it is true, in their application in the Soviet Union, of Karl Marx, existed before the Soviet Union was formed and even if the Soviet Union for any reason should collapse, would continue to exist* It ox-^ presses an idea of social, economic and political organization, and I have this observation to make in reference to it because I know in my own country and in some other countries there are different ideas as to how the matter can be treated. I venture to suggest that if one does not believe and accept the Com¬ munistic ideology, the only way to answer it is to present a bettor one. I do not believe you can defeat ideas by force and I think one of the real failures in capitalistic countries has been on the part of economists or those who believe in the system to place a reasoned defense of their system as against the reasoned advocacy of Communism, and unless in capitalist countries we are able to present from economists and those interested in the problem a reasoned economy which will answer in the public mind the ideas presented in the Communist theory, we can not hope to maintain our existing system, and I throw it out as one of the most important and serious questions discussed in the Conference for those who believe in a different social, political and economic system from that which prevails in Russia. Another matter which I think impressed everyone of us was the remarkable record presented by our Soviet colleagues of the industrial development of recent years, including the industrialization of agriculture, and the not less notable increase in the military strength and defenses of Russia. No one could read the data papers presented by our Russian colleagues or listen to the full and frank discussion at the round tables without being impressed by the marvelous develop¬ ments that have token place in Soviet Russia in the last ton years. Those develop¬ ments, however, do create & situation that must necessarily be the subject of interest and concern on the part of other nations and peoples. J-here are certain international implications and reactions which must inevitably follow^this re¬ markable development in Russia. I shall but refer to two tonight. First: What, if any, will be the effect of this industrialization of Russia - the increasing industrialization of Russia - upon world trade and upon tho foreign trade activities of other countries. Now, we spent some two days discussing the remarkable industrial ex¬ pansion of Japan and the groat increase of her foreign trade and the effect of that increase upon the foreign trade of other countries. When we came to discuss the question of the possible effect of the industrialization of Russia our friends presented, as I understood it, this point of view: First: Wo arc now self-contained and we do not need to export as in the past and therefore there is no absolute necessity of our pressing our goods upon foreign customers and flooding foreign markets; Secondly: If I rightly understood our friends, there being no element of private profit in the matter, there is no incentive on our part to press our trade upon foreign countries. And ono must recognize the foroe of those answers. They pointed out tho difference between the motive of profit in a capitalistic country, but I feel safe in saying that not all the members of the round table were wholly satisfied with that answer or that tho other nations of the world engaged in international trade can make their plans on the assumption that Soviet goods will not interfere with them and may not seriously interfere with them in

in trade competition in foreign markets, and I mention it for this reason: During the past, when the Soviet government needed to import raw materials or they needed particularly machinery in connection with the development of the First Five-Year Plan, one recognizes thci it was essential that they should export goods in order to get the money to purchase the articles they needed to import. During that period, as we know, they dumped goods upon the market which in certain com¬ modities seriously demoralized the market, I refer to two of which I have particular knowledge because they especially p„ffooted Canada - timber and wheat. This is the one point of possible apprehension: While the Soviet may not need to export at the present time because it is self-contained, while there is no profit motive to induce it to export, should any exigency arise whereby the Soviet wanted to increase its foreign credit in order to import foreign goods, by the complete control of export trade they have it in their power to place any goods produced by them in any foreign market in the world at any price they deem necessary to sell in order to get the necessary credit, I am not making any question about it, I am simply pointing that out as a possibility, but I think I should add this: That I would venture to think that the chance of the Soviet government exporting goods in a way that might seriously dislocate foreign trade would be much less if peace is preserved in the world than it would be if the Soviet government were faced with war and thereby com¬ pelled to adopt extraordinary measures to secure supplies that were needed or establish credit, and therefore from the standpoint of peace I should think on the whole the standpoint of peace were better if peace continues than if world disturbances took place. Then the second international implication arising from this development is the remarkable growth of the Soviet army and the increased fortifications which have been established in Russia and in the Far East, When I vra.s in Russia talking to a well-known American nev/spapor corres¬ pondent, he said to me that he thought the Russian army had the finest morale of any army in the world, I said "Why?" "Because," he said, "every man would be¬ lieve in the ideals for which ho was fighting," I make no comment on it, I simply pass on the observation, but that the Soviet is today one of the groat militarist powers in the world none will question, and everyone who is interested in world affairs, whether he welcomes or regrets the situation, must recognize that the Soviet today is one of the greatest powers of the world and must be recognized in dealing with international questions. Now, on the problem of increased armament and increased fortifications of the Soviet Union what are the international implications? We have had a most interesting discussion in the round tables on that matter. May I say to you quite frankly if the object of the Soviet is peace and to maintain peace, then I gather that the strength of the Soviet forces would bo a stabilizing force' in the world situation. On the other hand, if the Soviet object is not peace, then one must recognize that the existence of those large armaments must necessarily involve a disturbing factor in the international situation. Speaking for myself, I am personally impressed with the view that the Soviet is inspired by peaceful intentions and I base that view on three grounds: First: the fact that the Soviet joined the League of Nations and has participated

in this organization for maintaining world peace is to ray mind striking evidence of peaceful intentions * The second is the desire of the Soviet Union to conclude non-aggression pacts with other nations - and many have been so concluded, I can hardly think that If their desire was to engage in any militaristic or aggressive enterprises they would have been so anxious to conclude these pacts. And third, the progress which has been made in the adjustment in the issues which in the past have divided Japan and Russia - the fact that we know an agreement in principle has been reached on the establishment of a commisssion to deal with border incidents is a matter of great significance to us in Canada, with both Russia and Japan near neighbors across the Pacific® We know the benefit of a Commission to deal with border matters. We have an existing Commission between the United States and Canada that deals with border issues. That Commission has been in existence for more than 25 years and has dealt with a number o f important matters to the entire satisfaction of both countries. Because of our own ex¬ perience we in Canada are very gratified that in principle an agreement has been reached to set up a commission to deal with border incidents and we hope that the actual agreement will soon be concluded. And third, the agreement to delimit a certain area of the boundary which has been in dispute. And between these two and the adjustment of other problems, it is the desire of every friend of both Russia and Japan that any outstanding differences may be amicably settled and that both of these two great powers, with whom we all desire to remain 011 terms of friendship and good understanding, may settle all matters between them in a sense that both will feel just and satisfactory. We all recognize, however, the difficulties of the international situation and a suggestion was made that we could not hope to get a permanent solution of the economic problems, although temporarily arrangements might be made which would smooth the way, without efforts at a more permanent solution and I believe it was also discussed at the round tables on Japan and on Russia in regard to the calling of an economic conference. Whether the present is the time for the calling of ^ such a conference I don!t know# I am sure every student of international affairs must realize that the present tendency toward economic nationalism is leading the world backward instead of forward - in the wrong direction - and unless men in the nations are prepared to take the lead and stand for a better understanding in trade matters and freeing the channels of international trade from some of the^ obstructions that may prevent trade between nations, wo are in danger of slipping back into the dark ages. And I am sure everyone sympathized with the idea of some form of conference between the nations of the world that would put an end to extreme economic nationalism and start the world on the road to world trade. It was also suggested there should be a disarmament conference. I donft know, in view of the past failures, whether it is possible to convene a dis¬ armament conference at the present time that could obtain any practical results, I am afraid some matters in Europe - maybe some in the Far East will have to be adjusted before such a conference can be held, but surely no lover of his kind — no one interested in human progress or human welfare can view but with the gravest apprehension the rise in armaments today, and surely it is the part in the countries from which we come to create the atmosphere which would make possible international cooperation leading to infcernational understanding and a measure of reduction in international armaments.

With the limited time at our disposal it was not possible to go into many of the questions suggested on the agenda* We will have to leave them for another conference or some other occasion, "but 1 think I may say this in connoction with it, that interesting as were the discussions on the New Deal, more interesting as were the discussions on Japan, the most interesting round tables we have had have been those dealing with the Soviet Union, and I think we are indebted to our friends from the Soviet Union for the clear and forceful presentation they ho.ve made of their points of view. We do not expect in this Conference to reach agreement, What we do hope is to understand each otherTs point of view, I confess I qui not converted to the Soviet political and economic system by what I have heard but I under¬ stand better the Soviet economic and political system than I did before, and I am sure we all feel that way. And while the Soviet friends may not have modified theit* ideology by what they have heard from us, I am sure they do not think us so bad as what they have heard us to befc On the -whole these round tables have been most helpful and I am sure in the minds of all the members will constitute one of the most outstanding features of this Conferencek

Secretariat 1936 Document 20 STATJ&SiJT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON RUSSIA ROUND TABLE TOPIC III, AUGUST 17, 1936. (V, Motylov) The USSR Group is extremely pleased with the scope and the direction of the discussions which for two days have been centering on the internal and external policies of the USSR. The USSR Group is under the impression that the fundamental idea which the USSR wanted very much to make clear has met with a considerable measure of understanding and response* It is the idea that the internal development of the USSR excludes the necessity for any sort of expansion and that the peace policy of the USSR is not only a matter of principle and program but the external re¬ flection of the nature of its internal development® Even any necessity for a foreign-trade expansion is eliminated by our development as our socialist economic system is not in nood of foreign markets and does not depend on them. Our policies within the country as well as our peace policy abroad, are both established on the unshakable foundation of the conscious and wholehearted support of the hundred and seventy million population of our country* The creative initiative of the peoples of the USSR and the rapid rise of their cultural levels, manifested in the spirit with which they have worked and acted during the years of Socialist construction, are a most important feature of our development* Without this creative initiative wo would not have been able to accomplish what we have accomplished. One of the most typical features of this creative initiative at the present stage are the great successes in the mastering of the new technique, in the rise of technical skill and in the further rise of cultural levels. The spontaneous development of a new movement among our workers which aims to got out of industrial technique everything it can give is an important development in this direction* This movement, which is being called ' Stakhanovism* creates prerequisites for a great increase in the productivity of labor, of a further acceleration of the tempo of the economic development, and of an accelcratec growth of material well-being of the population. This movement means that the basis of the distinction between mental and manual labor is being undermined. If the elimination of the inequality between mental and manual labor is still a matter of a future, though not too distant, there Is another historical inequality the elimination of which is approaching its fulfillment. The historical inequality between city and country, between the industrial material and cultural standards and the standards of the village - is being gradually overcome on the basis of a collectivized and mechanized agriculture. The traditional inequality between industry and agriculture has been broken also in another sense. If until recently the tempo in the development of agriculture did not correspond to the rapid pace of the industry - during the last two years

thcro has boon a changc in this rcspect also, a change, accomplished on the basis of the large-scale collective fanning. The percentage of the increase of the gross-production in agriculture, compared with the previous year, has been in 1935 - 11 per cent and in 1936 is going to bo 24.2 per cent, while corresponding increases for industry for the samo years are respectively 20,7 and 23.0 per cent. At the end of the Second Five-Year Plan (1937) the gross production of agriculture will havo doubled compared with 1932. And it is known, I assume, that wo have the habit of fulfilling our figures, and sometimes of over-fulfilling them. This accelero-tion of the tempo of the development of agriculture creates a new basis for the acceleration of the growth of the whole national economy. The political expression of the internal social and economic changes in the USSR is represented by the draft of the new Constitution of the Soviet Union. This Constitution firmly anchors the state, cooperative and collective farm property as the economic foundation of the new social order, ^he Constitution guarantees full political equality of all stratas of our virtually classless society, The Constitution is also a further important stop towards the equal¬ ization of the cultural activities and material wealth of the numerous nations of the USSR, so numerous indeed that the USSR could be called a socioty of Nations in itself. We are very much satisfied by the considerable interest shown by membors of this Conference for our new Constitution. In our opinion our Constitution provides for the most consistent and complete democracy. Still, the question was raised as to the extent of guarantees of political rights and civil liberties as compo.rod to democracies of an older "typo. We would be quite prepared to go into this subject in every detail but, as one of the members of our delegation has pointed out today, this would load us to questions such as the compatibility of economic inequality and unfreedom with juridical equality and formal political freedom, and the mutual working out of these contradictory phenomena. If wo Would go into this argument this might bring us into regions dangerously bordering on what some people choose to call Communist propaganda. And as we have no intention whatsoever to evangelize or propagandize - we rather prefer understatement to overstatement. May I add just this, namely our firm belief that the progress of genuine democracy in our country is by itself encouraging for friends of peace and democracy in a world threatened by non-peaceful changes and social reaction. Allow me now to pass to the international aspect of the debate on topic Number Three (USSR). May I, first of all, express my gratification about the fact that distinguished Japanese delegates have extended their assistance to our efforts to make clear to all of our colleagues that there are no insoluble con¬ tradictions between Japan and the USSR and that widespread beliefs that a conflict is inevitable are erroneous, and that as far as there are pending questions be¬ tween the two countries, there is no impossibility to solve them in an entirely peaceful way - if the spirit will prevail which I saw in some of the speeches of the round table I attended today. There I could see that a correct estimation and a deserved recognition was given by statesmen of great European nations in their statements to the idea, of which my friend Romm reminded us yesterday. I mean the idea of the close inter-dependence of peace in all parts of the world, in particular of peace in different regions of Europe and Asia. This is the more important, as at the same time we heard another statement to the effect that not only at present but in the future as well it is unthinkable that Japan would

concluclc with Germany any aggrossive agreements or alliances directed against the USSR. If we aremember for a moment that Nazi Germany is the main aggressive force in present-day Europe, we will realize the importance of this statement* Is it possible to doubt the good faith and the good will of a distinguished Japanese statesman whose signature stands under the diplomatic document which created the basis of the normal relations between the USSR and Japan? But is it possible, on the other hand, to doubt also that, as Stalin pointed out recently (in his interview with Roy Howard), the enemies of peace work secretly# The fact that such aggressive coalitions do not correspond to the desires or the information of this or that friend of peace, unfortunately, does not prevent enemies of peace from going very far in their destructive, secret work, which tomorrow may become visible to all® As far as we are concerned, we consider that the sooner the friends of peace will become conscious of the reality of aggressive preparations already made and of some 1 cooperation1 already working - the better will it be for the cause of peace* In this debate, which confirmed to the Pacific Institute of the USSR the usefulness of such an exchange of opinions, in which we participate for the first time, more clarity was introduced also in the understanding of other aspects of the international policy of the Soviet Union. If in the process of this exchange of opinions the understanding has been strengthened of the nature of the principles of the foreign policy of the USSR, and in particular of the unshakable character of its principle of respect to the rights of other nations to independence, self-determination and equality of security, and if the understanding was strengthened that the economic growfch, and the development of democracy in the USSR, and - last but not least - the military- power of the USSR correspond to the interests of lasting peace - the Yosemito Conference, from our viewpoint, already in its first part, will have made its contribution to the cause of universal peace.

R0UN3 TABLE TOPIC III,AUGUST 22,1936 (Mrs. Barbara Wootton) Mr. Alexander, Ladies and Gentlemen* I know that I have your sympathy. I have calculated that this topic has been under discussion for six and three-quarters^hours, and^it would indeed be an insult to the concentration of meat in those discussions if I were to assume that they could be effectively summarised by anybody - much less by myself - in twenty or twenty-five minutes. I know therefore that all the rapporteurs in their turn will have your sympathy in the difficulties of their task. I have attempted to pick out four main topics which I think occupied the greater part of the attention of the round tables. The first and that which, judged by space, took least time was Mongolia. The second concerned special questions of interest primarily to Soviet-Japanese relations, ihe third covered those internal economic and political features of the Soviet Union which _ ;cicular. interest us in this conference. And the fourth was the groat and all important question, can we all exist happily in the same world with this new and strange economic system? I propose to say just a few words summarizing the content of other people*s arguments on these four topics. On the question of Mongolia we had some doubts expressed, from members of both the Chinese and the Japanese delegations as to the state of Soviet relations with that country. From a Soviet point of view the reply was given that the Soviets are interested only in technical and economic assistance to an undeveloped country, and that their aim in giving that assistance is only to promote the independence of Mongolia. Emphasis was made on the existence in Outer Mongolia of institutions which are regarded with abhorrence within the borders of the Soviet Union, such, for example, as the private ownership of herds and other property. Further doubts were expressed as to the situation on the Mongolian- Manchurian frontier. Some delegates thought that it was a little odd that, if both Mongolia and Manchuria were independent states, they should have to takie the assistance, each of a neighbor, in determining their respective boundaries. The members of the UcSR delegation disclaimed participation on behalf of the USSR in the settlement of that boundary but at the same time they laid emphasis upon the fact that there are certain situations which cannot be overlooked - at least by those "who are near enough to them. On the whole Mongolian question I suspect that many delegates, like myself, derived a great deal of enlightenment by the speech mo.de by one who is particularly well qualified to speak, We learned first of all that the position of Mongolia in relation to both China and Soviet Russia has a very much longer and more complicated history than we might have supposed^ and few of us will ever for¬ get the picture of the Mongolian sheep which feeds and clothes and houses and warms the Mongolian her '„sman. I think the only part that that sheep does not play in the economy of the Mongolian, is that of entertainment. It may be that it was only pressure of time which prevented that aspect of the matter from being developed also.

I turn now to the special questions of interest for Japanese - Soviet relations® They arc many® First, as to trade relations, one of the most hopeful things that came out of the round tables was -the optimism with which both Soviet and Japanese delegates spoke of the possibilities of Soviet-Japanese trade® As to the developments, particularly economic developments, in the Far East, the view expressed by the Japanese delegates that these might have a rather menacing appearance for Japan; and it was stated on behalf of the Soviet that it is the policy of -the Soviet government to establish distinct bases of defense in the eastern and western parts of the country® In reply to the Japanese, various assurances were giVen that nothing is intended by these armaments except security and defense and that (as so often is the case with armaments,) they were not direct¬ ed anywhere in particular® We did not carry the subject further because at this point it was perhaps beginning to canform to the pattern of a very old dis¬ cussion - that is the argument whether the hen biologically preceded the egg® Which armament first provoked which is a discussion parallel to the argument about the hen and the egg, but different in this, that whereas the hen and the egg are life giving, the armaments are life destroying® The questions relating to the proposed Soviet-Japanese non-aggression pact took a good deal of our time* The Soviet delegates expressed disappointment that the pact had not come to actuality® On behalf of Japan we learned that two obstacles had stood in the ways First, the fear of misunderstanding at home® In our rather strange world if two hold hands there is always danger of an implied assumption that they are proposing to arm themselves against a third party® The second difficulty related to certain outstanding questionsof dispute, notably those relating to boundary questions between the Soviet and Japan* From the Soviet point of view it was urged that if you have already agreed not to fight, that makes a better setting for the settlement of boundary and similar disputes© And as you have been reminded by the first speaker, there was common and pleasant recognition of the fact that steps arc now, we hope, effectively being taken to deal with the border question® Wo then passed to the possibility of a Japanese-Gorman alliance. Here we left the world of actuality, and .found ourselves moving amongst the philosophers when we ceased to discuss what is and embarked on a discussion of the non-existent* Upstairs and down, in each round table, we had statements from the Japanese delegates that they have no knowledge of any Japanese-Goman alliance. It was indeed said that the Japanese would welcome economic cooperation with Germany. (We are still hoping that we all welcome economic cooperation with everybody else. ) Members of the British delegation expressed the view that any such alliance, since it would not be part of a collective system, would be viewed with dismay in my own country, and similar opinions wore expressed by an American delegate® Comparison was made with the Franco-Soviet pact but great emphasis was laid on certain differences between that pact and a possible Gorman—Japanese alliance, notably in the two facts, first that the pact lies within the framework of the League, and second, that it was a regional agreement; whereas it would indeed require a considerable flight of the imagination to say that any Gorman- Japanese pact was of a regional character* It was I think a very happy feature of the conference that just at this stage, when those particularly difficult matters were under discussion, the pro¬ posal for a world economic conference was warmly supported by our friends from Japan.

Wo pass now to the general economic and political problems of the Soviet Union, I think that a certain disappointment was felt in some of the round tables that the conflict between the Communist theory was the planned state is immune both from satiation and from unemployment, and the non-Communist theory that those are ills and all flesh is heir to, was not fully treated® I regret very much the impossibility of treating it# A groat many volumes have been written on the sub¬ ject, and 1 know that the members of the conference would not wish me even to give a digest of the contents of those volumes. Very shortly, I take it that the basis of the Soviet claim is that since they control both their production and the incomes of their people, so as their production increases, they will arrange for the incomes of their people to rise in like measure# The contrary criticism from the non-Soviet world fastens particularly upon two things, first, that fluctuations of trade are prior to the capitalist system, and that until the contrary is proved, we must expect them to last even after that system has passed away; and second, that the Soviet need to export might, at certain times, be powerfully influenced by their demand for essential imports. Further the Soviet stands in a peculiar position in so far as that mystery of the economic text books, the cost of production, has no comparable meaning in their own country# That may have its advantages, at least to the Soviet Union for the common charge of dumping which is generally brought by any defeated compe¬ titor against Ms victors may be rebutted by the Soviet economists in so far as their whole conception of cost is different# If you have no cost in terms of capitalist calculation, you cannot be accused of selling below it# These, however, are rather academic and abstract matters, particularly, I think, in the eyes of those whose views on the topics tend to be of a more concrete and practical character and to be expressed in terms of say, lumber or wheat, arid I shall not be able to say more on this except just to remind you that the saying of Bernard Shaw is still true unhappily, "All the economists in the world, if they were put end to end, would not reach a conclusion," Some of us perhaps still hope that the stature of the Soviet economists would be great enough to bridge the gap. Passing to the political questions, those .X think I may deal with very shortly, for Mr, Rowell and Dr, Motylev both touched upon them# Much interest was shown in the new constitution of the Soviet Union, and questions were asked and answered, particularly in relation to the rights of free speoch, free association, of voting and of religious freedom# The chief thing that appeared to me to emerge from those discussion was this: that these freedoms must be regarded both in their verbal context in the constitution itself, and in their historical setting. More than that I hardly like to say, particularly when speaking in the U,S,A# in the presence of many American citizens and distinguished American lawyers - for the interpretation of constitutions is an art in which no Briton will compete with an American public# Finally I come to the problems of the coexistence of Soviet and capital¬ istic systems in the same world# Here, apart from the economic differences upon which I have touched, the major issue would appear to be that which has been described as the question of the 1exportability of Communism#*

My first advice to those who are considering whether Communism is an exportable article would be to look into their own hearts and to study their ex¬ perience during the past week# They will there, according to their own experience, find an answer# All, I think, were agreed that Communism has this in common with other articles in the export trade - economists would include it in the invisible exports •• it has this in common with other articles, that it cannot be sold where there is no demand# Its appearance upon the markets of the world was widely noted, but we were reminded by our friends from the Soviet Union that in that country - tlx; words are mine, but I hope I express their thought accurately if in different form - we were reminded that in their country foreign trade is a state monopoly and that the article Communism, however it may appear upon the markets of the world, is not included in the exports of the Soviet foreign trade monopoly. I don't think that we wont further into the question whether there should be an inquiry into smuggling from the Soviet UnionJ Those, ladies and gentlemen, appear to me to be some at any rate of the outstanding lessons which, I as one of the receptive members, learned from attend¬ ance at the round tables® One last note I would like to strike -which might be perhaps a little Core personal. I have tried to observe the objectivity of the character associated with that of rapporteur# I doubt if I havo succeeded but I have tried, and I ask you to lot me say one last thing in my own capacity. The significant feature of all these discussions was, I felt, the atmosphere of willingness to cooperate. I was at Geneva in 1927 at the World Economic Conference and at that time represen¬ tatives of the Soviet Union were participating for the first tijne in a conference of -that type. How much our attitude has changed since then; How different is the tone of our criticism! While criticism remains, on all sides the atmosphere in our round tables, from East and West, was one of willingness to lead toward mutual understanding and cooperation. As I put these thoughts together this afternoon in my cabin 1 heard sounds which made me think for a moment that war had broken out both upon the Atlantic and upon the Pacific# I refer to the contests that were talcing place on cach side on the baseball field# But I was mistaken. How different was the atmosphere in¬ doors from that which prevailed out of doors! And one fact of the discussion in¬ doors was continually in my mind. All of us who are collected hero are representa¬ tives of nations signatories of a pact which has renounced war as an instrument of policy. Sometimes as I listened to our discussion on strategy and related matters I thought that a little reflection on that fact might put our discussions into a due proportion, and I am sure that what took place in our Soviet round tables was a very real and sincere attempt to take our peaceful obligations seriously.
