essay:div.essay:p: Secretariat 1936 Document ol STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION OH CHINA i Round Table Topic IV, August 24, 1936 (T. A. Bisson) In the round tables of last week, some of you may have noticed that whenever the discussion approached North China and smuggling, the barometer pointed toward storm. As I understand it, the chairman - no doubt with the kindest intention in the world - has merely asked me to take up these and rolatod political issues, and expatiate on them at some length. Under the circumstances, I can only take my courage in both hands and deal with the offer in the spirit with which it was tendered. If I speak frankly and unreservedly, I trust that the impartiality with which I shall attempt to aim my shafts will help to mitigate whatever offense may be unintentionally given. Perhaps on no other subject under consideration will complete frankness tend more to con¬ tribute to an understanding of differing points of view, and so facilitate the possibilities of mutual adjustment. Before embarking on a consideration of the military-political phases of Japanese expansion in China, it is necessary to make clear that foreign expan¬ sion in China is not merely a thing of today - it has a history. I am more inclined to stress this point because at one of the previous round tables, mem¬ bers of my delegation advanced the claim, if I understood them correctly, that there is something in the American system which makes it fundamentally incompat* ible with imperialism. Now we Americans are inclined to pride ourselves on the fact that in our relations with China we have exhibited a marked hesitancy in infringing upon the territorial integrity of that country. But if we stop at that point, it is my belief that only half the story - perhaps the less impor¬ tant half - is told. It is necessary to point out that only two years after the signing of the Anglo-Chinese Treaty of Nanking in 1842—the first of the modern "unequal treaties"--the United States had hastened to conclude a similar treaty with China, conferring similar rights and privileges on American nation¬ als. The insistence of the American government at this time upon the most- favored-nation principle was an important factor in enmeshing China in a net¬ work of treaty relationships which eventually generalized privileges infringing ChinaTs sovereignty to all the treaty powers. For our purposes, it is not necessary to enter into details on this issue. The data paper prepared by Mr. H. D. Fond of the Chinese delegation supplies the requisite information. Suffice it to say that under these and later treaties, including the Boxer protocols, American nationals enjoyed the advantages of the statutory 5% tariff (in actual practice often well under 5%) for some 60 years, and that at present American nationals are represented in the Shanghai Municipal Council, the governing body of the International Settlement, American nationals enjoy extra¬ territorial status, American merchant ships ply China's inland and costal waters, and American troops and gunboats arc still stationed in China. So much at least must be said to keep the record clear on certain points of historical and contemporary significance. Similar rights, it should be added, are enjoyed by certain European powers and by Japan. But when we come to the present situation, I think that the facts support the drawing of a sharp distinction between Japan and the other treaty powers. Since 1922, these other powers have displayed a marked reluctance to extend their political, a s distinguished from their economic, rights in China. In some oases, notably in the matter of the rendition of certain concessions and the Weihaiwi leasehold, there has even been a retreat from political privileges acquired in the past. On the part of Japan, on the other hand, I venture to

submit that there has seldom been witnessed either recently or in the past such a long-continued, persistent and large-scale infringement of China's territorial and administrative integrity as has taken place since September 18, 1931. Japanese military-political expansion during this period maybe divided, for purposes of summary, into five phases# At this date, it is not necessary to describe the process by which in 1931-1952 the establishment of Manchukuo was carried through—you will observe that I do not speak of the conquest of Man¬ churia. Nor is it necessary to enter upon a description of the Shanghai hostil¬ ities of 1932. The second phase began with the Japanese military occupation of Jehol province in March 1933. This drive was soon extended into north China, ending temporarily with the Tangku Truce, signed on May 31, 1933. By this truce a considerable section of northern Hopei province, from the Great Wall to a line drawn inland some miles north of Tientsin and Peiping, was "demilitarized, " i.e. Chinese troops were withdrawn. Under its terms, also, the invading Japan¬ ese troops wore to be withdrawn from the "demilitarized" area which was to be policed by a Chinese constabulary force. This truce constitutes the starting- point of the situation which has since developed in North China, and is there¬ fore, still closely tied in with current events in that region. It is to be hoped that one issue of fact, in connection with this truce, may be clarified in the course of round-table discussions. The Japanese affirm, and the Chinese deny, that the Nanking government made a number of concessions on May 31, 1933 which were not included in the published terms of the Tangku Truce. In this connection, I may refer to the Japanese data paper prepared by Mr. Ozaki, which states on p. 6 that "such achievements in 1934 as the restoration of through traffic on the Peiping-Mukden Railway (July 1st), establishment of customs stations along the Great Wall (June 3rd), and resumption of postal communications between Manchukuo and China (January 1, 1935)" were "terms of settlement of the Truce." No such terms were included in the text as published. Since Japan¬ ese political and military leaders have repeatedly justified activities in North China oil the ground of rights conferred by alleged secret terns of the Tangku Truce, it would be a distinct contribution if this subject could be cleared up in the discussions. The third phase occurred in May and Juno of 1935. Based mainly on ex¬ pressed dissatisfaction with conditions in the demilitarized area, Japanese mili¬ tary leaders presented a scries of demands to the north China authorities. These demands were backed up by airplane flights over Peiping and Japanese troop con¬ centrations. A memorandum containing those demands dispatched by Lieut.-General Yoshijiro Umezu, commander of the Japanese forces in North China, to General Ho Ying-ching, War Minister at Nanking and then acting head of the Peiping Military Council, was eventually accepted, and has since been generally referred to as the Ho-Umezu agreement. Under its terms, among other things, the Second and Twenty- fifth Divisions were withdrawn, thus denuding North China of all regular Nanking government troops; the governor of Hopei province, Yu Hsueh-Chung, and his Fifty- first Army was withdrawn; Kuomintang party organs in Hopei Province were suppressed; certain Peiping and Tientsin officials were removed; and anti-Japanese activities were prohibited. Simultaneously, as a result of the so-called "Changpei incident", essentially similar changes were effected in Chahar province. The fourth major phase occurred in November and December 1935. Since this so- called "autonomy" movement is fresh in our minds, it is only necessary to note that two new political regimes arose in North China as the outcome. On November 24 the so-called "autonomous" regime of Yin Ju-keng was set up in the area "de¬ militarized" by the Tangku Truce. On December 18, the Hopei-Chahar Political Council, headed by General Sung Cheh-yuan, was formally inaugurated at Peiping. Since this latter Council is subject to strong Japanese influence, yet ho.s not severed its ties with Nanking, it may bo conveniently termed "semi-autonomous,"

in tho sense to which wo have rocontly become accustomod to the use of the word "autonomy•" The larger five-province "autonomy" scheme of the then Major-General Doihara, which was also to include Shantung, Shansi, and. suiyuan, did not mater¬ ialize# Our summary of this subject will conclude with the smuggling issue, as it has developed this spring# The economic phases of this subject are treated in data papers, and will no doubt be brought up by members of the Chinese delegation. I wish merely to comment on one issue. I understand that in one of last week's round tables" an attempt was made to dissociate the Japanese army from smuggling. Let me recapitulate. Japanese troops invading North China force the establishment of a "demilitarized" area. The proper functioning of the Chinese police force in this area is prevented. Threat of military force enables Yin Ju-kong's regime to be established in this area. Japanese goods begin to flow through this area into China without customs dues or with nominal levies accruing to Yin Ju-kong's regime. Supported by Japanese military and naval forces, this regime disarms Chinese cus¬ toms officers on land or drives them out, and prevents chinose revenue cutters from operating in waters north of Tientsin. In the light of these facts, I confess that I still seem to trace some connection between the Japanese army and smuggling. The broader implications of this military-political expansion are by far tho most important, inevitably the question arises in our minds: "Where is this to end?" Since 1931 the Japanese first line of defense has become -what might be termed a "moving" phenomenon. First, it was the three northeastern provinces; these required Jchol and "the Great Wall, which in turn required northern Hopei and Eastern Chahar. As we take part in discussions noro, wo learn that the Manchukuo commander, Li Sliou-hsin, is advancing into suiyuan and fighting with tho Chinese forces there under Fu Tso-yi. From certain Japanese pronouncements, and from the three-point program elaborated by Mr. Horota, we gather the impression that the objective of this expansion is complete Japanese political control of China# If this be true what we are witnessing is a menace to the continued independent ex¬ istence of the Chinese nation# Under those circumstances, I should judge that the course of the discussions would at some point turn to the methods by which the Nanking government is meeting this fundamental issue# Tho problem of if, when and how effective Chinese resis¬ tance is to develop is present in the minds of all of us. Its urgency is reinfor¬ ced to all those who, like myself, believe that a lasting poace in the Far East hinges 011 the development of a strong and united China# On this issue, I should like to ontor certain reservations as to the policies adopted by Nanking. In the light of Japan's continuing military expansion in China, and of tho total absoncc rf a functioning collective security system in the Pacific, it is necossary to judge Nanking's"policies from tho standpoint of whether they adequately safeguard tho Chinese nation. I hope, as do all of you, that discussions in round tabic five will contribute toward finding a Sino-Japanese settlement through progress toward a collective security which will rule out the necessity of armed Chinese resistance. For the time being, howovo.r, that ultimate resort cannot be overlooked. In approaching this issue, lest seme of my remarks be misconstrued,^I wish to make it quite clear at the outset that I do not sharo tho pessimistic views com¬ monly entertained in .rospect of China's immediate or more distant future. I do not believe thot the groat arid cultured Chinese people, with 2,500 years of re¬ corded history behind them, will be overwhelmed. On the contrary, I feel that if tho attempt is made to press current Japanese policy to its extreme limit, the result is likely to prove a boomerang. At the same time, in order to f'aco the current Chinese sceno realistically, we must candidly examine certain aspects which arc loss reassuri.ng than others. At this point I am quite consciously adopting a negative attitude, more especially bocauso the documentation and the contribution of the Chinese delegation supply the positive side. My Chinese colleague at this

session, whose closc and accurate knowledge of the Chinese political scene I can¬ not pretend to equal, is at hand to set no straight on points whore I go astray. The non-resistance policy faithfully adhered to by the Nanking government since September 1931 has, in my opinion, had certain unfortunate consequcncos. The whole of Manchuria was lost virtually without a struggle, and the ease with which Manchukuo was established invited excursions further afield. Demonstration of the possibilities of real resistance was left to the Nineteenth Route Army at Shanghai, quite inadequately supported by the Central government. The anti-Japanese campaign of Generals Feng Yu-hsiang and Fang Chen-wu in the summer of 1933, which succeeded in capturing Doloner, was eventually crushed as much by Nanking's intervention as by Japanese forces. Other items might bo added to this list. To those criticisms, the natural reply is that there were two prerequisites to effective resistance: greater internal unity, and a period of preparation in view of the relative disparity in military strength. And it must be admitted that this reply has undoubted force, particularly in view of the recent consolidation of Nanking's internal position, if we except only the continued existence in strength of the Chinese Communist movement. Nevertheless, the reply loads to a consideration of several additional factors. Resistance at this late date encounters the handi¬ cap imposed by the loss of Manchuria and much of North China. Even more important, the exigencies of a long-continued policy of non-resistance have had unfortunate effects in the relations of the Nanking government with the Chinese people on the issue of the national emergency. I refer to three factors: the suppression of the boycott after the Shanghai armistice by government intervention; the muzzling of the Chinese press; and the suppression of tho student movement and its outgrowth— the national salvation associations established in many centers of China. On February 20 of this yoar, it should be observed, the Nanking government issued an emergency law which empowered Chinese troops and police to use "force or other effective means" in suppressing meetings, parades and propaganda activities" which aim to violate peace and order." Since tho issuance of this law, as also pre¬ viously, demonstrations calling for resistance to Japan have been broken up and hundreds of students have been jailed. This policy raises the question as to whe¬ ther military preparation resides solely in actions taken by government at the top, or whether the morale of the people is not an equally important consideration. One further point, perh£C£>s the most basic of all, as to tho nature of the in¬ ternal unity which is being fostered by Nanking, ^he admirable British data paper on the reconstruction movement in China contributed by Mr. George E. Taylor lays particular stress on the point that the policies formulated by Nanking have been in the main carried through by and in the interests of the Chinese bankers, industrial¬ ists, and landlords. Allied to this, he points out, is tho fact that political and military control at Nanking is today contered in the hands of one man, and we may note that the new Constitution scheduled for adoption in November vests powers in ' the hands of the President that can only be termed dictatorial. More than this, he emphasized that the dictatorship which today functions at Nanking has taken on cer¬ tain aspects ince 1933 which tend more and more to resemble phenomena associated with Germany and Italy. In this respect, he does not refer so much to the abrogation of civil liberties, strict control of labor unions, or the drastic anti-Communist measures, all of which have been normal features of the dictatorship at Nanking since 1927. More alarming is such an agency of government as the "Blue Shirts", a secret terrorist organization which has stifled liberal and left-wing opposition, suppressed labor strikes and unrest, and removed dangerous political opponents. Similarly, it is to be notod that labor conscription is sanctioned by Article 22 of the new draft constitution. Never wholly absent in China, labor conscription has of late years been applied under government auspices on a national scale, ox~ pecially in road-building and dike-construction projects. It is elements such as these present in the Nanking regime which lead me to maintain certain reservations with regard to the character of the internal unity which it has been forging, and

with regard to the future effects of such a unity on China and its people» After these distressing and delicate issues, I turn finally without any p, re at sense of relief to the subject - shall I call it the non-controversial subject - of Communism in China. For reasons of brevity, I have chosen to pre¬ sent this issue in its positive aspects. Al.sojj I understand that the delegation from China represented at this Conference certainly cannot be accused of being wedded to the Communist doctrine. It may be, therefore, that I shall make some contribution by playing the role of the devil's advocate on this issue. In the first place, I should like to clear up one misconception. It is sometimes claimed that the Chinese Communist movement is something about which no certain information is known, and that therefore it is impossible to reach any conclusions about it which have a basis of fact. T0 refute this claim, I need only point to the lengthy bibliography on this subject which has been printed in the current issue of~Pacific Affairs. To those with the will to investigate, much may be discovered about it. I shallbricfly touch upon three issues: the basic program of the Chinese Com¬ munist movement and its application in practice, the reaction to it rxiong certain sections of the Chinese people, and its present program and policy. The basic pro¬ gram and its application may be best studied in southern Kiangsi and '.'o stern Fukion provinces, whore a relatively large and stable Communist base was maintained for six years, from 1928 to 1934. In this area, the following policies among others were carried into effect: a land redistribution favoring the poorer peasants and abolishing the great landlord estates, substitution of cooperative credit societies for the private usurer, enforcement of collective agreements for minimum wages and hours in local industrial enterprises, a graded taxation system bearing mainly on wealthier elements, elimination of the growing of opium, a" literacy program for adults and youth, and founding of a military academy and university at the capital, Juichin; and the involvement of the mass of the people, including women, in poli¬ tical life through active participation in a hierarchy of organs which reached from the local village Soviet to the center at Juichin. It may be argued with justice that this is not a socialist, much less a Communist, system, but the skill which the Chinese Communist leaders adapted their policies to the limited material basis at hand must nevertheless evoke a certain admiration. That thoir program, limited though it was, did involve a powerful thrust at the feudal interests of the Chinese countryside is attested'by the virulence with which they were subjected to attack from the Nanking regime. This fact also bears witness to the possibility that under more favorable conditions their program right be extended much further toward a socialist goal. On the second point, it should be noted that the military achievements of this regime started from a point not much above zero in 1927-28, when the Communist forces numbered but a few thousand. Yet in 1955-1934, Nanking and the allied provincial authorities were forced to put into the field something like half a million men well furnished v*rith modern military equipment including airplanes to meet the Communist armies. In ihe end, Nanking only dislodged those forces from Kiangsi, it did not crush them. This fact evokes two comments. First, the Communist program must have corresponded to the needs of the local population. Secondly, it must have aroused their enthusiastic support and assistance, or this amazing military strength could never have been developed on such a poor and limited territory, both as to resources and standards of life* Theso comments are justified by the strict precautions taken by Nanking in the later phases of the campaign to insulate its troops against contact with the Communist populations. That this sympathy exists in wide sections of China is also supported by the evidences of peasant assistance afforded the Com¬ munist army after November 1934, when it marched safely across half-a-dozen provin¬ ces to Szechuan in the far west 0 The same phenomenon occurred in the North this

spring, when part of the Communist army entered Shan si province. The peasantry- accorded them support, and even the provincial armed forces were considered shaky# It was absolutely necessary for six divisions of Nanking troops to enter Shansi, in order to drive back the Communist onslaught. Finally, as to current Chinese Communist policy. To meet what it considers an overwhelming national emergency, the Chinese Communist party during the past year has materially revised both its internal and external policies* Internally, its pressure on small landlords, richer peasants and merchants is being relaxed, providing only that they supply convincing evidence of support to the program of resistance to Japan. The core of its political program calls for a united national defence government and a united anti-Japanese army. Details of this now program are included in the manifesto of August 31, 1935, issued by the Chinese Soviet Government and the C. P. of China. The May Fifth Proposal of this year, referred to at the conclusion of Mr. Reizo Otsuka's interesting data paper, carried the pro¬ posals of last year even further. The Chinese Communist Party now makes the follow¬ ing proposals directly to the Military Affairs Committee on the Nanking government, of°which Chinag Kai-shek is chairman: "Immediately cause the cessation of civil war, hold a peace conference, and form a united front against the activities of Japan in China." An interesting statement as to its foreign policy was made by Soviet China1s Foreign Commissar in March of this year. In answer to an interviewer1s question, ho do dared: "Our foreign policy is based on the principle of the freedom and independence of China and the safeguarding of the interests of the Chinese ' people....The chief enemy confronting us is Japanese imperialism, and the countries which preserve a benevolent neutrality toward our struggle against Japan are our friends, and we are ready to maintain frio rv.ly diplomatic relations with them based on equality. Our country is still backward economically, hence we must cooperate with those which are economically advancod. Therefore, the ^ovict government is prepared to conclude economic agreements, basoci on equality, with all countries which are friendly to us. The annulment of the unequal treaties is, however, one of the• post important foreign political tasks of the Chinese Soviet government. With the exception of Japan, this can be accomplished through diplomatic negotiations." In view of the evident expediency of this policy, we may assume that it is sincerely put forward# In conclusion, may I reaffirm the hope that the last round table will threw further light on these vexed issues that cast 'the shadow of war across the Pacific, and offer some means of escape from the dilemma which they present. May I also reaffirm the confidence which I have already expressed in China's ability to copc with its difficult problems. We all join this morning in paying tribute to the rich cultural heritage of China which is increasingly becoming the common heritage of mankind, and we welcome in advance the contribution which this groat people still has to offer to our common future.

Secretariat 1936 Document STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON CHINA - ROUND TABLE TOPIC IV August 24, 1936 (Dr. Eu Shih) RECONSTRUCTION IN CHINA Our British Colleague, Mr• G. E. ^ubbard has defined Chinese Reconstruction as "the evolutionary process which is taking place in economic, social and cultural spheres of China," The Chinese torn for this movement simply means "construction" or building up. It is reconstruction in the sense that what is being built up is actually remaking and reshaping the surface of an old country and the life of an ancient nation# Broadly speaking, Chinese Reconstruction has three phases - 1# the building up of a physical basis of national unity, 2* the improvement of the physical well-being of the people, and 3# the remolding of our cultural life for a better adjustment in the new world. All progresses in the field of transportation the railways- the highways, and the air lines - come under the first category of providing the nation with a physical basis for political unity# The sense of national unity, which now extends from Manchuli to Yunnanfu, from Kalgan to Canton^ from Shanghai to Tibet, is largely one of racial, cultural and ..historical unity. There has been lacking a material or physical basis to strengthen this historico-cultural unity and bind the various distant parts of the country more closely together. Chinese leaders early recognized the urgent needs of modern means of transportation and communicationj but unfortunately, ever since the outbreak of the World War in 1914 when foreign capital ceased to come to China on any large scale, China has made very little progress in railway building. It is only within the last few years that the Government has taken up the railway projects with now vigor and has succeeded in ex¬ tending old lines and constructing new ones. The Lung-hai Railway is now extended beyond Si-an; the Shanghai-Hangchow-Ningpo Railway is being connected by the construction of the Bridge across the. Chientang River; and the Canton-Hankow Railway is now completed and will be open to^ through traffic this month. Of the newly planned lines, the Hangchow-^anchang Railway which connects the Yangtze Delta with the capital of Kiangsi and the Hwai-nan Railway which connects the Hv/ai River with the Yangtze, are the most important ones that have already boen completed. For the first time, we are having trunk lines running from Canton to Peking and thence to the ■ Northwest, and from the oastern coast westward into the heart of interior China. In the development-of provincial and inter-provincial highways, even greater progress has been made. The first modern roads wore started in 1920—1921 as a relief measure during the famine of those years. After the establishment of the Nanking Government in 1927, road-building was under¬ taken with nation-wide enthusiasm. From the 1,185 kilometres of modern roads, the total length has increased to nearly 100,000 kilometres in 1935. In some of the provinces, notably Kiangsi and Kwangsi, the provincial trunk roads roach every hsien with local roads connecting all the important towns within the province. Again for the first time wo are now able to motor

iu from Shanghai to anchang and Changsha and thonco to Canton* Commercial aviation has helped to connect the noro distant ccntcrs which have not yet been linked up by transports on land. One can now fly from Shanghai to Chengtu, a distance of about 1,300 miles, in seven hours; and from Peking to Chengtu, via Chengchow in Honan and Si-an in Shensi, in ten hours# Beginning with last month, one can breakfast in Peking, fly to Shanghai to keep a luncheon engagement, and return to the old Capital for his supper at home - a distance which usually takes 80 hours for the return trip. All this improvement in transportation is building up a new physical basis for a modern national state. When the Hwai-nan Railway was being built early last year, there waa a great famine in northern Anhui and there was no means for transporting the food stuff from the more plenteous regions, Tho starving population requested the railway engineers to make temporary pro¬ vision for grain transportation bofore it was ready for passenger traffic. The request was complied with, and tho population was saved from starvation. It was the improvement in roads which greatly aided the Government troops in their final campaign against the Hod Array in Kiangsi in 1934. And it was also the modernized roads which enabled the Government to suppress the armed Rebellion in f'ukien in loss than two months. The railways and highways are accelerating tho process of economic arid political unification. Under the second main category - the betterment of the livelihood <__of the people - may bo grouped all those processes of rural rehabilitation, water control, formation of cooperatives, reforms in taxation and improve¬ ment of public health. I shall not attempt to summarize the able treatment of rural economic reconstruction by my friend Dr. Franklin Ho in his data paper, in which he has given a very comprehensive picture of all the phases mentioned above with the only omission of the item of public health. His omission of the recent progress in public health work was probably due to the fact that this work was started in the metropolitan centers, and is only beginning to reach the rural regions through the establishment of Health Centers in the interior provinces. The task of rural economic reconstruction in a vast country like China is a gigantic one, and the recent achievements in its various phases can hardly be said to have more than a mere humble beginning. Irrigation schemes in Shensi and tho Northwest are now watering millions of mou of farming fields, and the repairing of dikes and dredging of rivers along the Yangtse River are lessening tho dangers of possible recurrences of catastrophic floods such as those of 1931# But these and other similar works barely scratch the surface of the gigantic problem of water control and famine prevention in a country which has the reputation of a Land of Famines and which has to face the tremendous task of irrigating a vast hinterland where annual rainfall is often below 20 inches. It is true that we now have made some progress in crop improvement, agricultural research and education, and the cooperative movement. But the progress already achieved appears so infinitesimally small when compared to the magnitude of the problems involved. What, for instance, is one million members in 26,000 cooperatives in a population of 450 millions? It is also true that, in the realm of reforms in taxation, the provincial and municipal governments have in the last two years abolished 5,200 items of exorbitant and unjust taxes and surcharges. But these are merely insignificant relief measures compared with the untouched fundamental

problem of land tenure in a country -where 85 per cent of the population is congested on about 17 per cent of the land, and where the boldest stretch of imagination has so far failed to find a formula for an equitable dis¬ tribution of land which will give the agricultural population a minimum level of decent living. Under the third category may be grouped all the reforms and pro- grosses in the field of education and culture in general. Statistics show that, compared with the first year of the Republic (1912), the number of primary school students has in 1931 increasod four times; that of secondary schools, 8 times; and that of university and college students, 100 times# Beginning with last year, the Ministry of Education is endeavoring to carry out a Five-year ^lan of Compulsory Education by which it aims to give every child of school ago at least one year of free and compulsory education* A second Five-year Plan is to begin in 1940 when the Government hopes to lengthen the period of compulsory education to two years. The success of the first year has given us reason to hope that this very moderate program can be successfully carried out. Of the many educational and cultural changes that arc taking place in China today, I wish to point out a few, the significance of which cannot be easily shown by statistics. One of these is the language problem. In the last twenty years China has successfully solved this problem in two ways. On one hand, the problem of a common language for the whole nation is solved by the recognition of one most universally spoken dialect as the ^ational Language which has since 1921 been used in all primary and secondary schools in the place of the dead classical language. The dialects will srij. [ per¬ sist, as they all persist in all countries. But the unification in language is achieved v/hon all products of the public schools will be able tc talk and write and understand one another in the National Language, The second phase of the language problem is the creation of a literature in the living national language, ^t is no use to toach the people a language which the best writers and poets refuse to use as their literary medium. The success of the so-called literary renaissance in China lies in the fact that all young writers have accepted this living language of tho people as their medium of prose and poetic composition, and are producing a living literature, the intrinsic worth of which is beginning to be appreciated by the most con¬ servative elements of the older generation. Another important phase of this "evolutionary process" is tho social evolution which is going on in every aspect of Chinese life. It has been pointed out by some recent observers of Chinese events that thore is much reactionary tendency in the social and cultural movements in China as is evidenced by the revival of the worship of Confucius and by the frequent exaltation of Confucian virtues in the "Now Life Movement" sponsored by im¬ portant leaders of the Government. As a die-hard advocate of liberalism and modernization, I must confess that such a reactionary tendency does exist and has a following chiefly among party workers and office-seekers. And the explanation is clccir# China is now in the midst of her nationalistic develop¬ ment, and all nationalistic movements easily lead to an apologetic attitude toward the indigenous civilization of the pact. Moreover, there is no doubt that the reactionary movements in certain quarters of Europe and Asia have had their influence, direct or indirect, over some of the political leaders in China. The tomb and temple of Confucius, for example, were ordered by the Chinese Government to bo repaired and the worship of Confucius was re¬ vived as a state rite, when China learned that our neighbors in Japan had

completed ci now Temple of Confucius at tho cost of more than two million |yun, and wore wending out invitations to Chinese scholars ^o attend the ceremony of unveiling 1 Such reactionism abroad has greatly strengthened our re¬ actionary movements at honcj with the result that there is really much vogue for such slogans as "an authoritarian or totalistic state" and "the revival of our glorious past." But I must confcss that such reactionary tendencies are merely passing moods which do not appeal to the imagination and thinking of the younger generation® The social and cultural movements oi tho last twenty years have boon on the whole unmistakably in tho direction of liberalism ana. democracy, and I am fully inclined to believe that China may yet be one of the last strongholds of liberalism in the world, I have thus far presented to you a general summary of the main features of what has been broadly characterized as Chinese Reconstruccion. The whole movement can be best described as an "evolutionary process parts of which have had their early beginnings two or throe decades ago. This evolutionary process, however, was for a time paralleled and almost inter¬ rupted by a revolutionary movement best represented by tho Communist Movement which had its origin in the formation of the Chinese Communist Party fifteen yoars ago. The history of the Communist Movement in China is the best illus¬ tration of the doctrine expounded the other day by our Soviet Russian col¬ league that Russian Communism is not exportable. Tho early prog,rem oi the Chinese Communist Party which included the 8-hour working day_, vb.j protection of child and woman laborers, tho enforcement of a unified graded com of taxation and the distribution of land to the tillers of the so.'. {. vjos quite moderate and differed very little from the social and poi programs of Dr. Sun Yat-sen. This similarity made it possible for Dr. party to join hand with the Chinese Communist Party for a few years during which the new enthusiasm and discipline of the younger party and the advices ana the organizing ability of the Russian advisors contributed very much to the success of the Nationalist Revolution of 1925-27. When the split finally came in 1927, it was quite clear that, whatever might be the declared dif¬ ference, the really fundamental incompatibility between the parties was one of procedure; it was evolutionary versus revolutionary methods. The Kuomin- tang was too much inclined toward compromiseing with tho moderate elements of the cities and was at least unconsciously unwilling to risk its political power in an ooen warfare with the foreign powers which they,in thoii acquired terminology, called the Imperialist Powers. The young Communists were im¬ patient and wanted an immediate revolution which should bo a social and economic revolution, a class war, and a part of tho i/Torld Revolution des¬ tined to bring about the final overthrow of the capitalistic system. Their impatience led them to all forms of excesses which cost them very much in the loss of sympathy throughout the country. Moreover, the Kuomintang, being rather narrowly nationalistic, was conservative and apologetic for tho old culture of China for which the internationalist Communist had not the least regard. It was these fundamental differences in procedure, in tempo and attitude, which finally led to the tragic split in 1927. After the split, the Chinese Communists, supported by those armies which had been more deeply influenced by their ideas and which later formed the nucleus of the Red Army, have set up an armed opposition to the banking Government and more than once threatened the political stability of the latter. After the successful campaign of the government forces in 1934, they were forced to leave their stronghold in Kiangsi and their remnant forcos moved towards tho southwestern provinces where they were further defeated and scattered.

Judging from their published, appeals for "a United Front" against a common enemy, it is clear that they too have learned from experience the failure of their impatient and revolutionary methods, and arc now putting forward a much more moderate program of mild democratic socialism, "Whether the armed threat of an external enemy will finally bring about the reconciliation and cooperation of the Chinese Communists with the ational Government or not, time alone will tell. But the lesson from this historical episode seems clear. It is that, in the light of history and national teuperament, China, if allowed to pursue hor own course of development, will in all prob¬ ability follow the path of gradual evolution rather than that of violent revolution,' I now come to the question, Yfhat are the international implications of China*s program of reconstruction? The reconstruction work in all its phases has largely boon carried out by Chinese personnel and financed by Chinese money. But, of course, there arc international implications which may be summed up in these words: from the U,S,A, we get the training of the Chinese personnel; from the League of Nations, the technical advice of experts; from Great Britain, an important portion of the money; and from Japan, all the obstruction. Since the return of the first portion of the Boxer Indemnity to China in 1908 for the purpose of educating Chinese youths in American universities, the U,S,A, for 27 years has been educating Chinese students in scientific technique, technological training and administrative ability. It is these men who form the nucleus of that vast personnel which is planning, loading, directing and executing the- multifarious activities of Chinese reconstruction. The League of ^ations has been very helpful to China in furnishing her with a large number of technical exports whose advicc and assistance have been fcund most useful in the planning of transportation, public health, water control, and rural reform. Of these advisers, mention must bo made of Sir John Hope Simpson whoso great contribution to the relief work during the great floods of the Yangtso region in 1931 will suroly be long remembered in China, The League has recently decided to undertake the training of Chinese technicians by allowing them to be attached to the appropriate sections of the League Secretariat, There has been c omparativoly very little financial aid from the outside in this reconstruction work except the American v/heat and cotton loan which made possible the initial formation of the National Economic Council as the central organ for the direction and planning of many of the projects of reconstruction, and the railway loan from the British banks for the con¬ struction of the Chiontang River Bridge, But mention must be made of the part played by the British portion of the Boxer Indemnity in the financing of the reconstruction projects. This fund, which had accumulated from the end of 1922 and was returned to China in 1928, has been used in the financing of productive activities,and the Chinese Government guarantees to pay an annual interest of 5 per cent, which interest is again spent on the educational and cultural activities in China, About 7 million pound sterling has been thus used in this reconstructive work. The greatest obstruction to Chinese reconstruction work has come from Japan, from whom wo had a right to expect sympathetic understanding and friendly assistance. This obstruction has come in at least three main directions.

In "fcho first place, the "whole sorios of events from the sudden invasion and occupation of Manchuria in 1951, and the Shanghai War in 1932, dovm to the invasion of Jehol and the war along the Great Wall in 1933, created a war situation which made it absolutely impossible for the government to pay attention to any constructive work# The invasion of Manchuria took placo at a time when China was faced with the unprecedented catastrophe of the Yangtso floods which affectod 25 million people in 131 hsiens in five provinces, and which resulted in a total material loss of two billion • The Shanghai War which lasted a little more than a month, caused untold losses in human lives and destruction of property and paralyzed the Yangtso delta for many months during which the Government found it difficult to pay the school teachers and governmental employees* For two whole years, the wholo nation could not settle dovm to do any constructive work. It was not until after the failure of the ^ytton Report and the -^eague of Nations and after the Wars along the Groat Wall that China came to a fuller realization of the significance of the new situation. She now realized that all the peaco machineries of the Pacific region had boon torn to shreds by the armed fist of an aggressive power, and that she had now only herself to rely upon for her own national salvation# China, as it were, was aroused from the slumbers of a false sense of international security# It was not until then that China finally settled down to work on her own program of internal recon¬ struction# But what a change in the meaning and content of the program I A sense of the imminent danger of national perdition has gripped the whole people,and National Defense has become the generally accepted necessary guiding principle in every thing we undertake# Even the students of the universities and schools arc demanding of their teachers that their educa¬ tional curriculum be reorganized in order that they may be better prepared to meet the needs of what they call the "extraordinary times i" In the second place, Japan has not only interrupted the peaceful reconstruction work in China, but also openly told the whole world that she does not allow any other nation or nations to render to China any assistance in her reconstruction. In the famous Amau Statement of April 17, 1934, Japan warned the wholo world that, because of her "position and mission" and "special responsibilities in East Asia," she could not tolerate any joint operations in respect to China "undertaken by foreign powers, even in the name of technical or financial assistance#" In the same Statement, Japan threatened that, in case of her warning being unheeded, whe might be forced to "act alone on her own responsibility#" Indeed, this threat she has tried to carry out more than once# Last November, China promulgated hor new cur¬ rency reform lav/ which was accepted by all Chinese Banks, and which had the full cooperation of the English and other foreign banks# But Japan, in her anger against China for not having previously informed her, and in her suspicion of British participation and cooperation in the reform schome, began to stir up serious troubles in North China, which, it is commonly be¬ lieved, wore intended not merely to weaken the authority of the Chinese Government in China, but also to punish the British through the punishing of the Chinese# Lastly, Japan seems to have determined not to tolerate any government that may have a chanco to unify and consolidate Chine.# At least her militar¬ ists have nevor concealed such intentions# Throughout the whole summer of 1935, Japanese military officers of high rank both in North and South China repeatedly issued statements to the effect that Japan would not deal with the ^anking government as long as General Chiang Kai-shek remained as its powerful leader# In an equally famous Tada Statement of September, 1935,

the Japanese military leader in North China declared that the Empire of Japan could not co-exist with Chiang Kai-shek and his party. "Shall the Empire surrender to them? or shall they be crushed "by the Empire?" These and other similar declarations have convinced us that our neighbor is fully determined to oppose any government that shows any capability of achieving political unity in China, Such a re the international implications of Chinese reconstruction# Shall China abandon all her activities of political, economic and social reconstruction and prepare to die stalemate? No, a thousand times No I Me are determined to go on with cur work of putting our own house to order, of solving our own urgent problems, and, if necessary, of fighting for our own existence#

Secretariat 1936 Document 37 STATEMENT FOR SPECIAL PLENARY SESSION CONCERNING SINO-JAPANESE RELATIONS August 25, 1936 (Kenkichi Yoshizawa) It has been suggested that I make a brief statement in order to clarify Japan1s position before further round table discussions of China's economic re¬ construction take place. Sino-Japanese friendly relations have a long, historical background, in part due to geographical propinquity and racial affinities. However, since the early years of the Mciji era (beginning 1868), because of intimate relations between the two countries, there have been both agreeable and disagreeable circumstances. Referring to more recent events, we find that unfortunately there have occurred situations which have produced strained conditions. Personally, I deeply regret this situation. I have come to YoSemite with the purpose of ameliorating if possible these unfortunate differences and, further, in the hope that I may contribute toward the re-establishment of our historical, friendly relationship. The Japanese policy toward China should be to maintain friendly relations with her and to promote the smooth progress and prosperity of that great country. This policy has been followed on the whole ever since the conclusion of the first Commercial Treaty in the early part of the Mciji Era. Unfortunately, however, China was torn by civil wars up to 1928 when the country was unified by the Kuo- mintang. When Manchuria, under Chang Hsuoh-Liang, united with the Nanking govern¬ ment, the unification of China was effected. However, this unification proved to be transitory and again China faced inter-necine struggles and presented the same situation as under the old, military warlords, With the downfall of General Chen of Canton, some two months ago, there was effected a union between C&nton and Nan¬ king. Thus, it is plain that it was not Japan who obstructed the unification and reconstruction of China, but it was rather the internecine struggles which in real¬ ity constituted the fundamental obstacle. "Fifteen years ago, at the suggestion of the United States, a conference was convoked at Washington, to which interested nations came, and Japan joined with them to promote the peace and prosperity of China. To substantiate this statement, I may*mention the signing of the Nine Power Treaty and the various concessions made to China to ameliorate her tariff situation, as well as the restoration of Shantung to China. "Soon after the Washington Conference, a tariff conference was convoked in Peiping and Japan led in the movement to restore tariff autonomy to China. But due to internal disturbances, this restoration had not been carried out until 1929, when it was actually effected. In spite of Japan's friendly attitude, China im¬ mediately raised her tariffs, which raise has most adversely affected Japan's trade with China. And this action not only damaged Japan's interests, but also adversely affected the well-being of the common people of China, because these Japanese goods net the ovoifday nco ds of the masses, "In addition, ^hina has again and again violated her treaty obligations towards Japans For instance, in spite of the Protocol of December 22, 1905, pro¬ hibiting Chinese construction of railways parallel to the South Manchuria rail¬ way, and in spite of repeated protests by the Japanese Government against this action on the part of China, the latter actually did construct such railways.

"Our attitude of conciliation at that time towards China, instead of meeting with a reciprocal attitude on the part of the latter, met rather with a policy of greater and continued violence on the part of the Chinese. This led to the Manchurian incident of September 18, 1951. "The anti-Japanese movement in China proper, namely: South, Central, and North China, continued unabated and even increased to an intolerable extent. Consequently, Japanese lives and property, shipping and commerce, suffered tremendously. Ve in Japan, have thousands of Chinese residents. The friendly attitude of the Japanese people is abundantly explained by the fact that the Chinese residents liv¬ ing in Japan have never been molested in any way when anti-Japanese movements of the worst type have been going en in China. "As I see the situation in retrospect, 1 do not feel that everything Japan did in the past was right, but I am equally convinced that what China did was not always correct. Therefore, the differences and ill-feeling which exist at the present between the two countries can only be remedied by the assumption of a more conciliatory attitude on both sides for a considerable period of time. Unfortunately, in such international convocations as the Peace Conference in Paris and the Tfashington Conference, we have been made a subject for vituperation, I feel that the best way to bring about the desired harmonious relations is for China to change this attitude and to cooperate with Japan, Yfhile I have spoken candidly in order to make my position clear, I had no in¬ tention to make any of my remarks deliberately offensive to my Chinese colleagues and their well-wishers. My solo conviction is that the only way to attain peace and stability in that country is for all of us courageously to face the stark realities.

Secretariat 1936 Document 26 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON CHINESE RECONSTRUCTION, AUGUST 25, 1936 (Dr. P,C. Chang) Mr. Chairman, Ladies and Gentlemen: We have just spent two days in discussing the phenomenon and certain im¬ plications of the reconstruction movement in China that has attracted inter¬ national attention in recent years. It is but natural that only a few phases have been touched upon during the limit of time. I think at the conclusion of this discussion it may be well for us to turn our attention to a little wider view of the whole movement. The word reconstruction itself requires some modification, "what is after all taking place in China today Is what we might say is the more intensive ex¬ pression, more articulate expression of a larger movement of Chinese adjustment in the modern world, that, due to size, to hugeness of the population, to long drawn conditions, has been slower than many of us wished, but it is a fact that the slowness of that development has necessitated fundamental questioning, and we hope as a result of the fundamental questioning tho final result, or rather the final way may be more satisfactory, more stable, more fittingly modern than the way of adjustment that can be described as ill-digested and only bringing temporary advantage. However, that last sentence requires some explanation, What aro somo of the fundamental questions that hove been raised? Why is it that people in China today aro still discussing such problems as whether China is going through a period of complcto Westernization or whether China should still keep certain of tho traditional ways of doing things. That is still considered a problem in Chinese discussion. It may strike you as being a little theoretical and yet it seems to be necessary. Why is it so and how is it so? After tho period of the conception of conflict there is the conception that either Chinese traditional ways will remain or western ways must be adopted. After the period of conflict, comes the period of compromise, the compromise may be stated in such words, that is, to take on what is good from other cultures and to keep what is good in your own. That is usually taken to bo the liberal view - to take on what is good from other cultures and to keep what is good in your own. But nevertheless that still leaves two questions to bo answered: What is good? How to determine tho good? And secondly, what is the nature of the procoss of taking on and keeping in the field of cultural activities, I mil, may I, repeat those two questions. I think they arc fundamental. (l) What is the good? How to determine tho good? (2) What is tho nature of the process of taking on or keeping tho activities in the cultural field? We may then follow that discussion a little further and sec what thoughts are going through the Chinese mind, for after all, in these various expressions of activities in road building, in political organization, in educational adjustment in those various things, we are simply following out certain of tho hesitancies as

woll as certain of the gropings of the adjustment to this modern world, looking from a "broad point of view, Now, how to determine the good? One man nay say you need a bath-tub; another man may say you need certain ways of doing things. Certain terminology I think when applied to the Chinese case always requires a new definition. Using words that are common in general western parlance, we have to be extremely careful when applied to words in the Chinese case. Is the Chinese situation simply a process of westernization, what is usually called - total westernization?
