You may find occasionally in China as elsewhere a certain trend of opinion that takes pride in the old things as a sort of inferiority complex, as a sort of assertion of something within themselves as a matter of hurt pride, so to speak, but nevertheless the general trend has gone far beyond that narrow point of view, that protective conservatism. Protective conservatism is unworthy and I am happy to say the majority of the people in China who think have given that up. The next question, what is the nature of the process that China is going through? Is it a process of westernization? So often we use that term. If we push that a little further wo will find there are difficulties in that conception. In other words, what do you mean by westernization? '"'hat do you moan by the west? Historically there have been many xvests and geographically I am sure today we find many wests. Shall wo westernize according to the fascist model or communist model? 1'hey are all western products. If you call it western, which period of western history shall we copy most? Some people have suggested the word "modernization." They tell us that about 150 years ago China was not far behind the rest of the countries of the world in material things. One hundred or 150 years ago the Chinese economic condition, although differently organized, nevertheless could supply certain comforts that were rather surprising, to say the least. They were as comfortable in China - even more so - than in Europe 200 years ago; the various utensils used 200 years ago; the various utensils Europeans used 200 years ago. Two hundred years ago Chinese civilization as a whole did not particularly emphasize what wo might call today spiritualistic oast. '-'Ie have always paid attention to the material things of life. I have no time now to mention those things. As a matter of fact if you read some of the early reports of the Jesuit missionaries you will find that Semi do, a Portuguese priest, went to China and re¬ ported things in China wore more comfortable - better clothes, better houses, and oven the prisons v<rere more comfortable. In other words, comparing tho material phases of life two hundred years ago, China was not far behind. The Chinese wore able to live fairly comfortably. Of course today if you go to China you will say they are barbarians be¬ cause they haven't bath-tubs. Marco Polo was surprised at the way tho Chinese took baths. Isn't that curious? Baths arc quite a modern i lea and the daily bath that is considered to be good manners is still proverbial, I am afraid. Thus to people who see that historical perspective - 200 years ago China was not far behind the rest of tho world in material things - what China needs is simply to modernize. But after all that concept is not satisfactory because you cannot understand the modern world without its historical background, without its Greek heritage and Hebrew traditions of onoTs self being right and nobor^ else right. That sort of tradition, the Hebraic, GodTs chosen people and that sort of thing, ordinarily has contributed to modern nationalism.

Now you can't understand the modern world without the "background* Con¬ sequently China to modernize will have to understand certain things of Greek times, We are trying to establish a system of modern law. How can we without Roman law? A modern system of scientific investigation. How can we without the Greek dialectic? Historically there have been many wests and today geographically there have beqn many wests. Then what is the process that China is going through? It is not westernization nor modernization, I think that is the most important thing behind it all, I hope we will raise our heads about this presentation of the present period and see the transition of one-fifth of the modern race - what effect it is going to have on that amount of people and what that amount of people will finally produce and how that will affect the world, What is the nature of the process? After all what is required in China is a different kind of adjustment and I hope that this point will be made clear, thct our slowness, its own difficulties, has brought sufferings to usj that I hope the sufferings will result in a deeper questioning so that when the adjustment comes it will be more final and not the ill-digested type of adjustment. It will be more fittingly modern and stable, VJhat does that mean? It moans that we will have to face the situation more critically than we have done and people have ever done, Iiow will we make that adjustment to the modern world. It is not exclusively modern. It is not narrowly a westernization. Then what is it? That is the key to the situation, I think we can see evidences in China today especially, and getting seme of those evidences before us, we may be able to extract from those evidences cer¬ tain tendencies, I will formulate those tendencies in three phrases - the tend¬ encies that may characterize this Chinese way of adjustment to the modern world - this is not yet absolutely recognized but many of you will see tendencies through all the hesitancies, through call the maladjustment - tendencies of ways of doing t hing s, The first phrase we might say is a sensitive recognition of concrete dissatisfactions - sensitive recognition of the fringe of concrete dissatisfactions. By that is meant not simply vague things - fantastic things. For the first gener¬ ation of our adjustment; wo might soy the conception was rather vague but now I think it is becoming more concrete. Looking at the dissatisfactions as they arc you find the university professors talking in that woyj you will find the students are all going into the problems. Concrete dissatisfactions - what they are, not only as a whole but also the fringe. What do I mean by the fringe? That narrow lino, that wavering line -where the situation as it is gives that sense of the broken fringo of dis¬ satisfaction, The mind must be keen enough to have that sensitive recognition of the fringe of concrete dissatisfaction* You find the Chinese today, especially in the last three or four years, dissatisfied with anybody talking in big words, "What are you driving at? How can we get at it? I seem to discern the development in this delegation - challenging the people who use big terras and asking, "Do you sensitively rocognize the fringe of that dissatisfaction?"

(2) We might say an extensive survey for stimulation and suggestion - not exclusively from any system; not exclusively from any geographical tradition; not exclusively from any definite part in history^ either Chinese or western, but an extensive survey for order, for stimulation and suggestion in facing the present. And it is in that direction that Chinese are now, I think, understanding the modern world a little better than the generation before us, I think we are gradually seeing things as to how they have come into being. We are gradually learning your history and reinterpreting our own history; (3) What I might call a liberated inventiveness. That implies whatever suggestion you may see in formulated ways of doing things in other parts of the world or other times in history you must see them in terras of their own condition¬ ing circumstances. Thereby you acquire an inventiveness. You must pardon me for hurrying because my time is limited and a- subject like this should be discussed in more leisurely mood. Summing up: (l) A sensitiveness of the fringe of the dissatisfaction, not only with the conditions but also dissatisfaction in western terms; among the thinkers in China today a dissatisfaction with the conditions and trying to as¬ certain the broken edges of dissatisfactions; and (2) An extensive survey. Some of the students who have never been abroad now surprise me. I feel my generation who have had the privilege of travelling abroad are gradually losing our prestige, I think those of us who have taught in China understand the modern world better than those who have spent five or six years abroad. A student of mine writes Chinese, English, French, German and Russiai In other words, there are people in the younger generation who are able to see things in a more concrete wtty than my generation, probably the first that wont abroad in an extensive manner. Up to the end of the 19th century the Chinese were stupid enough to believe they were self-sufficient. It is only with the turning of the century that the Chinese went abroad to study. Only after thirty years certain minds have been produced in China who can see things more clearly than those of us who have wasted time and money abroad. There Is this tendency in China of finding out the details of the situ¬ ation in a much more concrete manner. I do see a tendency in this direction, no longer using words for the sense of general satisfaction calling a man a petty bourgeois and saying ho is no good. That is gradually lessening and getting more concrete. So this adjustment of China to the modern world, looked at broadly, is one of the most significant things in the world today and we hope that out of this will come a stable adjustment,a digested adjustment, a fittingly modern ad¬ justment of China to the modern world, and we hope that certain things may come forth that may serve as humble suggestions to the rest of the world as well. Now we turn to the present. Evidently the essential temper that is easily noticeable to recent visitors in China is a realization of the need of integration of notional effort. That integration is implied in the desire for what we might call self-direction and national independence. To find a way out in our own manner. We think that we may be pardoned for asserting thct we may perhaps be allowed a little self-direction. That integration is applied in the self-direction and national independence as the first and foremost consideration,

le-wing social policies to bo adjusted as occasions arise, That has already been commented upon. One may wonder, in hearing the discussions of the last two days' round tables why so much time has boon spent on the question of Japan in relation to China,s reconstruction. Curious, isn't it? Obviously China's reconstruction is a Chinese problem, and the fact that so much attention has been given to relation¬ ship of the different activities of Japan to china's reconstruction is a reflection that those activities are, justly or unjustly, taken not only by Chinese but by the whole world as having had some direct adverse effcct on Chinese reconstruction. We must make it dear not only to our Japanese friends but to the world at large that we admire what our neighbors have dono in the last half century despite certain serious problems awaiting solution. Those efforts have been heroic, We sincerely admire than. Please take that as really sincere, Lay I soy wo have a great deal to learn from them. The traditional friendship of the two people in Eastern Asia is a fundamental fact that cannot be denied, But the difficulties in the way must somehow be removed and we still hope that somehow such difficulties will bo removed in a peaceful way, Trte have hoard it stated that our neighbors have always had a good will toward us. We appreciate that expression but somehow it seems to leave the im¬ pression - to state it frankly - that the present misunderstanding has been duo to either Chinese stupidity or ^hinesc ingratitude. Yet occasionally we find state¬ ments emanating from Japanese sources, and those statements have given the Chinese occasion to suspect - not necessarily justified, at least occasion to suspect that the ways to bring about that good will are rather difficult to understand. May I be pardoned for reading you a short paragraph from a sto.toment issued on September 1, 1935 by General Tada, the Commander of the Japanese Military Garrison in Tiontsi: This statement was denied later but nevertheless was made by a Japanese officor, so porhaps it may be very interesting. The statement is called "The Fun amental Concept of Japanese Policy Toward China," I am sure many of my Japanese friends deny the authenticity of that state¬ ment. Copies were distributed to the educational institutions in Peking and Tients: by the Japanese Garrison, At first we didn't dare to open the pamphlets and finally we opened them and found beautifully printed copies of the statement. And we road this - from Cho.ptor 3, Section 6: "To take advantage of the greediness and lack of loyalty of the Chinese militarists and to induce them to offer us special privileges in order to facilitate our economic development or to supply such militarists with money and munitions in order to buy their services; Such is the old formula of our policy, and must be regarded as against the principle of openness which should characterize the Empire's policy. For instance, in North China the Empire's garrison has already acquired in fact the power of direct control and there is no more necessity of making uso of Chinese militarists," That is a very interesting statement. It may be denied but it was officially issued. However, it is not my iesirc to leave you with this point of contention. Old scores must be forgotten if we want to find a now trail toward pea.ee. Lot bygones be bygones, 'When things cannot be explained, I think it is advisable not to try to explain them. Facts must be faced and among them is the firm and growing confidence of the Chinese people already alluded to to solve their own problems on the basis of self—direction and self—reliance. This is not a, denial of assistance; neither should this be used by anyone as a claim for monopolistic control in China,

Secretariat 1936 Document 25 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION ON CHINESE RECONSTRUCTION, AUGUST 25, 1936. (Lord Snell) We have now reached a point in the work of this Congress when we pass from detailed plans and acts of special governments to general principles and outlooks to try to discover how these separate acts will react upon the world at large. In our searching discussions there has been no scapegoat; no nation has escaped being questioned; none has evaded an answer. The United States, Japan, Russia, China have all been separately examined and even my own inexperienced and guileless country has not been forgotten in our inquiries. What then up to date have we achieved? World peace? No, But we have wished to achieve it, which is the first fruitful step in that direction. Have we achieved knowledge and understanding of each other? To some extent we have, above all else, been able to look the other fellow in the face and to call him friend. Now, in this concluding speech tonight I want to be as brief as possible for during the last ten days such an avalanche of words has fallen in this Valley such as these ancient walls have never heard before, I think I understand now the wisdom of that school boy in my own native land who said that in America they put their criminals to death by elocution, and also in my own country, especially at this time of night, the kind of oratory wo like best is finished oratory. But we have to try to understand what yet remains for us to do, I believe that we have in essentials a three-fold task. The first is: How to encourage and advise Japan in the peaceful expansion which she desires and which we wish that she should have - how this alert, this valiant little nation can fulfill her own destiny without so injuring the process of the world as to create disaster. For her the immediate position is this: that If the other nations were to erect Impassable barriers against her the Japanese people would starve, and Japan quite rightly has no intention that they should starve. Our second problem is how in a rapidly changing world wo can prevent China from becoming broken China- how wo can assist this old distressed land to reorganize her own life and to restore something of her old glories. Those of us who belong to the western modern nations owe her a great deal. Those of us who were privileged in London this year to witness her wonderful exhibition of art could do no more than enter into a kind of silent homage for all that she stood for - the serenity and power and restfulness that seemed so refreshing to this troubled world. And today we know that she has difficult troubles. There is another debt we owe her, 1 understand that it was she who invented coinage. In that respect I have a personal grievance against her that she didn't invent enough of it in those sections of life that I know best. But today we see l\er developing her energies; coordinating her great strength, determined to defend and develop at all costs her own cultural and intellectual values.

And thirdly, wo have to try to decide how the western world can face this now impact upon its life. The difficulty is that the eastern nations entered into the western industrial system at a dangerously low lovely a level that wo had long left behind us, a level that if it were successful, would reduce our general standards. Now, as the economists know from the Gresham law of coinage, if two coins arc in circulation in one area, one a "bad coin and the other a good one, the bad one will tend to drive the good coin out of circulation* When a lower standard of life compotes with a higher one, the tendency is for the low standard to make headway and for the higher standard to become submerged. Some authorities hold that that was the reason why Rome declined; that invasions of peoples with lower standards reduced her standards until she became weak and incapable. That is our position in the west. We shall defend our standards of life because we must de¬ fend them, but that is not incompatible with the possibilities of cooperation with the eastern nations and the development of higher standards for their own. people. Over-production that we so often hear about is just a capitalistic myth. There is no such thing. The wants of the world are insatiable. If we can break down, the barriers which prevent the free flow of goods and services the delusion of over-production can be put to one side. It is to find a solution to these problems that the remainder of our conference must be devoted. That is first of all the problem of raw materials. I believe the whole of my delegation believes that there can bo no permanent Jsoaco in the world that is not based upon social justice and some measure of equality or equity between one people and another. We are asked in our agenda for tomorrow to consider the question of collective security in the Pacific,, "fell, that is the problem of the whole world, and it is no more difficult in the Pacific area than anywhere else, but it is so important that wo should find a way to collective security that it is becoming a race between common sanity and disaster. We are asked whether such machinery as is necessary should be organized under the League of Nations or under special regional pacts. I don't mind which - eithor or both, if it will give us peace, that will be abiding in our time. When I go to church I don't mind who plays the organ if I like the tune that is being played. But I personally believe that the best way is the League of Nations. We have the League. It is with us. And one hair on the head is worth two in the brush© You know I always adnirod that Church of England clergyman who preached a sermon upholding the doctrines of his church and when he'was questioned by an American visitor - the ijincrican visitor said to him: "Say, do you really mean to say that there is no other way to Heaven except through the Church of England?" And the parson said, "Well, it is possible there may be another way but no gentle¬ man would ever think of taking advantage of it®" There may be other ways than the League of Nations. I dare not continue. But lot me say this, that in life we build upon experience. To uproot is to destroy, but to graft on to the old trunk is to give now and fruitful life. Now the problem of the 20th century as I sec it Is just this: how the different races of men may live upon the earth in peace and in harmony. And that is the problem to which we are devoting our attention in these wonderful lays of our experience. Wo are facing the problem with an earnest desire to solve it and the

price of succcss is nothing less than tho salvation of mankind. Tiliat we dosiro will not be achieved by arguments or by polite dissembling® Vie have to ask each other definite questions and try to get the real problem firmly in our minds. The old way has been tried throughout history and has failed. "Some therefore cried one, some another and the more part knew not wherefore they were called together, but all cried, groat is Diana of the Ephesians." We have cried peace when there was no peace but we have not cried dismay before the task which confronts us. Wo knew the importance; v<re know the magnitude; but we take courage in our belief that we can solve it. Let us look at one aspect of the problem which confronts us. There is no sense in hiding the fact that the world is drifting towards a new irrationalism. We are governed by mass phobias which are encouraged and preached as policies of national regeneration and tho new humanism. The new intellectualism has to face a new barbarism 'which may be more destructive than any that the world has known. The metaphysicians and tho physicists, such as our distinguished colleague, Professor Millikan, assure us that the past is past and the Almighty himself can not alter the past. But what God cannot do the politically minded historian and the war fostering politician both can and does day by day. Wo have the doctorod press; we have the tainted sermon; we have the poisoned broadcast and the warped education, end the world considers not its own limitations but devlops a disease of national and racial self-adoration. The power complex is increasingly fostered in us and we are taught to hold in contempt the lesser breeds without the law, which includes all those who do not belong to the best clubs. More and more we are becoming alike. Our minds arc being cut to a pattern which is too often a pattern desired by a government or a class or a special interest. I want diversity and unity through diversity. The attraction of a picture gallery does not consist in its uniformity but its variety. Rubens differs from Rembrandt, and Michael Angelo from Raphael, and that is what entrances us. The flowers and the trees differ in color and size and texture but all are necessary to make up the landscape and the beauty of the earth on which wo dwell. And so I believe that every race has its own special contribution to make to the v/orld whi ch the world cannot do without. A nation shuts itself within its walls by tariff barriers and yet it can¬ not be isolated. Emerson told us we are piqued with pride of pure descent but nature loves innoculation. And so in this groat problem we are considering 1 want, to repeat, unity through diversity. Let each nation bring its gifts to the common pool. Didn't Robert Bridges give us that thought: "Each to the world's right market brings Its bright, divine imaginings In rival tribute to surprise The world with native merchandize." And so I believe we shall have to return to our old gods, not our new ones; to democracy rather than dictatorship. I know how slow progress is under democracy and how depressing the speed sometimes is. I believe that if Moses had had to consult a committee before he went across the Rod Sea ho would have been overtaken by Pharoah's hosts and exterminated. I have never known a committee that was any good except wheal I was the only member of it. But that is the price we pay for democracy. It is the one gospel and social mechanism which

transforms o. population into a people. It is the only system under which you can¬ not loaf -without personal dishonesty. Now I must not detain you further except to express my belief that there is a "better way than war and that we shall find it. You will forgive me if I refer to my own. country again - just a little loyal patriotism in passing - but in the old days in London the old craft guilds, as you have known them, were always quarrelling - fighting against each other, and the two most irreconcilable companies were the ancient company of the master tailors and the skinners, and they were brought to trial and the Lord Mayor of that period - Lord Mayor Billesden on the 10th of April, 1484 - I hope I have got the date right - passed a judgment and he condemned them that each yjar the master tailors were to invite the master company of skinners to their ^ity Hall and give them the best dinner they could, and he also condemned the other side to invite their opponents in the same way and once a year for 452 years these old enemies meet together in one of the wonderful ^ity Halls and dine together. Now it is a part of my duty in London to attend those ceremonies and I assure you that the dinner is thoroughly worth while going to. And so I think there is a bettor way, I think we shall find it, I am not one of those who dispair because I think I see that the prophets of woo of the past have been wrong, "It is a gloomy moment in history. Not for many years ~ not in the lifetime of most men who read this paper - has there boon sn much grave end deep apprehension; never has the future seemed so incalculable as at this time. In our own country there is universal commercial prostration and panic, and thousands of our poorest fellow-citizens are turned out against the approaching winter without employment and without the prospect of it. In France the political caldron seethes and bubbles with uncertainty; Russia hangs, as usual, like a cloud, dark and silent, upon the .horizon of Europe; while all the energies, resources and influences of the British Empire are sorely tried, and are yet to be tried more sorely, in coping with the vast and deadly Indian insurrection, and with its disturbed relations in China," That inspired message appeared in Harpersfs YJcokly on the 10th day of October 1857 - 79 years ago, after which Anerica had one of the most wonderful periods of prosperity that any country ever saw. But she wasnft alono in that. My own country had its similar profits, ^ilberforce in the 19th century said: "I dare not marry, the future is so dark and unsettled," The Duke of Wellington in 1851 thanked God he would be espared from seeing the consummation of ruin that was gathering around him; and Lord Shaftesbury in 1868 declared nothing could save the British Empire from shipwreck. It didn,t happen, and so today I am one of those who Is going to keep his faith. Dead walls are constantly being broken down and every day new tools are being invented to our use.

Isaiah, at the very zenith of his power said: "Tho Lord has givon unto us a new thrashing instrument vdth teeth," and to us arc given these wonderful tools that we are without the moral responsibility to use, Tho scientist gives us some great new product of his brain and all wo do is to take it up in an aeroplane and rain ho11 upon innocent citizens. But there is hope in this direction, with which I will conclude, I believe in a process of cross fertilization between one nation and another, You know the apple which through Adam and Eve brought all this trouble into tho world was a crab apple which after you ate the wisest thing to do was to sit under a tree and sing "Wearer My God to Thee," An the rest of those beautiful things we oat now are man-produced and in some small way California is tho home of cross fertilization, Burbank has produced through his genius now forms of enjoyment for our palatos, Isn't it just possible that there is a law of cultural cross fertilization? Do we aot owe part of our civilization to the social and cultural heredity which comcs to us through many nations? Rome was tho daughter of Greece and all have learned from each. In a day or two we shall separate and our minds will be richer through this cross fertilization that has taken place among us. Vfe have tried to make our contribution to the greatest problem of our time. Lot us carry tho spirit of these gatherings to our own separate lands and try to interpret it to our own people. Then if we succeed in preserving the peace our labors will have been blessed indeed but if our efforts fail and the nations are again at war, there will nevertheless be peace in us.

Secretariat 1936 Document 15 REPORT OF THIS GENERAL RAPPORTEUR ON ROUND TABLE TOPIC IV CHINA Ladies and Gentlemen: Vie spent last week in the consideration of the policies of the United States, the U.S,S#R#J and Japan as they hear on the international relations of the Pacific Area. While we devoted a good deal of time to the domestic situations in those countries out of which their foreign policies arise and to the general, world-wide effects of those policies, our thoughts were never far from the re¬ lations of these policies to the situation in China, We began our discussions of China, itself, therefore, with a good deal of thought engendered in the previou round tables and with the conspicuous advantage of having had some time to scrutin ize the very valuable documents prepared on this subject by our councils in China, Japan and the United Kingdom. It was accordingly possible for us to concentrate into six hours of discussion an extraordinary amount of comment directly pertinent to our agenda and it was possible to progress steadily towards a general consensus of opinion which furnishes an admirable starting point for the construction of our final topic, "The Changing Balance of Forces in the Pacific and the Possibil¬ ities of Peaceful Change." I shall report our discussions under the three headings of our agenda, but before doing this I should like to mention the characteristics of these dis¬ cussions which most impressed me and which may serve to focus my ensuing remark:*?. First, I was impressed by the extraordinary record of reconstruction in China to which all observers, from no matter what nation, testified. This reconstruction is progressing along all lines, economic, social and political and follows or inheres in, as one Chinese member put it, a conspicuous change in the mental attitude of the Chinese masses towards the institution of government itself and towards innovations. But this reconstruction is conditioned or obstructed by two factors, one, dissatisfaction from considerable sections of the Chinese popu¬ lation -with the capitalist or bourgeois aspects of the reconstruction methods and auspices, the other, the disrupting influence of Japanese aggression. My second impression was the conspicuous absence of hostile statements regarding the present program of the Chinese Communist movement from our Chinese members and the very fair and objective way in which they described its history and program. This left me with the thought that the way might still be open for complete Chinese unity including the Communists either in an emergency national defence government or in a constitutional democracy following the adoption of a constitution this coming fall. The third impression is one which must have struck all of you forcibly, namely, the determination of China to take care of herself and to preserve her entity as a great nation vis-a-vis Japanese aggression.

To turn now to the formal part of my report, I shall first take up item I on the agenda, "Chinese Reconstructiont Aims and Achievements," Here we begin by a consideration of the physical reconstruction which it was generally agreed was the prerequisite of political unity. Our data papers contained such full in¬ formation on this question that in our meetings we did not undertake any rounded recapitulation of the reconstruction program. We did, however, lay emphasis on the vast increase in trunk highways which are rapidly shortening the distances among all the provinces of China and we noted that the length of these highways had increased phenomenally in the last few years - from 1,000 kilometres in 1921 to 100,000 kilometres in 1936, The great value of this program was generally ap¬ preciated by all members of the Conference and the question relating to it had to do with relatively minor points. The Chinese were asked if it were not true that the highways were primarily for military purposes and to the farmer of small economic value if not indeed an economic hardship because the farmers had to build the roads themselves under a system of forced labor. The reply was that these points were partly true, but i/fiat there were extenuating circumstances: the lack cf capital made resort to forced labor a necessity; the military nature of the roads was a temporary feature required by the circumstances. Mention was made of the other features of the reconstruction program in the fields of finance, railways, agriculture and land holding, public health, and in social and cultural measures. In regard to the entire reconstruction pro¬ gram an American member asked who were the principal beneficaries, the bankers and industrialists or the farmers. A Chinese member replied that the answer de¬ pended on tho point of view taken, whether judgr.iont was based on the concrete facts of the moment or on the historical relation of what was being done now to what was done in the past. The Chinese situation can bo observed from the longer view of unification first and then development of the larger social measures second, or it can be looked at from the point of view of the common people. From the long view progress on behalf of the common people is more apparent than from the short view. To illustrate this point the Chinese member said that the new cooperatives organized by the modern banks loaned money to farmers at 12 to 15% whereas the old interest charges were much more exorbitant, in other words that while the modern practice was not above criticism, it showed marked progress over the old. It should of course bo noted, and the ^hinese were the first to admit this, that in comparison to the needs of the country the whole reconstruction program was still inadequate. Much emphasis was put on China1s need of foreign capital to finance her reconstruction program, the Chinese and foreign members being agreed on this point. Three difficulties in the way of securing such capital were pointed out, the least important of which because of its probable temporary character being the unwilling¬ ness of American and British bankers during recent years to send money to China. Statements were made at the round tables that this situation might soon be remedied. The second difficulty was the terms on which China was willing to borrow, terms which a number of the foreigners questioned as possibly providing unsatisfactory security but to which tho Chinese strenuously clung because of their previous dis¬ astrous experience with political and foreign-supervised loans from the imperialist powers and because of what the Chinese pointed out as being a remarkable improve¬ ment in the integrity and efficiency of their own government. These terras are;

"(l) that 61% of the capital share shall be owned by the Chineso; (2) that a majority of the directors shall bo Chinesej (3) that the chairman of the board of directors and the manager shall bo Chinese; (4) that in any °ino—foreign under¬ taking the foreign investors shall have the responsibility of technical planning and the provision for machinery and equipment; (5) that ^ino-forcign undertakings shall conform to the laws of the Chinese Republic and shall not call into assist¬ ance the extraterritorial rights and privileges in their defense; (6) that in the purchase of materials preference shall be given to those of Chinese make; and (7) that a Chinese staff, which shall have the preference of employment, shall be given appropriate powers in management, and that foreign staff shall bo employed only when no Chinese staff shall be available*" The third obstacle to China's obtaining foreign capital, and much the most important, was the attitude of the Japanese government as expressed in the famous Amau declaration. As the elaboration of this point came in the discussion of Sino-Japanese relations I shall now do no more than thus mention the item. So much, and it is too little, for the first heading in our agenda. Aiming to "The Communist Movement in China" our second heading, there was con¬ siderable discussion of the differences between Nanking's program of reconstruction and that offered by the Communists. With respect to internal economic and social questions a direct comparison was sought in Kiangsi Province occupied by the government when it was ovacuated by the Communists in 1934 after almost six years of administrative control. It was pointed out that the Communist regime had brought about rural reforms in dispossessing large landowners and redistributing the land among the peasantry, creating cooperatives in place of the old usurious money-lenders and unorganized forms of production and marketing, establishing a more adeciuate educational system, and greatly improving trie position of women. Upon taking ovor the province, the government had given back the land to tho land¬ lords except that a limit of 100 mow or about 17~o~ acres was placed on an individual holding and the surplus land turned over to cooperatives. While the government thus partially preserved certain reforms or introduced new ones, the discussions clearly indicated that the Nanking policy of rural rehabilitation is frankly a capitalist one as contrasted to a Communist one. A comparison on the basis of Kiangsi Province, however, is already out of date, for as a Chinese member pointed out, in the right of a changing scene the Chinese Communists have modified their program. They have given up the con¬ fiscation of land, they have abandoned the policy of confiscating foreign property except that belonging to Japanese, arid they have signified their desire to co¬ operate fully with other political groups within China in a united effort against Japanese imperialism. A more fruitful basis for comparing the program of Nanking and the Communists seemed to lie in their respective foreign policies. On this point it was indicated that if the Communist program be taken at face value it differed from Nanking's only in being openly and aggressively anti-Japanese, but it was also suggested that this similarity might be only a superficial one in that the fundamental Communist position was over a long period irreconcilable with Nanking's capitalist tendencies. On the actual strength and significance of the Communist movement there were marked differences of opinion expressed, one Chinese expressing the view that they were no longer an important internal factor, and a foreigner the view that they wore stronger today than at any time since 1927. One Chinese member gave his views on the subject at length and width with great clarity. He felt that if viewed as an organized political movement the Communists had been broken late in 1934 on. the evacuation of Kiangsi and Fukien and were now not an important

political force. But if viewed as the exponents of a plan of economic organization the Communists' influence today was widespread throughout the countryside. He added that lately a now factor had been introduced into the situation which had significantly strengthened the Communist position, namely, Japanese aggression which the Communists had effectively made their solo immodixte enemy. An .American member expressed tho opinion that Chinese Communism in tho last three years had changed its manifestations in adapting its program to Chinese conditions and to Japanese imperialism. He felt there was no indication that tho movement was spent. On the contrary, he believed the Chinese masses wore becoming increasingly aware of the fact that their bourgeois leaders were not acting solely in the country's interests, but also in their own capitalist interests. He felt, too, that many Chinese were dissatisfied with tho government's non-resistance to the Japanese on the ground that a policy of waiting was more advantageous to Japan than to China, He also suggested that during tho period of waiting other foreign powers might gain a hold on China which they might use to their own ad¬ vantage at a later period0 He suggested further that if Japon could bo viewed as the sole bulwark against tho spread of Communism in Asia so Chinese Communism could be viewed as the principal bulwark against the spread of Japanese imperialism. As the foregoing parts of this report have indicated, or at least implied, there was widespread feeling in tho round tables that Japanese aggression had strengthened tho position of the Chinese Communist movement. One member stressed this point rather clearly when he suggested that Japanese aggression was making Communists good Chinese citizens. In view of the prominence given to the sup¬ pression of this movement by the Japanese Foreign Minister's demands on the Nanking Government, our discussions passed easily to tho third division of our agenda, namely, "International Implications of Chinese Reconstruction," The transition to this topic had also been made in the earlier discussion regarding China's urgent need of foreign capital and assistance. It is from this latter point that I may more suitably begin. You vd.ll recall that one of the chief obstacles to foreign assistance in Chinese reconstruction was thought to be the Japanese policy as enforced in April 1934 by Mr, Am.au, spokesman of the Japanese Foreign Office, The round tables conscientiously sought to determine the exact meaning of the Ajnau Doctrine, as subsequently modified by the Foreign Office, in its application to the question of foreign assistance to China. Japanese members stressed the point that the Amau statement had received serious criticism in Japan as woll as abroad and had accordingly been significantly modified, I am not certain that the Japanese position on this question was really clarified in our discussion, for while It was stated that Japan desired to pre¬ serve the Open Ibor in China, that benefits to hina were- more often than not also benefits to Japan, and that Japan's policy did not exclude foreign assistance to China of a non-political and non-military nature, nevertheless it was evident that Japan wished to reserve some sort of right of consultation or even power of veto. The exact nature of that right or of that power was not discovered in our discussions. Perhaps the most accurate general report on this point that I can make is that Japan wishes China to consult her on any matters pertaining to foreign assistance and that presumably such a right would carry with it the power of veto.

Ameii can members questioned Japan's right to carry out such a policy in international lav?, but it was immediately brought to their attention that this was exactly the policy the United States had pursued in the Caribbean, Iho American members in large part admitted the accuracy of this contention and countered with two points, first that the United States had abandoned that policy during the last ten years, and, second, that the policy when practiced had been a commercial failure in holding back the development of regions which might have been assisted by funds from across the Atlantic, ^hoy suggesteu that the JapancoO policy towards china might have the same result of holding back the very develop¬ ment of china which the Japanese asserted they desired. The concluding discussions on Round Table Topic 3-V pointed the way to the discussions which we shall begin tomorrow, iheso questions wero askeds If Japan is truly interested in a prosperous China which may buy consumption and capital goods frjm her, is not the wisest policy to relax prcsourc and ailow China to capitalize on the new sense of unity which has developed in the last two or three years? And, secondly, would not any bilateral settlement of the whole Sino-Japanese difficulty bo far less satisfactory to both parties and far less lasting than a settlement based on a system of collective security applicable to the whole Pacific Area and to the whole world?
