essay:div.essay:p: Secretariat 1936 Document 40 STATEMENT FOR PLENARY SESSION OF ROUND TABLE TOPIC V August 26, 1936 (The Hon, F. W. Eggleston) The discussion on which we are about to embark is the most significant of all the discussions because it asks us to take the responsibility of formulating rem¬ edies and it also suggests that on some one lies the responsibility of putting into operation tl-ese solutions. Before such discussion can be of value, I suggest some clarification of terms is essential. And I propose to make some remarks upon cer¬ tain conceptions that are used in the discussion scheme. The main terms I will consider will be change, peaceful change, collective security and collective systems. This scheme makes one admission that is crucial and which very many discussions ig¬ nore and that is that the main problem of the Pacific as in other parts of the world is change and the adjustment to change. Somehow or other over the whole world the tempo of change has been rapidly increased so that the difficulties of adjustment are almost insuperable. I think it is exceedingly important to recognize that changes of this kind are the most important causes of international difficulty. Policy under changing conditions is difficult and nervous changes occur in which old economic structures are unsuitable and machinery which sustained large popu¬ lations becomes inadequate. These populations struggle to maintain their old position though it rapidly bccomes impossible. The phenomenon of rapid change is the most vital feature of the post-war world and the underlying cause of all our difficulties. The war created a tempo of changes which had been inevitable for many years but which would have gone on in the revolutionary way. The changes which are occurring are inevitable. It would be as futile to stop them as to brush back the waves of the sea. They are to an extent involuntary and uncontrollable and all we can do is to accomodate ourselves to them. Vie must make these accomodations peacefully, but the term peaceful change often assumes that the changes necessary are relatively simple. The idea is that some expert knows them and we have only to follow his advice. This is net true. The changes in the social structure of the nature of which we have been considering have some analogy to change in physical structure. Strains accumulate and breaks occur. But they are still less control¬ lable than physical changes because they are the product or resultant of the activ¬ ities of millions of human beings, produced by separate will, and influenced by emotions and ideas which must work thru these individual minds. The fallacy of an easily controllable world must be abandoned. Peaceful change, therefore, is not a matter of prescription by an export or the decision of a democratic body or the rescript of a dictator - it must result from changes in human conduct on the part of large masses. The position, therefore is that change is happening at an un¬ usual rate in the world around us. YTe cannot stop it or wholly control it. YJhat we have to do is to make the adjustments that are necessary without war. The doctrine of collective security raises the question whether the desire for security is compatible with the necessity for change. Collective security is axiom¬ atic. Somebody is this series ef discussions will perhaps define the term collective security. I will not criticize it but will only raise the point that the desire for security may be only an expression of resistance to change and if change is inevitable wc ha.ve a rather awkward situation. Y,re are only a whole body of nations trying to stop the inevitable. In support of the question, I can only say that all of you who have any acquaintance with politics that fear of change is an emotion that is only less strong than fear of pain. The communist theory is that the resistance is so strong that It can only be overcome by revolution. Collective security, there¬ fore may be mere resistance to change and some of those changes may be necessary to enable nations to maintain their populations. Unless collective security is accom¬ panied by some ineans by which can be promoted and rendered safe, it may easily be¬ come a menace, though it may be a moans of making the change safe. It is rather im-

portant to notice that another expression of the resistance to change may be in armaments and the connection between the two under the league plan of salvation is somewhat erroneous. Sanctions are a sanctified form of the blockade, I feel very strongly that the League may very well be an agency for peaceful change if armaments are so reduced as not to be a major factor. Then sanctions may be a police measure. But the arming of police with machine guns - is not productive of law and order. In the present condition of tho world, armaments dominate the scone, they increase the resistance to change without reducing its necessity or tempo and hurry it on to calamity. Nor is aggression a simple problem. If changes are necessary to accommodate increasing populations, may not aggression be the only way out for increasing populations? YJhatevor tribunals you sot up must decide on tho present order and cannot ad¬ judicate on change. We must recognize change and promote it. I am afraid I am becoming an impossibilist. But all I am saying is that we must recognise change and promote it. It is inevitable, it is the demand cf new forces, now minds and souls for recognition# It is unfortunate that we cannot direct it better but we have no adequate machinery for the problem precipitated upon us. This leads us to a dilemma which is very deep. Our difficulty may be that there is no solution to the problem of change along the linos to which we have been accustomed. There is certainly no solution along the lines of forced arma¬ ments. The great war arose out of the demand for change which was. resisted. After four years of slaughter, changes of the most far-reaching and disastrous charac¬ ter were brought into operation. That change then demanded could not have been adjusted because it was wrongly interpreted as mere aggression which indeed was the form it took. Force is no remedy and armaments reduce all machinery to futility. I have :\o doubt that all problems of change could be solved on the economical plane if we were all intelligent and allowed changes to take place which can justify themselves. Our old enemy "laissez-faire" had some good points. The point is that we are not intelligent and a solution of perfectly soluble problems on economic lines seems more improbable than anything else. The result is that the only solution must be the ethical solutions and in¬ deed it is true that change cannot come about writhout sacrifice. If the change is to be peaceful that sacrifice, must be voluntary. In other words, collective security may be a menace but a collective system in which the problems of the world are viewed as a whole and their meaning recognized and the responsibility of making the changes necessary for peace is placed on the leading members with¬ out compulsion, is still a feasible system. It can, of course, only be successful if the responsibility of tho greatest nations tc: make the sacrifice is accepted in a spirit of noblesse oblige. If it wore recognized that an Empire which owns 1/5 of the earth's surface cannot havo an exclusive block, or that the nation which has the greatest accumulation of resources and wealth cannot have the high¬ est tariff and the largest navy, we should be nearer peo.ee. In any case, enor¬ mous strides to peace might be made if there wore a proportionate reduction of armaments . Not because security was obtained by political settlements but because people were willing to take risks and did not regard change as the chief risk. Let me say a few words about the Pacific In conclusion. The dangers in the Pacific are essentially the same as in other parts of tho world. The industrial¬ ized nations of western Europe find in the Pacific markets which help to maintain their populations. But the other populations of the Pacific desire to be treated as ends in themselves and build up balanced communities in which a full life self- determined economically as well as pclitcally is possible. If this aspiration - of the newer nations is realized, tho ambitions of foreign nations is reduccd. Japan demands access to foreign markets to maintain her population and everybody

is afraid of these markets and adopts restrictive legislation* As markets are closed the line of least resistance, which happens to be China, is taken. Here is the essential position of the Pacific. It is relatively a far more simple and feasible problem than that of Europe# If china were stable a balance in the Pacific could be obtained. The fact that European nations hold minor interests in the Pacific should not prevent Pacific people from insisting that Pacific problems should be handled by Pacific people along the lines which will lead to the most beneficial development there. The intense problems of Europe are due to the fact that you have proud historic nations with huge industrialized populations crowded together in a relatively small continent with very narrow entrees to the world. The character of the traffic problems of the Pacific is entirely different. The Pacific is spacious and most nations are self-contained, hostile action is difficult, de¬ fense is easy, and we should insist that those advantages be retained. I suggest, therefore, that the terms we use in the discussion on this round table topic should be very carefully considered and the implications should bo carefully studied.

Secretariat 1936 Document 41 STATEMENT AT PLENARY SESSION ON ROUND TABLE TOPIC V. August 29, 1936 (V. E. Mo.tylov) In the course of the discussion of the last topic of our agenda the fact of the economic, political and military grovfth of the USSR and its defensive power has attracted not less attention, than during the discussion on previous topics. This growth, which one of the distinguished delegates at this conference characterized as a dramatical one, has been widely recognized as an outstanding factor of the Pacific relations, and, as it seems to me, has been recognized by at least a majority of this Conference as a powerful factor for peace in this region of the world. I consider that enough evidence has been given at this Conference, that the growth of the military power of the USSR in general, and in its Far Eastern Region, in particular, not only assures peace at its borders, but also encourages peaceful tendencies in more than one country of the Pacific. Nowadays, weakness and helplessness invito aggression—the growth of our capacity for defense, on the contrary, chocks aggression and makes it more diffi¬ cult for aggressive groups to start some now "peaceful changes." I wish you would for a moment ask yourselves that would be the world sit¬ uation today if instead of the Union of Soviet Socialistic Republics there were an imperialist Russia* Is it not self-evident that in this case the world long ago would have been thrown into the horrors of a new world war, of a new "red ocean' of blood", for the sake of selfish interests of a ruling imperialist clique? Is it not self-evident that the existence of a socialist system of ucconomy in our country, eliminating any stimuli for expansion and aggression, is to the real advantage of humanity, thirsting for peace? It is the more important to remind ourselves of these facts at a Conference in which it has become clear enough that the pro-requisites for a collective or¬ ganization of peace—which we consider to bo the only real guarantee for peace- do not exist so far in the Pacific region# is known to some of you that I have something to do with geographical studies. Together with a number of my colleagues here I could note that some significant changes are taking place in traditional geography: oceans become more and more narrow, continents get closer to each other, and their intor-do- pendcnce grows stronger. The difficulties of guaranteeing peace in the Pacific should not make the friends of peace fold their hands and recognize fatalistically the inevitability of -war. The organization of collective security in the Pacific,, such as it should be, did not appear at this Conference as a practical possibility of today. But does this mean that all possibilities of safeguarding peace are exhausted and that new forms aro unthinkable which could combine tho peaceful efforts of all interested powers?

Allow no, as I did already at a round table yesterday, to rccall one practical suggestion which was made by Mr. Litvinov more than two years ago at the clos in." session of the General Committee of the Disarmament m Gone**. I think that the time has come to remind ourselves of that suggestion again. In making the proposal to transform the Disarmament Conference into a perman¬ ent institution for the preservation of peace, Mr. Litvinov said: "I propose to transform this conforence into a Permanent Peace Conference, meeting periodically and working for the safeguarding of the security of all nations. So far peace conferences have been convoked^mostly after wars and had as their aim the partition of spoils, the imposition on the van¬ quished of onerous and humiliating conditions, the redistribution of territories, the remodelling of states—and thus created sources of now wars. The Conference which I have in mind, must be created for the pre¬ vention of wars and of their terrible consequences. It should work out, widen and perfect methods of strengthening security, listen in time to warnings of coming war dangers, listen to the "SOS" appeals of meanace states and extend to them a timely possible help, moral, economic, finan¬ cial, or other. "I foresee references to the League of Nations which by the articles 12, 15, 16 and others so obliged to serve the very aims to which I would like to direct the work of the Conference. But, the League, first, has a great num¬ ber of tasks, it deals with many matters, great and small,_it was croatcc. at a moment, when many people thought that the danger of war is excluded for many years to come. But now, when we all see the danger of war, ^ thought ^ should bo given to the creation of a special organ, directed in its ac iv:- ity towards one aim, namely the prevention or the lessening of war danger. Secondly, the League of Nations is too much bound by its Covenant. The appeal to it and its decisions are too strictly regulated, while the tribune of the Conference could be made more accessible, more free, more responsibe to the needs of the moment. Let the Conference continue to be an organ of the League and use the machinery of the League, lot it be most closely connected with the League, let it not replace the League, which should fully maintain its prerogatives....But did^not the very con¬ vocation of the Disarmament Conference prove the insufficiency of the frame-work of the League for such big tasks, as disarmament,—and my pro¬ posal deals with greater tasks, namely with the permanent preservation of peace?" Wo heard at this Conference proposals of rather abstract nature regarding so-called peaceful changes, proposals detached from their fundamental pre-requis- ite—collective security. No one objects and no one could object to an lc.ea, go excellent in itself. But we did not, it seems, notico there any visible pro¬ gress in the direction of the realization of this idea, on the basis of a vol- untary, equal and sovereign consent of all interested parties. TJowld it net be better if we shoul seriously think over how to make such feasible practical^ changes in the organization of peace, which would constitute a serious handicap to the danger of war? And it is with this idea in my mind that I come back to the practical proposals of Mr. Litvinov, which would make possible the cooperation for peace by all, in all parts oi the world. Ladies and Gentlemenj Our conference is drawing to its end. Whatever the possible practical effects of our work here may be, two facts^are evidenc: xirst, our work has not boon in vain. The factual material at our disposal, the ex¬ change of opinions—all this made the situation in the Pacific mere clear to Uo all.

At the same timo-«-and this must be said openly—we have seen such a picture of most serious and deepening contradictions vhich cannot but arouse the apprehension of all friends of peace, and at the same time fortify their Mil to peace. I represent here the scientists of the USSR enraged in the study of Pacific affairs. One of the maxims of our scientific method is the unity be¬ tween theory and practice In our theory as well as in our practice we will subordinate our activities to the great task—the fight for peace.

Secretariat 1936 Document 48 ADDRESS OF HEM I BOM-IE T Special Plenary Session August 26, 1936. Mr. Chairman, Ladies and Gentlemen: I have to speak today on the work of the International Conference of the International Institute of Intellectual Cooperation, and especially of the preparation of the next session of this "body, which will have to deal with the following subject: "Peaceful solution of certain international problems," and then a sub-title, "The specific difficulties in and the procedures for the peaceful solution of the economic, social and territorial problems, with special reference to (a) population migration and colonization* (b) markets and dis¬ tribution of raw materials. If I was so kindly invited to give you some information about this piece of research work, I am sure it v/as not in order to give me the satis¬ faction and the opportunity of bringing my little contribution to this avalanche cf which Lord Snell was speaking yesterday. Neither was it as an expert in English,, as you perhaps realize already, njr as an expert in economics and other matters, "but because the studies of the International Conference are closely related to the interesting debates you have already had and will have tomorrow and Friday in this Pacific Conference. The subjects which you have discussed have an important bearing on the studies of the International Studies Conference, and we hope also that the inquiries which the Institute of Pacific Relations will make during the coming month will largely contribute to clarify some of the points which will be examined next year, in June, when the International Studies Conference will meet. Having tried to explain - even to justify my presence here - I would be inclined* of course, to add some words on the International Institute of Intellectual Cooperation itself, but I shall refrain from doing so, reminding you only that the Institute is the organ of a technical organization of the League „vf Nations* The aim of this organization is, broadly speaking, to establish direct relations between the organizations, departments, associations, devoted to intellectual, scientific and educational action in our different countries and.to create between them the habit of working in common; of settling, by international methods, the numerous problems which they are all faced with at the same time. Our Chairman, Mr. McDonald, said this morning, that the history of the last fifteen years was made of lost opportunities and that nothing appropriate had ever been done, at the right time. I entirely agree, but one should add that the history of these past years was also entirely made up of deep rooted in¬ comprehension and misunderstanding* If the peoples of the world are to be able to live in a community of nations while at the same time preserving the high. degree cf independence they enjoy today and their national genius, they must realize and understand what unites them and be able to make some concessions on what could divide them#

It is true that no human society could exist without rules, but these rules must, in addition, be based en a common morality* It is true also that a widespread consensus of opinion exists in regard to the principles which ouht to rule the international relations - reconciliation of interests; arbitration; international justice, for example6 But the problem remains of converting these principles into notions recognized as the compulsory source of any political act ionc Now, to help in the solution of these very groat problems of inter¬ national collaboration of thought it was recognized that one should, amongst other activities, think of the qualified representatives of scientific work and research in the field of social sciences and international relations* that an important service would be rendered and at the sane time a specific work of intellectual cooperation would be accomplished. I now come to the second point of this statement, which I should per¬ haps have begun with, that is, to tell you something about the organization of the International Studies Conference itself. In the third and last part of this statement I shall try to explain in what spirit the very large and complex session will function. The International Studies Conference became a studies conference only five years ago. It had previously been an administrative body for the scientific study of international relations, such as the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London, Centre d'Etude de Politique Etrangere, some German, Dutch, Polish and Roumanian institutions, and also some international schools and institutions like the Graduate School of International Studies in Geneva, or the Institute of Pacific Relations itself# It was soon recognized that the best way of promoting research and at the same time promoting real international collaboration in the field of social sciences would be to associate the various members of the Conference in the study of some major problem of international relations, to follow in this respect the example of the Institute of Paci.fic Relationso The first attempt v/as made when a thorough study of the economic life culminated in an International Con¬ ference held in London in 1933- Then followed the study of the problem of collective security, which led to a similar general conference, which was held last year, and this last conference on collective security explains the choice oi tne present subject to be studied. The Program Committeef when making its decision, intended to continue its research on collective security and to complete the results already obtained by a study of the methods for the removal of the causes of war. But before beginning to speak of the subject itself, I will try to give^you an idea of the organization of the Conference, which is a new,, independ¬ ent international bodyr autonomous in the frame of the technical organization for intellectual cooperation of the League of Nations. It is composed of about thirty different national groups of institutions dealing either with foreign politics and international relations or at least some aspects of these branches of research* The first success of the conference has clearly been to promote the study of these questions in many countries where this kind of study needed to dc encouraged or developed; and second, to introduce a more effective inter-* national cooperation in a field which requires, perhaps more than any other one?

the knowledge of the results obtained in other "branches of science, geography, economics, and so on, in the various countries. As a proof, a large number of institutions have recently been created in Europe in order to participate fully in the v/ork of the International Studies Conference and are at present "being organised. They "benefits of course, from the experience of older and well- equipped institutions« They try to place all sorts of facilities at the dis¬ posal of the individual research workers - "bibliographies, information depart¬ ments, specialized librariesc They create study groups for the discussion in common of the most interesting, important and acute problems of the day,. And through the new system of liaison, which the Institute of Intellectual Cooperatio has established, they have, apart from this common study of the methods of peaceful settlements of international problems, a good deal of collaboration on other topics. Some of them, for instance, are studying the structure of the new political regimes which have recently been created in other countries of Europe. Others inquire into agrarian problems. They deal also with various important political problems and with social questions, like unemployment and many others, and on these special points the interested bodies have also special liaison and special exchange of views and information. And of course a great number of these institutions ~ they are increas¬ ing in number every day - like the American or British institutions, issue books of a scientific character, pamphlets and also reviews. New institutions of this kind have in fact been created or reorganized or at least certain coordinating committees, in many countries of Europe - in many countries of Central Europe - Czecho-Slovakia, Austria, Hungary, Bulgaria^ Norway. In Spain a very strong institute was created last year and I hope very much it will escape the consequences of the civil war; in France a new Centre d5Etude de Politique Etrangere; in the United States a new liaison committee has recently been created to have a better liaison with our conference, and the conference of course keeps all its contacts and relations with its older members in Great Britain, several dominions, the Netherlands, in Italy, and so on. Before going further, I would like to insist on the distinctly scienti.f ic character of the conference. These individual members do not think evidently that the philosophers should rule their various nations but they think never¬ theless that the philosophers can still give some help, as they did in the past, but that would require some developments, and have insisted on the really scien¬ tific, objective and disinterested character for their conference. We come now I think to the question of positive change. The subject will be dealt with at the next session of the conference. As I told you, it is but the.continuation of the previous work on collective.security, the results of which have been published in book form by the Institute of Intellectual Coop¬ eration. I am not trying to give a resume of this book. Let me point out, how¬ ever, that with the exception of perhaps one delegation, there had been in the conference a general consensus of opinion on some very important points. It was agreed that the preservation of peace makes necessary the recognition of certain rules and the acceptance of the consequences which they involve for international relations. The idea of the prevention of war has given rise to the whole questic of new relations between nations. In approaching this vast and complex question the conference had been led to.make a special point of discussing the principle of the organization of pacific systems destined to eliminate the causes of war to the fullest possible extent.

I must say that previously of course tliey had discussed also the question of repression of war in its various aspects; they had made a searching examination of the notion of neutrality, "but an important part of the delibera¬ tions was devoted to the problem of the prevention of war and amongst other points one was unanimously recognized, that in order to fight against war with amy chances of success it is necessary to concentrate upon its causes "by looking for the pacific means of settlement of disputes which could lead up to war. And it was also recognized that these conflicts are in most cases connected with claims, founded or not, with aspirations which should find satisfaction or any¬ how "be dealt with in the existing juridical order. Many of the distinguished scholars and international lav/yers who were present at the London conference would certainly have "been able to discuss this question theoretically. They refrained nevertheless from doing so; to envisage procedures for Article 19 of the Covenant of the League of the creation of tribunals or committees. They thought - rightly I think - that they should em¬ bark on a new series of studies, the material for which will be furnished by the questions I already referred to - questions of population, colonies, raw materials and markets. The procedures to be employed to deal with these questions are of very great variety, and it seems to be a good method to approach the fundamental difficulties and to turn the attention to the positive procedures only after having made sufficient progress in the initial part of the undertaking. I can¬ not, having already been too long, I am sure, explain what are the proposals of the national groups, - the studies they have undertaken and the nature of the interim reports sent to the preparatory meeting of the conference, held at Madrid in June last. I will just try to give you some indications of the work already adopted. This work to be undertaken involves, above all, a critical analysis of the requirements in support of a request for any form of peaceful change, and an analysis of the obstacles or resistance opposed to such claims. All claims for change are not justified. Some may be exaggerated. They may be sometimes' legitimate in principle but dangerous in the solutions they demand or the methods they recomr.iendo And of course this study of the difficulties and the obstacles must be completed by analysis of the solutions existing. As for the first question - the question of raw materials - some days ago in our round tables we discussed the so-called question of raw materials in the Far East, and I noticed that it was not a very easy one. Somebody raised a very important point: whether the claim for raw material was made in view of the preparation for war or to facilitate the economic life of a country and its citizens. It is a very important point, but many others come to mind that re¬ quire a good deal of preliminary documentation first, which the various national groups and members are collecting, for instance, on the national consumption and production of raw materials. Are they imported from abroad or colonial countries'! It requires, above all, a comparison of the economic conditions of supply, of cost prices, and.of the real, existing obstacles, if any, to the free supnly of raw materials, and also a study of the policies envisaged by countries lacking in raw materials. What is the cost price of raw materials produced in the home country; of raw materials imported from the colonies; of the colonial territories which, for one reason or another, have adopted the open door policy? What are also the rates of interest and dividends of national undertakings producing raw

materials in the hone countries or in foreign lands? What are, in fact, the ex.- isting restrictions on the export of raw materials, fiscal duties, restrictions "by groups of producers, restrictions, also, on the importation of raw materials- I will only quote as an example an American ."roup, which created a special committee to investigate the more important aspects of the problem, com¬ posed of scholars of many American universities - Princeton, Chicago, the Univers¬ ity of Wisconsin, of Minnesota, of the National Bureau of Economic Research, the Brookings Institute. As for colonies, I shall not try to go into details. Hie crucial poinc will he a thorough study made "by many groups - the French, British, Dutch, per¬ haps a Portuguese group and a German (group - of the real value of colonies. What are the advantages and drawbacks of the possession of colonies from the economic standpoint as well as from the political and moral standpoint. Also a study of the solution suggested in the light first of non-controversial regions like the Congo Basin, or of the mandate system, and also taking into account the possibilities of territorial changes. We will study also the questions relating to the status of foreign colonies and the investment of foreign capital. It is easy to see there will be some difficulties and differences of opinion on this question of colonies, even on the definition and still more on the redistribution of colonies and the extension of the mandate system. Especially will there be differences of opinion when the confsrence comes to the study of the very important problem of migration, a question alluded to in our present conference and which plays a greater role in other parts of the world than the Pacific area. There again concrete problems are being studied ~ the problem of the assimilation of the immigrant; possibilities of habitation for different races in areas like to receive immigrants, and so on. I would also lite to point out that some .groups are concentrating their attention 011 the problem of over-population. When can it be said that a state is over-populated? What are the principal criteria of over-population? I think the mere enunciation of these problems reminds you of many points on which public opinion in all countries neerls to be better informed upon and to profit from the results of objective studies of the facts and also of the policies which are followed by some nations. The last thing I have to say is that from the point of view of organ¬ ization there is a permanent coordination between all these parallel researchers- It is assured in three ways: Through the officials of the Institute of Intel¬ lectual Cooperation; second, by a general rapporteur assisted by four deputy rapporteurs; and third, by international committees of experts which meet from time to time. We have already had meetings of these international groups on each of the big problems - population, colonies, etc. I shall mention especially one of them, the Danubian group. The Conference decided to include in its program, as an example of a complete and concrete problem the territorial and social aspects of the Danubian problem and this proposal, it is interesting to note, came from the Institute in Vienna and in Bucharest. It was accepted by the six

countries concerned and all of then have created a special group for preparing this question, the leaders of which net at Vienna recently. And it is particularly gratifying to report that they cane easily to an agreement as to the nature and scope of the study they wished to undertake. With this encouraging note I think I have nothing to add "but to thank you and to apologize.for having "been too long. Perhaps I nay seen to be a little too optimistic on the future of the conference. My only wish is this, to ask for your help* Many of you are already members of the existing group. I wish warmly that many others of you will join these groups. I think you have them in your country, and I want, at the end, to make a strong appeal to the representatives of countries represented in the Pacific Institute which are not members of the International Studies Conference to persuade their universities to join this international "body as soon as possible. I wish to assure them that if they come to the International Conference next year they will be welcomed by all the other members of this Committee.

Secretariat 1936 Document 45 STATEMENT MADE AT PLENARY SESSION ON ROUND TABLE TOPIC V. August 29, 1936 (Albert Sarraut) Again I am honored—this time to say the last words of this conference, or better still, to refer to the witty speech delivered to us a few evenings ago by Lord Snell, and literally to pour forth the last waves of the avalanche of elo¬ quence# I wish to place myself immediately under the invocation of one of the first kings of France, whom they called Pepin le Bref, because he was of a very short stature.. I am no king for the time being; my name is not Pepin, and I am not so much of a dwarf, but I shall be brief. I now give you the pleasure of my promise to be brief. Because of that promise, I shall put aside tho natural temptation which comes to me to extract and to resume, in this last speech, the political and moral philo¬ sophy wiich can very well be drawn from the labors of this conference. That would be intensely interesting, but too long. Nothing is as long as a summary. Y/hen a man tells you that he is intending to summarize, bewardl The only exception to that rule which I know of is the summary given by the excellent rapporteur this morn?lng, and I hope you will permit me to congratulate him together with the other fine speakers of the morning. It is a great personal pleasure for me to refer to the worthy interests of our discussions of the past fortnight. Naturally, I would have preferred, not by national pride, but because of personal convenience, that the conferences had taken place in French, but if some of the Ideas have by chance escaped me here and there, I have, nevertheless, been impressed by the science, by the depth of thought, the documentation, and by the good faith of all of those who have analyzed the great problems which ive have tried to solve. I really take away with me a very high es- time for this conference; I donTt regret my long journey, and already I dream of purchasing my ticket for the next international meeting of the Institute three years hence-~if, of course, the good Good permits mo to live, and I see no special reason why he should not do so. I hope to find again at that time the same faces, the same assembly, both masculine and feminine; they would not understand that a Frenchman, unless he were very depressed, would miss the opportunity of' paying his respects to what we call in French the "weaker sex." Probably to vindicate our¬ selves, and because we feel that the intelligence and the heart of woman is In¬ finitely superior to that of man, we draw up Civil Codes to chain the power of this "weaker sex." Those are our weapons of Collective-Security. We shall have inscribed in the annals of this magnificent and enchanting valley, if not concrete results, at least the strength of a groat will in the direction of the preservation of peace in the Pacific area. And so, we will not have spoiled the valley by bellicose attitudes, by words of resentment or hostility and the magnificent frame-work of Nature will have merited our respect. silvery light, and. I said to myself that : "Yle too arc do\m in the shadow; we are still in the shadow full of fears and menaces where we don't see clearly, where our prejedices, our instincts, our errors, and our ignorance buffet one another together into a confused scramble which can become murderous. patience and restraint during this Institute of Pacific Relations Conference, and I confine myself in thinking of the changing balance of forccs and the use of force and the use of diplomacy, to only this single comment upon that brilliant speech, that the policy that he so graphically described as having been initiated by John Hay was net really achieved by the power of the big gun behind the diplomat' - because at that time I would not have regarded the United States as a very powerful naval force - and diplomacy in the future which is really backed by good will and met half way by the good will of other nations can be successful in improving mutual relationships and building peace. Nevertheless, in the field of the more technical discussions that we have had and to which Mr. Yoshizawa has referred today, there is a vast amount of work to be done. In regard to our relationships in trade with Japan, I feel confident - and I hope that Mr, Carter and those who have worked so hard with him in the Secretariat will take note of this - I feel confident that our exchange of views with our Japanese friends on the removal of difficulties in trade relations are going to be of extreme value and that what we are going to say to our people in England - and they in Tokyo - will lead to a removal, not at once perhaps but gradually, by good will, of many of the sources of irritation and barriers in our actual trade relationships. But I am more than ever convinced, and I hope my friends will agroo with me - I am more than ever convinced from our conversations that there will be no lasting peace with justice in the world until there is a properly erected machine for the construction of collective security, a collective security which will not leave the settlement as to whether justice is being done to those whose cause is being tried, but will leave it to the judgment of the nations of the world, assembled not in political order but assembled through duly appointed legalistic persons, jurists impartial, making their decisions with the guidance of the growing precedents of international law, I feel, too, that I ought to say that whilst wo have had very interesting discussions, with regard to regional pacts that we shall have to apply in our respective countries a great deal of thought and time to that question before we can really link into the minds of the peopl c the real world responsibility for peace with the regional action that requires to be taken, I am obliged, although I have been critical during this conference about the more academic side, I am obliged for the help and tho learning that we havo received upon those points from those who have made a study of intornational law. But above all although I have very little time left, ^ should like to end what I have to say this morning on a general note - I feel that there is always a danger both in the

conferences of statesmen, in the more formal councils, and in the assemblies of such study conferences as we have hero today, that we all may be tempted to magnify our own point of view, that we may on occasion even feel individual and intellectual pride in our particular contribution at a given time, and there¬ after leave the sphere of cur conference and our speech and think that wo havo very nearly done all that is required, forgetful, as I said to my round table yesterday, what the real problem is, the real problem of how, if I may requote some words I used last Tuesday, of how to bring to the great toiling masses of all the nations as individuals in those toiling masses, the right to know, and to enjoy, all the best that life can offer in the sphere of knowledge, emotion and hope. When I think of the conferences, I have been in with statesmen in political parties, or in such studies as this, I feel oppressed with the sense that over and over again the real case of these toiling masses is overlooked to a very large extent® They are pawns in the game, just moved like chessmen in the great struggle, to be used afterwards for cannon fodder# I should like to feel "that as we leave this conference today in the words of Mr. Yoshizawa we shall each opply at once not from the point of view of the personal projection of our own view but from the point of view of the colloctivo knowledge we have ob¬ tained and the personal understanding on the other hand of the difficulties of tho other nations « apply ourselves to removing the barriers. For that reason I must emphasize one othor thing, and I hope tho people who do not agree with me on this point will forgive me — that the people who drafted the agenda of this con¬ ference, probably none of them members of my political school of thought, were right when they included in the subject of discussion tho necessity of consider¬ ing the question of internal adjustment of economic and social and industrial questions, if we aro really going to bring into our perspective of the improvement of mutual relations between the nations in the future, the whole of the needs of the toiling masses, we have got to be prepared to consider improvements in that direction# We have vast improvements still to make in Britain# I see as I travel in the United States vast improvements still necessary to bo made if you arc going to solve the problem of the increasing output per unit of labor of production of wealth, with the comparatively static rate of consumption per unit of labor#. Secretariat 1936 Document 43 STATEMENT AT PLENARY SESSION ON ROUND TABLE TOPIC V August 29, 1936 (K# Yoshizawa) From different parts of the woirld, filled to a greater or lesser extent with fear and apprehension, have we come to this wonderful valley of Yosemite with a hope and expectation of finding out some means by which to alleviate troubles in the Pacific. Over the past two weeks we did exchange candid views and frank opinions, but evidently difficulties confronting us were so groat that we were unablo to attain concrete results satisfactory to all of us. We have been enlightened, however, as to the real nature of the problems facing us, and wo have learned anew that the world has not attained the degree of pcrfoction which would enable us to realize our ideal of peace in the immediate future. Somo of us, maybe, will be leaving this Con¬ ference with a distinct note of pessimism.} somo of us with a brightened feeling in tho anticipation of a better future. But most of us undoubtedly will leave this place with a conviction that more retrospect, exertion, and perhaps sacrifico shall be needed on the part of all of us boforo we reach any satisfactory solution of our problems. Round Table Topic V, needless to say, occupied the most prominent position in the whole Conference pro¬ gram, and under this topic we discussed the changing balance of forces in the Pacific and the possibilities of peaceful adjustment. In the course of our discussion, the question of a possible revision of tho Nine Power Treaty attracted a considerable amount of our attention . . . a question which to some of us appeared to be pertinent in tho changed situation in the Far East today. This question, however, subsequently led to more general discussions of collective security for the Pacific countries. And the central point in that question was how to devise a peace machinery fully compatible to peaceful change in the relation between different countries« To illustrator prior to the World War, the Anglo-Japanese Alliance was an important factor in tho political balance of the Far East. At the Yfashington Conference, various treaties were signed and resolutions adopted with a view to stabilizing the political situation in that area. Unfortunately, soon after, conditions began to change radically, making the practical operation of the foregoing international implements in¬ operative . If the proposed now machinery is to bo based upon sanctions, I would like to call attention to the practical difficulties involved, which are well illustrated in the recent difficulties of the League of Nations. The necessity must be realized, therefore, of further examination of such proposals before'their actual incorporation into any form of peace machinery. I think that Japan v/ould regard the question of sanctions with grave concern. Although some of the members have expressed themselves very bluntly with regard to the possible application of sanctions, It is highly doubtful if such application would achieve the desired result. I may further state that in the consideration of any proposed colle ctive security system based upon sanctions, it is imperative that we

take cognizance of the dynamic rather than static situation in the Pacific Area. Due to the limitations of Conference procedure, our discussion of this topic failed to formulate any concreto program, but we are extremely pleased that there has been a frank exchange of honest opinions, thereby giving us a guiding basis for a further study of this problem in the future# In conclusion, if we observe the situation prevailing in the world today, it appears that relations among nations are becoming more and more strained, and are thus tending toward grave conscquences« Unless some method of improving those relations is found, it is not difficult to surmise what this situation augurs for the future® Therefore, it is imperative that we discovor the underlying causes of tho present state of affairs, and make an effort toward their elimin¬ ation, with a spirit of cooperation so as to attain security. With this end in view, each delegate, it is hoped, will attempt to guide public opinion in his home country, so that peace and good-will among tho nations may bo assured.

Secretariat 1936 Document 23 ^DDHESS OF D.t# LE'.'IS L. LQiflTIil Special Plenary Session August 26, 1936 Mr• Chairman, Ladies and Gentlemen: I. Wo have cone here to consider whether peaceful change in the Pacific is possible and how# We start with the promise that peace is desirable and that change is inevitable. This Conference will have done a historic work if it will have outlined, no matter how tentatively, the path along which peace and progress may meet. During the ten days that we have been meeting here, we have been presented with a mass of vital information on the nature and extent of the profound changes which are transforming the Far East, and we have listened to frank, though differing interpretations of the meaning and causes of these changes# We cannot but be fully aware of the portent of our discussions# It would not be in harmony with the spirit of candor and with the eager search for the truth which have marked this Conference if we did not admit clearly and unequivocally the seriousness of the situation in the Far East and the difficulties which beset any effort for composing conflicts through cooper¬ ation# Y(g may be even more emphatic. Probably not since the religious wars of the sixteenth century has there been such a manifestation of doc¬ trinal intolerance, emotional vehemence, and of such passion for intergroup destruction as is shown today in different parts of the world# If, despite all these difficulties, we face our problem here with faith^ it is because of the evidence we have that never before was there such widespread and genuine abhorence of war and such hope that someone will somehow help to exorcise the specter of another conflagration which haunts the v/orld both East and West# II. In our various sessions we have examined in considerable detail the concrete facts of the changing world situation and specific proposals for allaying the present conflicts# We have emphasized particularly the industrial¬ ization and trade expansion of Japan, the economic dislocations of the Wostern countries, the disruption of traditional commercial and monetary policies everywhere and the friction between different social systems# In these, we have found the main, immediate causes of the present troubles of the world, and we have sought concrete remedies for these troublee# Our discussions have thus prepared us for what seems to me the larger task of examining the general aspects of the problem of peaceful change# In the brief time allotted to me this evening, I should like to state these general aspects and then indicato briefly how the work of the International Labor Organization - the I#L«0# - fits into the general setting# In broad outline, the major conflicts not only in the Pacific but everywhere may be traced to four processes or causes# First, is the in¬ equality in the rate of the economic and social development of different

countries® Second, is the unequal rate at which different social groups within each country develop and with which they can influence national policies# Third, is the desire of each nation or country to obtain an in¬ creasing share of the world's goods - whether of world trade, territory, political power, or cultural ascendancy. And fourth, is the indiscriminate and potentially or actually violent character of the .methods used to achieve such ends# In more general terms, it is the differences in the tempo of current changes, in their direction, in the inequalities of benefits derived, and in methods used that give rise to the threatening conflicts of today. It has been recognized in our round-table discussions that a solution of present day conflicts depends upon our ability to reconcile the tempo and direction of the industrial and social changes in different countries and to equalize their benefits. There have even been suggestions that the countries now in process of rapid expansion should moderate their tempo in order to minimize the dislocations in other countries.. That seems to me a dubious approach to the problem, and in contradiction to some of the basic ideas of this Conference. It is not a question whether one or another country should be asked to make "sacrificial abstentions" in favor of another. The matter goes much doepor. Expansion is the very essence of all life, and es¬ pecially of economic and social life. The rate at which such expansion takes place varies from time to time, but when any nation shows extraordinary vitality it would be against the interests of all mankind to suppress or repress it» The best way in which the economic expansion of a young nation may be harmonized with world needs is to guide such expansion in accordance with the highest concepts and standards of social justice. In other words, tho tempo at which a- nation may expand can be modified by policies which adjust the external expansion of a nation to the relative advance of the less favored social groups within the nation. A positive program of peace thus depends on our capacity to organize on a mutual basis not only world trade and world finance, but also the dis¬ tribution of world power and the relative toleration of different systems of ideas and doctrines. Much has been said here about the peaceful coexistence of different social creeds and systems. May I call ycur attention to tho fact that in its early stages, every new political and social system displays much belligerency and proselyting zeal* That is a way of making a place for itself and of sowing its seeds® But in the course of time, while each system spreads, it undergoes modifications, and a modus vivondi is established between various systems. Protestantism and Catholicism find it possible to livo to¬ gether; certainly, the varieties of democracy in the nineteenth century were not entirely in accord with the prophecies of Joan Jacques Rousseau, and we are witnessing today the gradual adaptation of collectivist and individualist economic principles in national economies. On the basis of these and other general considerations, which I have no time to develop hore,_ I venture to formulo.te four basis principles for achieving peaceful change: First, changes must take place on a more or less universal scale and simulatncously, for instance, if Japan is to make changes in the structure and methods of its textile industry, corresponding readjustments should be made in Lancashire or the U.S.A. This is the principle of universality. Second, the relative position of the different nations in world markets must be so adjusted as to eliminate monopolistic privileges. That is the principle of equalization of benefits.

Third, tho industrial and economic expansion of new nations should proceed in accordance with labor standards developed "by the more advanced nations# This is the principle of social justice and higher standards of living. Fourth, largo changes cannot bo made peacefully unless they arc prepared for. The question is asked why with so much peace machinery in the world, the cause of peace is so frail, I venture to suggest that ineffective as the various mechanisms may appear, they have been an important factor in putting off major international conflicts. But I would also point out what seems to me a basic weakness in existing international machinery. It is negative in that it either prohibits one thing or another and contains pro¬ visions not to do things. Or it is dilatory in the sense that it cannot bo brought into action until difficulties have arisen and tho elements of con¬ flict have developed to a serious stage. As a result, many an effort to readjustment comes too lato in the game. It is nocossary to recognizo that change is a continuous procoss and that what is needed is permanent machinery to guide itf This is the principle of planful change0 III. It is because it operates on the basis of the above principles that the International Labor Organization, tho I,L,0, - is, in my opinion, tho most significant instrument of peaceful change in its field., The IoLr,0„ which is an association of 61 states, including the U,S»A„, follows in its work the principle of universality. The draft conventions - or international labor treaties - which it adopts at its annual Conferences - aro intended for adoption by all the states which are members of tho I»Lo0, The purpose of those draft conventions is to improve working conditions everywhere and to raise the standards of living of workers in all countries, thus tending to bring about greater equality of tho benefits derived from industrial develop¬ ment# The I«L®0, is a permanent organization with a positive and definite program of ]a bor roporms which it tries to put into operation steadily and systematically* The program of the I,L,0, implies tho necessity of peace¬ ful change, and the work of the I,L,0, consists largely in mapping out the concrete measures and draft conventions by which such changes may be effected for the benefit of the industrial population. Time doos not permit mo to cite concrete illustrations of the way in which those general principles are applied in practice. But I beg your indulgence for a concrcte illustration bearing upon the situation in the Far East - Japan has been a member of the I,L,0, since 1919, In the 17 years of its oxistence the ^„L,09 has adopted at its annual Conferences ovor 50 draft conventions. Those cover a variety of problons, such as the age of admission to industry, social insurance, hours of labor, employment of seamen, machinery for fixing minimum wages, etc. Of these 51 or 52 draft conventions Japan has ratified 13# These conventions fix minimum standards of workmen*s compensation for accident, the age of admission of young workers at sea, medical examination of workers on board ship, limiting or prohibiting night work in bakorios, fixing hours of work in commercial enterprises, etc. The point which I wish to emphasize here is this. By adopting the draft conventions of the I,L,0,, Japan improves the condition of her workers, raises their consuming and purchasing power, and indiroctly adjusts the rate of its industrial development to a pace which is more in accord with conditions in more advanced countries.

To put it briefly, tho I.L.O. is contributing to peaceful change by helping to raise the standards of living of the workers in all countries. By doing so, the I.L.O. helps to bring about a better balance between the growth of the internal market and foreign trade expansion^ By having its draft conventions rativied, the I.L.O. lifts international trade competition to a higher level. We have talked in our round tables about the effects of lower standards of living on international trade. Much has been said about the incomparability of different standards in different countries* It is true there is an important psychological and traditional element in the con¬ cept of*the standard of living. But this can and is much exaggerated. There are two facts which should be kept in mind. In the first place, diets arc becoming more and more a matter of scientific study and determination. No country in tho world can claim today that its entire population enjoys an adequate diet© Secondly, whatever the concept of the standard of life is in different countries - whether it emphasizes leisure or security or mobility or aesthetics - the mass of the people need a much larger income than they earn today to enjoy the standard they value. IV. The International Labor Organization has found it necessary, in pursuing its basic aims, to expand its work. At the present time, the IaLeO© is studying problems of workers1 nutrition, with a view to promoting better and more rational diets among workers in all countries. It is now engagea in a comprehensive survey of the textile industry of the world vn.fi a view to suggesting a program for its rational reorganization. But, in its essence, the program of the I.L.O. is concerned with industrial relations and social justice. While its jurisdiction may expand, it leaves a wide field of international economic and social relations un¬ touched. What the experience of the I.L.O. suggests, however, is the pos¬ sibility of applying its methods to other fields. What seems to he neoded for the promotion of peaceful change is the reorganization of oth6r inter¬ national institutions on the same basis of a definite and positive program animated by the same principles of universality, equalization of oppor¬ tunity, and systematic study of the ways and means by which conflict may be composed and adjusted. I cannot examine this in detail but I have sug¬ gested in the past that permanent international committees for tho consider¬ ation of problems of raw materials, finance, colonies, etc. be established. Such committees would be supplementary to some existing machinery and also to the idea of general economic conferences. VJo have had some disheartening experiences with general conferences. It has been ironically pointed out by one speaker that tho General Economic Conference increased tho trend towards national self-sufficiency, that the disarmament conference resulted in a new race for armaments, etc. This must be taken with a grain of salt. The General Conferences have also had important positive results, but it is true that tho whole conception of international conferences needs reexamination. A general conference can be successful only if it is hitched to a permanently working mechanism which can give it direction and technical aid. In brief, the question is how to endow peace with a positive pro¬ gram and how to devise machinery in the form of definite economic, social and political institutions which can map tho coursc of world development in such a way as to anticipate and obviate conflicts before they bocomo sur¬ charged with psychological complications. This means tho organization of world industries and of tho world market in such a way as to form a system of mutual interests.

V. Thcro is no real conflict between the picccneal procedures which have been urged upon us this morning and the general principles stated above. The daily intercourse of peoples gives rise to specific and concrete issues which call for specific and concrete handling® But such concrete procedures are likely to be more successful if they arc in line with well-considered general policies. To develop the simile used by one of the speakers this morning, if the ship must proceed slowly among the reefs and rocks of the seas, it can only do so when the pilot knows what his destination is. It is the goal that determines the route and not vice versa. A current of grim realism has run through the deliberations of this Conference, There has been evident a sense of the grave danger of War in the East and West# Nevertheless, this feeling of apprehension has not weakened the effort to find a rational way out. Those seeking rationality in life may not always succeed, but without their effort the ravajos of unreason would be far greater« To put it in a paradox, the less the apparent chances for its success, the greater the need for rational effort. The real issue is - can we cease being the victims of change and bocomo its guides in the inter¬ ests of a peaceful huaanity?

August 29, 1936 (Albert Sarraut) Again I am honored—this time to say the last words of this conference, or better still, to refer to the witty speech delivered to us a few evenings ago by Lord Snell, and literally to pour forth the last waves of the avalanche of elo¬ quence. I wish to place myself immediately under the invocation of one of the first kings of France, whom they called Pepin le Bref, because he was of a very short stature.. I am no king for the time being; my name is not Pepin, and I am. not so much of a dwarf, but I shall be brief. I now give you the pleasure of my promise to be brief. Because of that promise, I shall put aside the natural temptation which comes to me to extract and to resume, in this last speech, the political and moral philo¬ sophy wiich can very well be drawn from the labors of this conference. That would be intensely interesting, but too long. Nothing is as long as a summary. ".Then a man tells you that he is intending to summarize, bewardl The only exception to that rule which I know of is the summary given by the excellent rapporteur this morning, and I hope you will permit me to congratulate him together with the other fine speakers of the morning. It is a great personal pleasure for me to refer to the worthy interests of our discussions of the past fortnight. Naturally, I would ha\re preferred, not by national pride, but because of personal convenience, that the conferences had taken place in French, but if some of the ideas have by chance escaped me here and there, I have, nevertheless, been impressed by the science, by the depth of thought, the documentation, and by the good faith of all of those who have analyzed the great problems which we have tried to solve. I really take away with me a very high es- time for this conference; I don*t regret my long journey, and already I dream of purchasing my ticket for the next international meeting of the Institute throe years hence—if, of course, the good Good permits mo to live, and I see no special reason why he should not do so. I hope to find again at that time the same faces,, the same assembly, both masculine and feminine; they would not understand that a Frenchman, unless he were very depressed, would miss the opportunity of paying his respects to what we call in French the "weaker sex." Probably to vindicate our¬ selves, and because we feel that the intelligence and the heart of woman is in¬ finitely superior to that of man, we draw up Civil Codes to chain the power of this "weaker sex." Those are our weapons of Collective Security. We shall have inscribed in the annals of this magnificent and enchanting valley, if not concrete results, at least the strength of a great will in the direction of the preservation of peo.ee in the Pacific area. And so, %ve will not have spoiled the valley by bellicose attitudes, by words of resentment or hostility and the magnificent frame-work of Nature will have merited our respect. This same Nature gives to us a lesson of peace in its very serenity, in its calm, and by its security for these charming animals who live here among the trees without fear, and without apprv'hensiofi .of the Lav/ of the Jungle-~even without fearing man, since it is for¬ bidden to kill here. YJhat a beautiful thing if the same restraint could be extended one day to the human life and to the life of all the nations! Is all hope forbidden in this respect? Somctines it has occurred to me here in the great tranquility of these beautiful evenings, when the valley is enveloped in shadows and when the soft moon is illuminating the lofty haughtiness of the valley walls themselves in its

silvery light, and I said to myself that : "Vie too are down in the shadow; wo arc still in the shadow full of fears and menaces where we don't see clearly, where our prejedices, our instincts, our errors, and our ignorance buffet one another together into a confused scramble which can becomc murderous. But there is a higher light above; it is the light towards which xve should move because of its serenity—towards its truth, its sweetness, and towards the peace xvhich it showers upon us, when wo shall have the will and the courage to attain the very crest of free reason-Tthe heights where wisdom reigns in a fresh life- giving atmosphere. It is impossible to understand ourselves, to realize that we are all human, to live near each other affectionately and in confidence buffeting against insoluble difficulties? Here again 'the lesson of the valley comes to my mind. For the past fourteen days we have lived near one another in a charming international life— it was a universe in miniature; our different races have mixed easily in cordial relations towards which each one contributed his smiles and the best he could give; we exchanged in a brotherly way the pure water and the tomatoe juice; Americans and Japanese ladies have danced to the same rhythm; Russians and Chinese ladies have shared the pleasures of the same blues; and with jolly enthusiasm the mas¬ culine and feminine representatives of throe-fourths of the universe have mixed the bubblings of their cheerfulness in the rapprochements of the barbeque. V;'hy not try to carry over into the complex life of the world the spirit which enchanted our cordial little life hero in the valley? It is already such a short life that we have--why put into it the conflicts and miseries of nations? All our people need peace; no one, however heroic, desires deliberately to permit kill¬ ing or to 3$ill his neighbor. ITar is not the normal state of humanity. Uar doesn't pay; war is not in itself an ideal. The great efforts of mankind have been strained for centuries and centuries so that the life of our cities might be full of clear 303/ and of happy tasks, and not so that the streets should run rod with blood, be burned by fire or strewn with corpses. Undoubtedly such ^oy is necessary for all, some liberty for all, some justice for all, and some sun for all. Everyone ought to have his place in the sun--we must strive together in a friendly fashion close to one another. What we cannot do, what none of us can do, is to relinquish his place and to re-enter the shadow, taking his flag with him in abdication of his own civilization; for by so doing he would be injuring humanity as much as himself. Our civilizations are not irreconcilable; they are not contradictory; I have never believed, I i\ould never believe in the "inevitable" hostility of the East and the ".Test. I think that to the contrary we can mix the brightness and the beauties of these civilizations, as tho most different flowers combine themselves together to make up the harmony of a splendid garden. May each one of us bring his best seeds for composing the magnificent blossoming of tho garden of peace I In this way we shall be worthy of our title as men. May God help us and bless us, because He wishes peace to all men of good will.
