essay:div.essay:p: Secretariat 1936 Document 42 STATEMENT AT PLENARY SESSION ON ROUND TABLE TOPIC V, AUGUST 2 9, 1936 (Et i or.me Demi e ry) Mr. Chairman, Ladies and Gentlemen: I have today a great feeling of responsibility. The report which was asked of me is, I think, something in the nature of a resume of the discussions of a round table, "which is in itself, something of a resume of all the preceding round tables, I feel even more this responsibility because my English is rather deficient, and my vocabulary limited, Mark Twain said that he once heard a sermon which he considered excellent. When it was over he went to the preacher and congratulated him upon it. But, he added, that strangely enough, he noticed that all the words of the sermon were in a book he had at home. The clergyman seemed very much concerned. He discussed with Mark Twain at some length the possibilities of plagiarism and unconscious imitation* Twain promised him that he would send him the book he referred to; and on the morrow the clergyman did, in fact, receive a parcel from hLm, He opened it and found it contained the book. The book was a dictionary. Now, I think that personally I have a very groat advantage over this clergyman. You won!t be able to find all my words in the dictionary. The subjects which were discussed in the fifth round table can be, as you know, divided into two parts: The first, which is descriptive - the exposition of the redistribution of power in the Pacific area; and the second, which is constructive, and which, by that fact, has been much more difficult to deal with - the possibilities of the peaceful adjustment of conflicts. In many of the books of political science or economics, the part which concerns the description of facts or the critiques of the policies, is brilliant and accurate. The conclusive part,, which deals with positive proposals, is not as convincing or as sound, The action of the Institute of Pacific Relations, in in¬ sisting on the discussion of positive readjustments is all the more to be praised, I, Redistribution of Power. 1, Economic Factors As far as the redistribution of power in the Pacific is concerned, there was, I think, a general agreement on the fact that a change of balance of power in this area of the world, had been extremely rapid; a chajigo which was chiefly attributed to two main factors - an economic one and a political or military one. Economically there has first been the intense economic development of some countries: the quick industrial expansion of Japan, and also the rapid economic development of the USSR, especially in Siberia, And there has also to be taken into account, since a very few years, the economic reconstruction of China, But the character itself of the different economic policies, pursued by the various countries of the Pacific also had some effect on the balance of power itself. The policy of the NRA in the United States, or the one of the five year plans in the USSR, contributed to turn the attention of the people of these two

countries, chiefly to their own affairs5 and that was considered to be true to some extent, though in a less important way, of the British Empire, after the Ottawa agreements, While in Japan, whose raw materials are more scanty and markets more narrow, the policy of industrial development turned the attention of the Japanese people, more an d more towards foreign countries® 2, Political and Military Factors, But political and military factors were oven more discussed than the economic one. Due partly to strategical, partly to psychological reasons (the desire for isolation on the part of -America, the preference on the part of Great Britain, of social expenditures over military ones), it was recognized in more than one discussion that the two chief countries in the Washington Treaties - the United States and Great Britain - had not maintained the same degree of pre¬ dominance. The case of the United States was chiefly discussed. Even with the vast increase of its navy, in the last three years, is this country in a position to enforce in the West Pacific its traditional policy of the open door and the integrity of Chine,.? "Which naval base could be used efficiently for such action? Would Guam or Manila be of main importance? Or would the Aleutian Islands be better Opinions amongst American members differed widely on this point. They differed of course still more when it came to the point of comparing the different strengths of the navies and the armies, Japanese military expenditures were said to be very high; but Japanese members declared that the Russian military forces in the Far East •-.were superior in number to their own. The Russian members, admitted that the doubling of the Trans-Siberian Railway and the development of their heavy industries in Siberia, had much increased their power of resistance in the Far East, The part which might be played in a conflict by the air force remained also a still rather unknown factor, though a British expert declared that in his opinion, the possible action of aircraft in a conflict in the Pacific, would probably not be as important as it is generally thought, or as it would be in other parts of the world, where the distances were not so great, and the necessity of auxiliary boats for carrying the loads not so urgent. In fact, as far as military potentialities are concerned, no one would have expected the round table to clear the facts. An American member said that it would be necessary to have in Yosemito a general staff plus Einstein, to determine the relative forces of the Powers in the Pacific, There was still more discussion when coming to the study of the char¬ acteristics of the military forces of each nation. Several Japanese members complained of the charge which was made of their forces having an aggrossivo character, saying that it appeared, in fact, that most of the nations considered the forces of their neighbors to be aggressive, and their own to be merely for the purpose of defense, 3, The Washington Treaties, These changes in the balance of power, whatever had been their extent, were asserted, chiefly by the Japanese members, but also by a few others, to be an important factor in the breaking up in the Pacific of the diplomatic machinery, ihe^instance of th©^Washington Treaties was chiefly discussed, and the present period in the Pacific was characterized by an American member as the time of the

breaking up of tho Washington Treaty. Tho Washington Treaties and especially the Nine Power Pact, did not take into consideration the possible development of Russia which did not attend the conference. The Japanese Government, said a Japanese member, fully adheres today to the Nine Power Pact, But the same member added that it may be a problem, for the maintenance of the future peace of the Pacific, to consider modifications of the Nine Power Pact, in view of the funda¬ mental changes in conditions in the Pacific, An American member stressed the fact that, in tho opinion of many American jurists, the treaties become obsolete because of changed conditions, only if the negotiators of the treaties contemplated that such changes did render the treaties obsolete; and he insisted on the point that tho existence of a change in cir¬ cumstance would not give, in any case, a right to unilateral denunciation. It only would give the right to appeal to an International Court for decision. In fact, there wore some divergencies of opinion about the present validity of the Nine Power Treaty, The majority of'-tho members thought that it wb,s still legally valid in the. Pacific *" s\ach were some cf the main remarks which wore made about the changes in the balance of powers in the Pacific, It has been, I think, one of the merits of those who discussed this situation not to try to make it clearer than it was in reality, and not to try to enunciate into simple formulas, trends and potentialitie; which are in themselves rather confused. Possibilities of Readjustment As I said in the beginning, this part of the discussion was chiefly tho descriptive part and also the critical one. The members of the fifth round table then tried to come to more constructive topics. Ideas are like stones - there are two ways of using thorn: either to throw them at one another or to use them to build something with, I am not sure the members of the round table never proceeded in the first way. The contrary would have been monotonous. But thoy tried to follow chiefly the second method, 1, Economic Possibilities, (a) Raw Materials Amongst the possibilities of peaceful adjustment which were put forward, some were of an economic character, some of a political one. Economically tho problem of guaranteed access to raw material was generally tho starting point; but as soon as it was discussed, it was found that such a formulation of tho questic did not load very far. Access to raw material is nearly always guaranteed in time of peace. Even restriction schemes do not prevent access to raw materials, Tho question of acccss is chiefly important in time of war. It becomes then mainly a political question, and a question of communications. More definite appeared to be the problem, which is rather different, of the control of the production of raw material, control which, when it is financial, might have some economic advantages, as far as the balance of payment of the country is concerned, and when it is political, has chiefly military advantages. One Russian member emphatically declared that the cause of the acutsnoss of the problem of raw material lies in the fact of the military policies of the nations. The need of raw material, he said, was, generally speaking, not the cause of an aggression but, on the contrary, it was the desire for aggression which was the cause for wanting raw material control*

In conclusion, it was felt necessary to say more specifically, instead of "access to raw material," "access to raw material with easy purchase." Several members, including Japanese, indeed admitted that the main aspect of the problem of raw materials was how to acquire the means of purchasing them* Two means were chiefly discussed: (b) Export Trade First, the development of export trade. But of course when it came to the practical ways of developing this trade, opinions began to differ -widely. A return to free trade was judged by many as highly desirable, and belong¬ ing to a past time of happy memory. But the question of the choice between dif¬ ferent evils, that is, between methods of protection, was discussed at a greater length. Though there was no general consensus on the point, it might be seen from the records, that the members in favor of quotas were more numerous than those in favor of tariffs, Vvhile it was noted that in practice these two forms of pro¬ tection are simultaneous, quotas were said by many to be mofe flexible, and es¬ pecially was it admitted that by allowing the nations to come to a clearer view of their needs, they were preparing better the way towards international economic adjustments© As far as these international economic agreements were concerned, though multi-lateral agreements were generally thought theoretically better, bilateral ones were judged by many members the best way at present of breaking through trade barriers of the world. The value of an unconditional most-favored-nation clause, which r^ight give to bilateral trade agreements a greater international value was much questioned, due chiefly to the fact that it was evaded by quotas or by some subterfuge in the defining of goods. It was also suggested that, together with the negotiation of bilateral agreements, a meeting of an economic conference would help for the general planning of world economy. (c) Money Lending, But another method of developing the means of purchasing the raw materials was discussed to some extent: the revival of foreign lending. It was suggested that if the American people would utilize their reserves of gold and consent to lend again, it would tremendously help world trade. Two difficulties, chiefly of psychological character, were stressed by American members, the first one due to the borrowers themselves, who generally want the money but are not eager to accept any form of control; and the second one due to the lender, who had become nowadays not too confident, Much money had been frozen iri the world; and the word "frozen" is, as everybody knows, an academic term to express a practice which has become very popular indeed in the world, A suggestion was made by a British member that it would be necessary to offer an international guarantee to lenders. But, unhappily enough, the proposal was not carried further* 2. Political or Juridical Readjustments If, in the coarse of the first four round tables, economic developments occurring in the Pacific were discussed at greater length, in the last round table, as far as possibilites of readjustments were concerned, the discussion of political or juridical plans was chiefly insisted upon. The general question which was

discussod was tho following: Is there any machinery which would "be effective in the Pacific for maintaining peace? It was evident from tho beginning that two kinds of solutions were proposed: those bearing upon special, particular agreements, and those having a more general character and admitting some kind of system of collective security. (l) Particular agreements In the first category wore discussed some proposals of bilateral agreement.' (a) Russia-Japan A Japanese member emphasized the fact that, though it was always necessary to have a broad scheme of machinery, in the main, it is also indispensable to pay ■ attention to those narrow bilateral arrangements for solving disputes* The possibility of such agreements between Russian -and Japanese, and on the other hand between Chinese and Japanese, was envisaged# With regard to tho relations between Russia and Japan, it appeared that many of the members of the round table we re finding a pact of non-aggression be¬ tween the two countries highly desirable. On one hand, Russia had changed, its policy of concluding non-aggrossion pacts with its neighbors. On the other hand, one Japanese member said that, with regard to Russia, he vdshed that tho two countries would dispose of their disputes in a peaceful way; that fisheries and border disagreements could, in fact, bo settled in such a manner; some important diplomatic personages in Japan were, In fact, favoring such a pact. The presence of a huge Russian army in the Far East was, in his opinion, the most important factor which was bringing suspicion in Japanese minds. (b) China-Japan The problem of the rapprochement between China and Japan appeared to be more complex. Though both the Chinese and the Japanese expressed the wish for a friendly settlement of all questions outstanding between tho two peoples, it was seen that many difficulties still lie in the path loading toward such a result. One of the conditions which seemed to some of the Japanese members preliminary to such an agreement, was the Chinese obligation to prevent subversive anti-Japanese propaganda. But the main point at issue appeared to be on what situations was such an agreement to be drawn up. A Chinese member said that tho withdrawal of Japanese political and military operati ns in China proper and Inner Mongolia would be a prerequisite. Ho also asserted that the principle of non-recognition seemed to him to be one of the only principles still in effect in the Far East, vfhile a Japanese member em¬ phasized, that if China still does not recognize the fact that Manchoukuo has been established, there is no possibility of peaceful settlement of the Sino-Japanese dispute. An essential condition to such an arrangement between China and Japan was also,in the opinion of many of tho Chinese members, that any treaty between tho two countries ought to bo in an international framework, which would include also the U.S.A., the USSR and Great Britain.

(c) General Pact The discussion of a possible agreement between Japan and China was then directed towards the study of a more general pact. The possibility of such a now pact was discussed in each of the round tables^ i A Chinese member proposed a reiteration of the Nine Power Pact. Some members suggested that the USSR might bo invited to sign such a pact® Most of the members agreed on the fact, that in any case, periodic conferences of Pacific Powers should be hold, and some proposed that before any Pacific Power took any important stop in the Pacific, it should consult with the other states at a con¬ ference of Ambassadors. The most modest type of consultations seemed to many members better than nothing. However, the type of pacts without teeth seemed to some members, to be of a rather inefficient type, and together with the possibility of consultative pacts or bilateral agreements, there was discussed inthe round tables, the more ambitious question of collective security® (2) Collective Security (a) Collective Security and Poacoful Change. The nature of collective security itself was questioned by some members. They seemed to fear that there was, in fact, an opposition between the idea of collective security as it is understood today, and the need of peaceful change^ Several Japanese emphasized the fact that some nations ought not to regard collect¬ ive security as an attempt to maintain status quo at the expense of proletarian nations, but that it ought to be an attempt to build a really secure peace. But it was felt by many of the members, that there was no contradiction between collective security and peaceful change. One of them, a Russian ono, ex¬ pressed, however, the idea that the words "peaceful chango" were themselves not always clear enough. He admitted that there must be changes in political situa¬ tions as they are in nature; but that two conditions ought to limit peaceful change. First of all, force ought not to be considered as a main factor in the poaceful change; and secondly, peaceful change ought not to recognize the changes made by force in the past. Otherwise this change would begin with a provocation •^0 aggression. Peaceful change in his opinion, needs some previous requisite; and this previous requisite is the adoption of collective security. He proposed a new form of safeguarding peace which would bo acceptable to all nations - the meeting of an international permanent conforence of peace, "It is better, he said, "to use a peace conference before a war has begun than after," (b) Collective Security Pacts, With such a clarification in mind, it appeared to most of the members, that the establishment of an effective system of Collective Security in the Pacific would be highly desirable; but opinion began to diverge to a considerable extent, when the question of the possibility of such machinery was considered. A Canadian member emphasized the fact that Collective Security supposed no reservation on national honour nor indeed on vital interests. In his opinion, the nations which were not prepared to accept such conditions, would do better by not becoming party to such a pact. In fact the warmest advocates of Collective Security, and notably a French member, asserted that there ought to be some differentiation, in the framing of Collective Security, between the obligations of the different nations. Any general scheme ofCollectivc Security, such as the Covenant of the League 01

Nations, might leave room for rogional pacts, the members of which would be more closely interested in the conflicts of a specified region* The parties of region¬ al pacts -would be under tho obligation of applying military sanctions against an aggressor in their region, while the members of tho League as a whole, -would only have, at least in the beginning, to apply economic ones. It was to be understood that the members of such a regional pact should not bo allowed to force sanctions, until the universal organization had determined the aggressor, A, ' Some regional agreements of this kind were suggestod for application in the Pacific area* An American member proposed a regional security agreement be¬ tween Japan, U®S#S®R® and China, similar to some extent, to Locarno® A British member suggested for the Pacific, the building of a rogional League composed of the powers directly interested in the region concerned® The Pact of Paris would bo itself linked to this rogional League, which -would bo affiliated in some my to tho main League at Geneva® Though more modest in their application, these regional pacts of CoiJIaetivt Security, met with some skepticism amongst many members, with regard to the'possi¬ bility of their application. Many reasons were quoted for those difficulties® (°) difficultios» Isolationist opinions Firstly, it was stated that some countries of the Pacific had growing isolationist; tendencies® Public opinion in America was said by seme American members to seek to prevent any kind of legislation which migit lead to action being taken against an aggressor# Another member stated that he believed, that oven if there was a desire in America, amongst many people, to see the country play a full role in attaining poaco measures in the Pacific, where American in¬ terest was clear, the idea of a possible entanglement with Europo through the channel of the Pacifio, might deter them from wishing to join in any new pact# More than one American member said that he was himself in favour of Collective Security, but that the mass of the people were strongly opposed to it, as far as the country was concerned# One of them added, however, that tho interest which was taken "by the American people in the question of the Philippines,might bring his countrymen to a clearer idea of their international entanglements# Peelings against Sanctions The second difficulty was considered to be conriocted with the question of sanctions® Some members stressed tho fact, that even though their countries had subscribed, by being members of the League of Nations, to the appliance of military sanctions, they did not feel absolutely sure, that public opinion would permit their appliance when it came to the point of declaring war® A Japanese member said in substance, that he thought that he doubted his country could participate in any agreement or organization, which anticipated the use of sanctions®

Vital interests The third difficulty arose from the fact that some of the members put forward the question of the vital interests of nations# A Japanese member stated that xvhen a question of policy vital to Japan1s existence and growth, qomos^up, Japan, as, in his opinion, other nations, would be loath to have things decided by the counting o-f heads# No government in the world, ho said, would consent to leave the destiny of its own people to a body of outsiders; all countries, in his opinion, allowed only matters of comparatively minor importance to go before the permanent court, or a body consisting of a third person# While this opinion was opposed by some members, the fact that such on idea might' be prevailing in some countries, was considered in itself, to be a hindrance to the establishment of Collective Security# Such were some of the ideas which were brought out during the discussions, and the main proposals made for peaceful adjustment in regard to political pro¬ blems. It could not be hoped that any of the solutions proposed would find un¬ animous support. But, as one of the Chairmen of the Round Tables pointed out, the Institute of Pacific Relations is net a gathering of diplomats. The main purpose of the discussions of the Round Tables had been attained to a large extent, if the implications of each of the main solutions proposed had been clearly realized; if the contact between the different groups of people had con¬ tributed to make each point of view easier to understand; and helped to the growth of a psychology, if not of collective security, at least of better collect¬ ive understanding#
